{{infobox football tournament season | title = Uganda Cup | year = 1996 | other_title = | image = | imagesize = | caption = | country = {{UGA}} | num_teams = | defending champions = | champions = Uganda Electricity Board FC | runner-up = [[Nile Breweries FC]] | matches = | goals = | top goal scorer = | player = | prevseason = [[1995 Uganda Cup|1995]] | nextseason = [[1997 Uganda Cup|1997]] }} {{1996 football in Uganda}} '''[[Ugandan Cup |Uganda Cup]] 1996''' was the 22nd season of the main Ugandan [[Association football|football]] Cup. ==Overview== The competition was known as the '''Kakungulu Cup''' and concluded on 2 November 1996 at [[Jinja, Uganda|Jinja]] where Uganda Electricity Board FC beat [[Nile Breweries FC]] 1-0 in the final.{{cite news |title= Uganda 1996 - RSSSF (Mikael Jönsson ) |publisher=RSSSF Archive |year=1999–2010 |url=http://www.rsssf.com/tableso/oeg96.html |accessdate=2014-01-17}}{{cite web |url= http://www.kawowo.com/index.php/football/item/13292-uganda-cup-past-finalists.html|title= Uganda Cup Past Finalists |work=Kawowo Sports |accessdate=2014-01-18}} ==Quarter-finals== The 4 matches in this round were played between 7 October and 21 October 1996. {{Col-start}} {{Col-2}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:80%; font-size:100%" ! style= width="80px" |Tie no ! style= width="300px" |Home team ! style= width="80px" |Score ! style= width="300px" |Away team ! style= width="300px" | |- | 1 | '''[[Express FC]]''' | 2–0 | Mbale Dairy Heroes FC | ''7 October 1996'' |- | 2 | [[Police FC (Uganda)|Police FC]] | 1–2 | '''[[Nile Breweries FC]]''' | ''10 October 1996'' |- | 3 | [[SC Villa]] | 0–0

{{refimprove|date=August 2014}} {{Infobox sports competition event | event = 2015 CrossFit Games | competition = | image = 2015CrossFitGamesLogo.png | alt = | caption = | venue = [[StubHub Center]] | venues = | location = [[Carson, California]] | date = | dates = July 21–26, 2015 | competitors = | nations = | teams = | win_label = | win_value = | gold = | gold_nation = | gold2 = | gold2_nation = | gold3 = | gold3_nation = | silver = | silver_nation = | silver2 = | silver2_nation = | silver3 = | silver3_nation = | bronze = | bronze_nation = | bronze2 = | bronze2_nation = | bronze3 = | bronze3_nation = | previous = [[2014 CrossFit Games|2014]] | next = [[2016 CrossFit Games|2016]] | champions = | men = [[Ben Smith (CrossFit)|Ben Smith]] | women = [[Katrin Tanja Davidsdottir]] | team = [[Rich Froning Jr.|CrossFit Mayhem Freedom]] }} The '''2015 [[CrossFit Games]]''' were held on July 21–26, 2015 at the [[StubHub Center]] in [[Carson, California]]. [[Ben Smith (CrossFit)|Ben Smith]], of [[Virginia]], was the men's winner. A Games competitor every year since 2009, this was his first win (he placed third in 2011 and 2013). Smith secured the win in a dramatic final event by holding off 2014's second-place finisher [[Mat Fraser (athlete)|Mat Fraser]] who many had predicted would be the 2015 champion. [[Iceland]]'s [[Katrin Davidsdottir]], making her third Games appearance, was the women's winner, overtaking countrywoman [[Sara Sigmundsdóttir|Ragnheiður Sara Sigmundsdottir]], who led for much of the competition, in the final event. CrossFit Mayhem Freedom from [[Cookeville, Tennessee]], captained by four-time individual men's champion [[Rich Froning Jr.]], won the Affiliate Cup.
Approximately 273,000 participants signed up for the 2015 CrossFit Games Open, which was held over the course of five weeks in February and March. The top 20 men, 20 women, and 15 teams from the 12 American and Canadian regions, the top 30 men, 30 women, and 20 teams in the European and Australian regions, and the top 10 men, 10 women, and 10 teams from Latin America, Africa, and Asia qualified for the CrossFit Regionals. After three-day Regional competitions held around the world, the field advancing to the CrossFit Games was narrowed to 40 men, 40 women, and 40 teams. New for the 2015 Regionals, the 17 regions were combined into 8 "super-regions".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://breakingmuscle.com/functional-fitness/what-the-crossfit-games-2015-changes-mean-for-you |title=What the CrossFit Games 2015 Changes Mean for You |publisher=Breaking Muscle |accessdate=July 23, 2015}}</ref>
As in previous years, the men's and women's competitions were similar, with the only differences being weights of lifted objects, heights of obstacles, etc. First-time elements in 2015 included open-ocean paddleboard racing and pegboard climbing.
CrossFit also held a Masters competition where athletes aged 40 and above competed in their own age groups. Masters athletes qualified though the Open followed by an online Games qualification, called the Masters Qualifier, instead of Regionals. The top 20 Masters men and women in each age group were invited to participate at the Games.
In 2015, the CrossFit Games added a Teenage competition to the Open in two age groups (14-15 and 16-17) for boys and girls. Towards the end of the Open, it was announced that the top 10 in each age group after the completion of the Open would qualify to participate in the Games.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://games.crossfit.com/article/teenagers-advance-crossfit-games |title=Teenagers advance to the CrossFit Games |publisher=CrossFit Games |date=March 4, 2015}}</ref> The Teenage and Masters Games events were the same and took place from July 21–23.
==Individual==
===Wednesday, July 22, 2015===
====Event 1: Pier Paddle==== * 500 meter ocean swim * 2 mile paddle * 500 meter ocean swim
For the fourth straight year, the CrossFit Games began on the Wednesday before the traditional weekend events. The Games have started with a swim every year since 2011, with this year's event consisted of 500 meters of ocean swimming, followed by two miles of paddling on a [[paddleboard]], and finished with another 500 meters of ocean swimming.
Jonne Koski won the event for the men and [[Kara Webb]] won for the women.
====Event 2: Sandbag 2015==== The athletes moved weighted sandbags across the tennis stadium in the [[StubHub Center]]. They started by carrying/dragging the sandbags from the top of the stadium down to the floor, used a wheelbarrow to take them to the other side, and then pushed them over a wall and carried them to the top of the stadium. The men had to move 720 pounds and the women had 480 pounds total weight of sandbags. This event was nearly identical to an event held in 2010 except that the weight was increased and the wheelbarrows were specially made to handle the weight.
Lukas Högberg and Anna Tunnicliffe won the event men's and women's events, respectively.
===Friday, July 24, 2015===
====Event 3: Murph==== While wearing a weighted vest: * 1 mile run * 100 [[Pull-up (exercise)|pull-ups]] * 200 [[push-ups]] * 300 [[Bodyweight exercise#Legs/Glutes|air squats]] * 1 mile run
CrossFit's most famous hero workout, named for fallen sailor US Navy SEAL Lt. [[Michael P. Murphy]], usually performed by American affiliates on [[Memorial Day]]. The weighted vests are 20lbs. for men and 14lbs. for the women.
Björgvin Karl Guðmundsson won the men's event and Samantha Briggs won the women's. [[Samantha Briggs]] finished the event faster than any of the men aside from Guðmundsson.
====Event 4: Snatch Speed Ladder==== Three rounds of: * 5 squat [[Snatch (weightlifting)|snatches]]
Within each round, each snatch is heavier than the last (a "ladder"), and the starting weight increases each round. Those who complete the ladder the fastest move on to the next round. Jon Pera won the men's event and Brooke Ence won the women's.
====Event 5: Heavy DT==== Five rounds for time, with a 205-pound barbell for the men and a 145-pound barbell for the women: * 12 [[Deadlift]]s * 9 [[Clean and jerk#clean|hang power cleans]] * 6 [[Clean and jerk#jerk|jerks]]
"DT" is a CrossFit hero workout named for fallen airman USAF SSgt. Timothy P. Davis, and usually performed with a 155-pound/105-pound barbell for men/women. Ben Smith won the men's event and Ragnheiður Sara Sigmundsdottir won the women's.
===Saturday, July 25, 2015===
====Events 6 & 7: Sprint Course 1 & 2==== A sprint across the soccer field at the [[StubHub Center]] through four pylons in a zig-zag and over four [[hurdles]]. Sprint Course 1 started with the four pylons followed by the hurdles and Sprint Course 2 was in the opposite direction after one minute of rest.
Dan Bailey won both events for the men and Lindy Barber won Sprint Course 1 for the women while Kristin Holte won Sprint Course 2.
====Event 8: Soccer Chipper==== * 100 foot "Pig" flip * 4 legless [[Rope climbing|rope climbs]] * 100 foot [[Hand walking|handstand walk]]
The event took place on the soccer field and started with flipping a weighted box called a "pig". The box weight was 560 pounds for the men and 395 for the women, and the length was over 6 feet, making the flips more difficult than shorter objects that many athletes had trained with. The first two legless rope climbs were done on a 2-inch diameter rope and the last two on a 1.5-inch diameter rope. The handstand walks had to be completed in 50-foot unbroken increments.
Ben Smith won the event for the men and Elisabeth Akinwale won for the women.
====Event 9: Clean & Jerk==== * 1 rep max [[Clean and jerk|Clean & Jerk]]
Each athlete gets two 20-second windows in which to attempt their heaviest clean and jerk for one repetition.
Aaron Hanna won the event with a 350-pound lift for the men and Brooke Ence won with a 242-pound lift for the women.
====Event 10: Triangle Couplet==== 15–10–6 repetitions of: * Thrusters * Bar [[pull-up (exercise)|muscle-ups]]
Named "Triangle Couplet" because the repetitions per round are all [[triangular number]]s. A thruster in CrossFit is a combination of a [[front squat]] and [[push press]] in one continuous movement and the weights were 165-pounds for the men and 115-pounds for the women. A bar muscle-up is a pull-up variant in which the athlete pulls themselves over the top of the pull-up bar and finishes with the bar at their hips.
Mathew Fraser won for the men and [[Camille Leblanc-Bazinet]] won for the women.
===Sunday, July 26, 2015===
====Event 11: Midline Madness==== Six rounds of: * 400 meter run * 50 foot [[yoke]] carry
The event took place inside the soccer stadium with the 400 meter run going up the stadium stairs, behind the jumbotron, and down the stars on the other side. The yoke, weighing 380 pounds for the men and 300 pounds for the women, was carried 300 feet across the soccer field.
Jacob Heppner won for the men and Samantha Briggs won for the women.
====Event 12: Pedal to the Metal 1==== * 3 peg board ascents * 24-calorie row * 16-calorie bike * 8 [[dumbbell]] squat snatches
The peg board ascents involved climbing a peg board using only two wooden pegs. The 24 calories were rowed on a [[Concept2|Concept-2]] [[rowing machine]]. The 16 calories were pedaled on an [[Indoor cycling|Assault AirBike]]. The dumbbell squat snatches are performed with a 100-pound/70-pound dumbbell for the men/women respectively and done with alternating arms.
Spencer Hendel won for the men and Margaux Alvarez for the women.
====Event 13: Pedal to the Metal 2==== * 12 [[parallette]] deficit handstand push-ups * 24-calorie row * 16-calorie bike * 8 [[kettlebell]] deadlifts
This event took place two minutes after Event 12. The handstand push-ups were performed against a wall. The row and bike were identical to the previous event. The deadlifts were performed with a 203-pound/124-pound (men/women) kettlebell in each hand, and after every two lifts, the weights were carried forward.
Spencer Hendel won again for the men and Katrin Tanja Davidsdottir won for the women.

[[Paul Carcaterra]] (Sidelines) | Ratings = | Intl Network = | Intl Announcers = }} {{2018 Mid-American Conference football standings}} The '''2018 MAC Championship Game''' was a [[NCAA Division I college football]] conference championship game for the [[Mid-American Conference]] (MAC), that was played on November 30, 2018.{{cite web |title=MAC Announces Updated 2018 Football Schedule |url=https://getsomemaction.com/news/2018/5/31/mac-announces-updated-2018-football-schedule.aspx |website=getsomemaction.com |publisher=Mid-American Conference |date=May 31, 2018 |accessdate=August 27, 2018 |language=en}} It was the 22nd Mid-American Conference Championship, and was played at [[Ford Field]] in [[Detroit|Detroit, Michigan]]. Sponsored by the [[Marathon Petroleum|Marathon Petroleum Corporation]], the game was officially known as the '''Marathon MAC Championship Game'''. ==Teams== ===Northern Illinois Huskies=== {{main article|2018 Northern Illinois Huskies football team}} Northern Illinois went undefeated 6-0 in conference play, until the Huskies lost to Miami on November 14. The Huskies were able to clinch the West Division, after the last remaining contender, Western Michigan, lost their third conference game also that weekend, eliminating the Broncos from contention. Northern Illinois makes their first appearance in the title game since 2015. ===Buffalo Bulls=== {{main article|2018 Buffalo Bulls football team}} Buffalo was able to clinch the East Division after defeating the Falcons of Bowling Green at the end of the season, compelling a conference record of 7-1. The Bulls make their first appearance in the game since 2008. ===Buffalo vs. Northern Illinois series history=== The match up was the 13th meeting against the Bulls and the Huskies. They last played each other last season in Amherst, New York. Northern Illinois defeated Buffalo in a close win of 14-13. After the 2016 match up, Northern Illinois lead the series, 11-1. Buffalo has not won against the Huskies since 1968. The championship game was the first time in history that the two schools played in post season. {{-}} ==Game summary== ===Scoring summary=== {{AmFootballScoreSummaryStart|VisitorName=NIU|HomeName=BUFF|state=}} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=1 | Time=6:38 | Team=BUFF | DrivePlays=13 | DriveLength=94 | DriveTime=5:39 | Type=RushTD | Runner=Kevin Marks | yards=3 | Kicker=Alex McNulty | kickresult=good | Visitor=0 | Home=7 }} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=2 | Time=14:55 | Team=BUFF | DrivePlays=11 | DriveLength=94 | DriveTime=5:00 | Type=RecTD | Receiver=Anthony Johnson | QB=Tyree Jackson | yards=13 | Kicker=Alex McNulty | kickresult=failed | Visitor=0 | Home=13 }} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=2 | Time=9:51 | Team=NIU | DrivePlays=12 | DriveLength=75 | DriveTime=5:04 | Type=RecTD | Receiver=Spencer Tears | QB=Marcus Childers | yards=13 | Kicker=Andrew Gantz | kickresult=good | Visitor=7 | Home=13 }} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=2 | Time=5:41 | Team=BUFF | DrivePlays=9 | DriveLength=75 | DriveTime=4:10 | Type=RecTD | Receiver=Anthony Johnson | QB=Tyree Jackson | yards=26 | 2pt type=pass | 2pt result=failed | Visitor=7 | Home=19 }} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=2 | Time=1:42 | Team=NIU | DrivePlays=12 | DriveLength=53 | DriveTime=3:59 | Type=FG | yards=39 | Kicker=Andrew Gantz | Visitor=10 | Home=19 }} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=2 | Time=0:03 | Team=BUFF | DrivePlays=8 | DriveLength=70 | DriveTime=1:34 | Type=FG | yards=24 | Kicker=Adam Mitcheson | Visitor=10 | Home=22 }} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=3 | Time=11:25 | Team=BUFF | DrivePlays=8 | DriveLength=75 | DriveTime=3:35 | Type=RushTD | Runner=Jaret Patterson | yards=9 | Kicker=Adam Mitcheson | kickresult=good | Visitor=10 | Home=29 }} {{AmFootballScoreSummaryEntry | Quarter=3 | Time=0:17 | Team=NIU | DrivePlays=5 | DriveLength=34 | DriveTime=1:41 | Type=RecTD | Receiver=D.J. {{Infobox park | name = Addington Hills | photo = Addington-hills-view.jpg | photo_width = | photo_caption = View from Addington Hills viewpoint | type = Public park |map = Greater London | map_label =Addington Hills | location = [[Addington, London|Addington]] | coords ={{coord|51.363|-0.058|type:landmark_region:GB-CRY|display=title,inline}} | area = {{convert|130|acre}} | created = | operator = [[London Borough of Croydon]] | visitation_num = | status = | open = All year }}
'''[[Addington, London|Addington]] Hills''' is a park in [[Shirley, London|Upper Shirley]], [[London]], [[England]]. It is managed by the [[London Borough of Croydon]]. It was part of the old parish of [[Addington, London|Addington]] before the suburb of Shirley was developed in the 1930s. The site consists largely of woodland on a gravel bed, with London's largest area of heathland at its heart. It is a [[Site of Metropolitan Importance]]. In the mid-18th century, it was a noted [[cricket]] venue used by the then-prominent [[Addington Cricket Club]].
It is a peaceful area with many pathways close to central [[Croydon]]. There is a viewpoint with fine views across Croydon and across to north London, including [[London Docklands|Docklands]] and [[Parliament Hill, London|Parliament Hill]]. It is served by [[Coombe Lane tram stop]] on [[Tramlink]]. The park covers an area of {{convert|130|acre}}. The [[London Loop]] path runs through the park. The park is fully accessible at all times.
Addington Hills and neighbouring [[Croham Hurst]] form popular open spaces in Croydon. The seasonal changes of the colourful heather, birch, oak and pine and the variety of birds and other wildlife and the bracing situation on top of the plateau attract visitors to the area at all times of the year.
==Cricket venue== The first definite mention of Addington Hills in a cricket connection is a [[1745 English cricket season|1745 match]] there on Thursday, 23 May between [[Addington Cricket Club|Addington]] and [[London Cricket Club|London]]. Little about the match is known except that Addington won.<ref name=ACS21>{{cite book |last=ACS |authorlink=Association of Cricket Statisticians and Historians |title=A. Guide to First-Class Cricket Matches Played in the British Isles |year=1982 |publisher=ACS |location=Nottingham |page=21}}</ref><ref name=ASW36>{{cite book |last=Ashley-Cooper |first=F. S. |authorlink=F. S. Ashley-Cooper |title=At the Sign of the Wicket: Cricket 1742–1751 |year=1900 |publisher=''Cricket'' magazine |page=36}}</ref> The venue was used for [[First-class cricket|first-class matches]] on at least four occasions between 1745 and 1752, a period which coincided with [[Addington Cricket Club]] having one of the strongest teams in England during the careers of [[Tom Faulkner]], [[Joe Harris (cricketer)|Joe Harris]], [[John Harris (Surrey cricketer)|John Harris]], [[George Jackson (cricketer)|George Jackson]] and [[Durling (Surrey cricketer)|Durling]]. The last one known to have been played there was Addington v [[Dartford Cricket Club|Dartford]] on 12 August 1752.<ref>{{cite book |last=Buckley |first=G. B. |authorlink=G. B. Buckley |title=Fresh Light on 18th Century Cricket |year=1935 |publisher=Cotterell |page=30}} </ref>
{{Infobox cricket ground | ground = Addington Hills cricket ground | image = | imagesize = | caption = | location = [[Addington, London|Addington]] | home club = [[Addington Cricket Club]] | county club = [[Surrey county cricket teams|Surrey]] | established = by 1745 | last used = 1752 }}
== Facilities == Addington Hills facilities include: * Car parking – off Shirley Hills Road and Oaks Road, at the junction with Coombe Lane * Toilets * [[London Loop]] path * Chinese restaurant * Horse rides * Viewpoint
== Geology and topography == [[File:Addington Hills London Surrey UK Summer 2011.jpg|thumb|A path across Addington Hills]] Addington Hills reaches 460 feet (140 m) above sea level on a plateau of Blackheath Bed pebbles,<ref>i.e mainly rolled chalk flints, see [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZcMQAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA50&lpg=PA50&dq=blackheath+bed+pebble&source=web&ots=ZzbgUrU4XG&sig=bu9pLZHLSPvs1lYvo4WTCMSCPM0&hl=en&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=4&ct=result#PPA50,M1 Outlines of the geology of England and Wales, William Daniel Conybeare]</ref> which has been colonized by [[Ericaceae|heather]] with scattered groups of [[pine]]s and mixed plantations. The plateau drops sharply to the north, exposing the pebbles at the end of the gullies. To the north-west the plateau has been broken into by a number of steep valleys which are covered with [[birch]] to the west and [[oak]] to the east. Below the Blackheath pebbles an outcrop of less impervious Woolwich Beds was marked by a line of springs; these have disappeared, possibly due to a lowering of the [[water table]]. Addington Hills borders [[Coombe Park]] on its north, and [[Coombe Wood]] on its south.
== The site and its history == The area was originally called ''the hill of Pripledeane'' or ''Prible Dean'', a name meaning "Gravel Valley" that came from the [[Middle English]] words ''prebel'' ("gravel") and ''dene'' ("valley").<ref name="Mills">{{cite book|title=A Dictionary of London Place-Names|first=A.D.|last=Mills|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2010|isbn=9780199566785|page=3}}</ref> The land was acquired in four parts over a 45-year period. In 1874 the Croydon Board of Health purchased the first area following a public meeting; the lower area towards Shirley was added in 1903; the birch wood from Oaks Road to Coombe Lane was a gift from Frank Lloyd of Coombe Park Estate (after whom the nearby Lloyd Park was named), and finally the small pine woods in the south-east corner were added in 1919 bringing the site to its current size and forming the largest public open space in Croydon at the time.<ref name=lbp>Adapted from London Biodiversity Partnership / London's Heathland Heritage / Croydon Council information board near the Addington Hills car park.</ref>
In 1963 a viewing platform was provided by Alderman Basil Monk as a permanent commemoration of Croydon's 1960 Millennary Year. The platform, which is north-west of the restaurant, is at the top of steeply sloping ground and provides extensive views over Croydon and towards London. A low wall around the platform is engraved with directional lines and inscriptions indicating the main view points, such as [[Shooters Hill]], [[Epping Forest]], [[Fulham]], the Town Hall and skyscrapers of Croydon, and on a clear day the towers of [[Windsor Castle]]. Sadly, in recent years, the metal direction plaques have been removed from the balustrade wall by thieves (it’s a shame that the information wasn’t cut by the stonemason directly into the coping stones). The nearby [[Shirley Windmill]] can also be seen.
Addington Reservoir on the southern side of the Hills is the only area that is fenced off and not open to the public. The reservoir was built in 1888 and the Valve House was initially open to the public with refreshments being served from the ground floor and a residence above. An outbreak of [[typhoid]] in 1937 was traced to the reservoir and the cafe was quickly closed and the area fenced off.
Below the reservoir on the Coombe Road frontage was once Broadcombe Cottage, which was part of the Coombe Park Estate. Broadcombe was the old name for the tract of land alongside Oaks Road at the foot of Addington Hills. Also in this vicinity was the Lamb Inn, according to tradition the site of a fierce affray between [[smugglers]] and [[revenue officers]].
==Wildlife== The heathland areas are dominated by [[Ericaceae|heather]] and [[gorse]], with some [[bilberry]] and [[goldenrod]]. Drier spots are indicated by the occurrence of [[bell heather]]. Fine-leaved [[fescues]], wavy hair-grass and purple moor-grass dominate the acid grassland areas with a mix of [[wood sage]], [[heath bedstraw]] and other typical species. [[Marsh violet]] and [[hard fern]] (both London rarities) occur in the damper areas.<ref name=lhh>Taken from London Heathland Heritage website [http://www.lbp.org.uk/lhhwebsite/Sites/Croydon.htm Croydon page] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110613025339/http://www.lbp.org.uk/lhhwebsite/Sites/Croydon.htm |date=June 13, 2011 }}</ref>
Burrowing bees and wasps occur in the bare patches of soil and the bushy heathers and acid-loving grasses provide home to a wide range of insects, spiders and other invertebrates, each well adapted to the warm, dry conditions at ground level.<ref name=lbp/>
The invertebrate fauna plays an important part in supporting a range of birds and reptiles – and all benefit from the varied mosaic of open and scrubland habitats. In open areas, [[common lizards]] and [[slowworm]]s thrive. [[European green woodpecker|Green woodpecker]]s may be seen in the woods and on the heath, and [[goldcrests]] among the woodland edges and in the gorse.<ref name=lhh/>
==Habitats== The northern area of woodland is by far the oldest, in particular the very old oak [[pollards]] near Oaks Road. Other wooded areas are comparatively recent, and the small pine plantations near the southern boundary were only established during the mid-19th century.
Until the 1920s, there were only a few scattered oak, pine and birch on the hills, which were then almost entirely covered in heather. Now there is far more extensive tree cover, and heather is limited to the slopes and ridges where it tolerates the harsh conditions provided by the very dry and acidic poor soil.<ref name=lbp/>
==See also== * [[List of Parks and Open Spaces in Croydon]] * [[Ashburton Park]] * [[Woodside Green]] * [[Brickfields Meadow]] * [[Addington Interchange]]

revision.text:
The '''Aeroflot Open''' is an annual open [[chess]] tournament played in [[Moscow]] and sponsored by the airline [[Aeroflot]]. It was established in 2002 and quickly grew to be the strongest open tournament; in 2013 it was converted to a [[Fast chess|rapid]] and [[Fast chess|blitz]] event, while in 2014 it wasn't held. The first event had around 80 [[Grandmaster (chess)|grandmasters]], while in the second event 150 grandmasters participated. The tournament is played using the [[Swiss system]] and the winner is invited to the [[Dortmund chess tournament]] held later in the same year, a tradition begun in 2003. Beside the main tournament (A Group), there are also B and C-class tournaments. ==Winners== The name of the winner is boldfaced as in some editions, a few players ended with the same overall score. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" ! # !! {{for|the arena in Birmingham formerly known as Barclaycard Arena|Arena Birmingham}} {{coord|53|35|21|N|9|53|57|E|region:DE-HH_type:landmark|display=title}} {{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Barclaycard Arena | image = File:Barclaycard-Arena-Hamburg-Aussendarstellung.JPG | caption = | fullname = | location = Sylvesterallee 10
22525 [[Altona, Hamburg]]
[[Germany]] | coordinates = | publictransit = [[File:Hamburg S3.svg|30px]][[File:Hamburg S21.svg|30px]] [[Stellingen station|Stellingen]] | broke_ground = {{Start date|2001|06|13|df=y}} | built = | opened = {{Start date|2002|11|08|df=y}} | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Anschutz Entertainment Group]] | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = [[Euro|€]] 83 million | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | former_names = Color Line Arena {{small|(2002–10)}}
O2 World Hamburg {{small|(2010–15)}} | tenants = [[Hamburg Freezers]] ([[Deutsche Eishockey Liga|DEL]]) (2002–2016)
[[Handball Hamburg|HSV Hamburg]] ([[Handball-Bundesliga|HBL]]) (2002–2016) | seating_capacity = 16,000 | dimensions = | scoreboard = }} The '''Barclaycard Arena''' (originally known as the '''Color Line Arena''' and formerly known as '''O2 World Hamburg''') is a multipurpose [[arena]] in [[Hamburg]], [[Germany]]. It opened in 2002 and can hold up to 16,000 people (13,800 or 12,947 for sporting events). It is located at [[Altona Volkspark]], adjacent to the football stadium [[Volksparkstadion]] and the new [[:de:Volksbank Arena|Volksbank Arena]] in Hamburg's western [[Bahrenfeld]] district. The arena is primarily used for [[Performance|pop/rock concerts]] and was the home of [[Team handball|handball]] club [[Handball Hamburg|HSV Hamburg]] and [[ice hockey]] team [[Hamburg Freezers]] until both teams folded in 2016. The Barclaycard Arena is among the most modern venues in Europe. == History == [[File:Hamburg freezers vs. eisbären berlin @ colorline arena.jpg|thumb|200px|left|Interior view during warm-up before a [[Hamburg Freezers]] game in 2008.]] The arena opened in November 2002, is 150 meters long and 110 metres wide and has an elevation of 33 metres. Construction costs totaled approximately 83 million Euro (ca. [[United States dollar|US$]]121.5mn). The construction of the stadium was funded by the Finnish entrepreneur [[Harry Harkimo]] and the city of Hamburg, who sold Harkimo the land for a symbolic price of one [[Deutsche Mark|Mark]] and also financed infrastructure improvements with 12 million Marks (about 6.1 million euros) as a preparatory measure. In October 2007 the arena was sold to Anschutz Entertainment Group for an estimated 75 million Euros. On 6 May 2003, Irish vocal pop band [[Westlife]] held a concert for their [[Unbreakable Tour (Westlife concert tour)|Unbreakable Tour]] supporting their album [[Unbreakable - The Greatest Hits Vol. 1]]. == Naming rights == [[File:O2 World Logo.svg|thumbnail|150px|right|Logo of the arena during O2 sponsoring]] The arena was initially named after Norwegian ferry operator [[Color Line (ferry operator)|Color Line]] as the "Color Line Arena". In 2010 the sponsor changed to Spanish telecommunications company [[Telefónica]], naming the arena as "O2 World Hamburg". O2 sponsorship ceased in 2015, changing the arena name yet again, this time into "Barclaycard Arena". ==External links== *[http://www.barclaycard-arena.de/ Official Website] *[http://bilder-hamburg.info/index.php/Stadien/O2-World-Arena Pictures of the O2 World Hamburg] {{Commons category|O2 World (Hamburg)}} {{Music venues in Germany|collapsed}} {{EAA members}} {{O2 Venues}} [[Category:Basketball venues in Germany]] [[Category:Handball venues in Germany]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Germany]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Germany]] [[Category:Sports venues in Hamburg]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Altona, Hamburg]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2002]] [[Category:Event venues established in 2002]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Germany]] {{Germany-sports-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox film | name = Benched | image = | alt = | caption = | directors = [[Deaton-Flanigen Productions|Robert Deaton
George Flanigen]] | producer = [[Fred Roos]] | writer = [[Richard Dresser]] | based on = {{based on|''Rounding Third''|Richard Dresser}} | starring = [[John C. McGinley]]
[[Garret Dillahunt]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = FR Productions | distributor = | released = {{film date|2018|8|17}} | runtime = | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''''Benched''''' is a 2018 American [[Sports film|sports]] [[drama]] film directed by [[Deaton-Flanigen Productions|Robert Deaton and George Flanigen]] and written by [[Richard Dresser]], based on his play ''Rounding Third''. The film stars [[John C. McGinley]] and [[Garret Dillahunt]]. [[Fred Roos]] is producing the baseball film, while Deaton and Flanigen are making their feature film directing debut. It was released on August 17, 2018.{{Cite news|url=https://fanfest.com/2018/07/02/john-c-mcginley-and-garret-dillahunt-star-in-the-heartwarming-baseball-comedy-benched/|title=John C. McGinley and Garret Dillahunt Star in the Heartwarming Baseball Comedy ‘Benched’|work=Fan Fest {{!}} For Fans, By Fans|access-date=2018-08-10|language=en-US}} == Cast == * [[John C. McGinley]] as Don{{cite news|last1=Pedersen|first1=Erik|title=John C. McGinley Coaches Youth Baseball Team In ‘Rounding Third’|url=http://deadline.com/2015/06/john-c-mcginley-stars-in-rounding-third-1201440295/|accessdate=July 25, 2015|work=deadline.com|date=June 9, 2015}} * [[Garret Dillahunt]] as Michael{{cite news|last1=Pedersen|first1=Erik|title=Garret Dillahunt Joins ‘Rounding Third’ & ‘Come And Find Me'; Kal Penn Enrolls In ‘Speech And Debate’|url=http://deadline.com/2015/07/garret-dillahunt-rounding-third-come-and-find-me-1201483563/|accessdate=July 25, 2015|work=deadline.com|date=July 22, 2015}} *Reid Murray *Hadley Maxwell *Brogan Hall as Timmy == Production == [[Principal photography]] on the film began in July 2015 in [[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]], [[Tennessee]].{{cite news|last1=Evry|first1=Max|title=Garret Dillahunt Joins John C. McGinley in Baseball Story Rounding Third|url=http://www.comingsoon.net/movies/news/465145-garret-dillahunt-joins-john-c-mcginley-in-baseball-story-rounding-third|accessdate=July 25, 2015|work=comingsoon.net|date=July 24, 2015}} == References == {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|4779344}} [[Category:2018 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:Directorial debut films]] [[Category:Films shot in Tennessee]] [[Category:Films set in Tennessee]] [[Category:American baseball films]] [[Category:American sports films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:2010s sports films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] {{sport-film-stub}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use American English|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox award | name = Best Fighter ESPY Award | current_awards = | image = | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | description = best fighter | presenter = ESPN | country = | location = [[Microsoft Theater]], [[Los Angeles]] ([[2018 ESPY Awards|2018]]) | year = 2007 | holder = [[Terence Crawford]] (USA) | website = {{URL|http://www.espn.co.uk/espys/}} }} The '''Best Fighter ESPY Award''' is an annual award honoring the achievements of an individual from the world of [[Combat sport|combat sports]]. It was first awarded as part of the [[ESPY Award]]s in 2007, following the subsumption of the [[Best Boxer ESPY Award]], which was limited exclusively to boxers.{{cite web|url=http://www.bjpenn.com/mma-news/demetrious-johnson/sorry-conor-mcgregor-demetrious-johnson-wins-espy-fighter-year/|title=Sorry Conor McGregor, Demetrious Johnson wins the ESPY for "Fighter of the Year"|last=Taylor|first=Tom|date=July 13, 2017|publisher=BJ Penn|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180122235105/http://www.bjpenn.com/mma-news/demetrious-johnson/sorry-conor-mcgregor-demetrious-johnson-wins-espy-fighter-year/|archive-date=January 22, 2018|dead-url=no|access-date=January 21, 2018}} The Best Fighter ESPY Award trophy, created by sculptor [[Lawrence Nowlan]],{{cite news|last=Avard|first=Christian|title=Sculptor commissioned to complete Joe Frazier statue has died|url=http://www.timesargus.com/article/20130802/NEWS03/708029923/0/FEATURES10|newspaper=[[Barre Montpelier Times Argus]]|date=August 2, 2013|access-date=January 21, 2018|dead-url=yes|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140221231935/http://www.timesargus.com/article/20130802/NEWS03/708029923/0/FEATURES10|archive-date=February 21, 2014}} is presented to the [[Professional boxing|professional]] or [[Amateur boxing|amateur]] boxer or [[Mixed martial arts|mixed martial artist]] adjudged to be the best in a given calendar year at the annual ESPY Awards ceremony in [[Los Angeles]]. [[Voting|Balloting]] for the award is undertaken by fans over the Internet from between three and five choices selected by the ESPN Select Nominating Committee, which is composed of a panel of experts.{{cite book|authorlink=Murry R. Nelson|first=Murry R.|last=Nelson|title=American Sports: A History of Icons, Idols and Ideas|url=https://books.google.com/?id=tfTXAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA399#v=onepage&q&f=false|publisher=[[ABC-CLIO]]|year=2013|isbn=0-313-39753-8|location=[[Santa Barbara, California]]|pages=399–401|access-date=March 25, 2018|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180325040624/https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=tfTXAQAAQBAJ&pg=PA399&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q&f=false|archive-date=March 25, 2018}} It is conferred in July to reflect performance and achievement over the preceding twelve months.{{cite press release|title=New categories unveiled for The 2002 ESPY Awards|url=http://www.espn.com/espy2002/s/awardcategories.html|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2002|access-date=December 20, 2017|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171222052554/http://www.espn.com/espy2002/s/awardcategories.html|archive-date=December 22, 2017}} The inaugural winner of the Best Fighter ESPY Award was American [[welterweight]] champion [[Floyd Mayweather Jr.]], who defeated the incumbent category title holder [[Oscar De La Hoya]] two months prior.{{cite web|title=ESPYs: Couture and Jackson miss out|url=https://www.mmamania.com/2007/07/12/espys-couture-and-jackson-miss-out|publisher=[[SB Nation|MMA Mania]]|date=July 12, 2007|access-date=January 21, 2018|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123072350/https://www.mmamania.com/2007/07/12/espys-couture-and-jackson-miss-out|archive-date=January 23, 2018}} He is one of two people to have been presented with the award more than once, winning the accolade a total of six times;{{cite news|first=Rosalinda L.|last=Orosa|title=Mayweather edges Pacquiao, cops 2014 ESPY Best Fighter plum|url=http://www.philstar.com/sports/2014/07/17/1347241/mayweather-edges-pacquiao-cops-2014-espy-best-fighter-plum|newspaper=[[The Philippine Star]]|date=July 17, 2014|access-date=January 21, 2018|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123075340/http://www.philstar.com/sports/2014/07/17/1347241/mayweather-edges-pacquiao-cops-2014-espy-best-fighter-plum|archive-date=January 23, 2018}} Mayweather was also nominated in 2015.{{cite news|title=Floyd Mayweather taunted by UFC star Ronda Rousey|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/boxing/floyd-mayweather/11743475/Floyd-Mayweather-taunted-by-UFC-star-Ronda-Rousey.html|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=July 16, 2015|access-date=January 21, 2018|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180122235056/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/othersports/boxing/floyd-mayweather/11743475/Floyd-Mayweather-taunted-by-UFC-star-Ronda-Rousey.html|archive-date=January 22, 2018}} Filipino boxer [[Manny Pacquiao]] has the second most number of awards won with victories in 2009 and 2011.{{cite news|last=Ramos|first=Josef T.|title=Pacquiao wins second ESPY Award|url=http://www.pressreader.com/philippines/manila-times/20110715/282222302408600|newspaper=[[The Manila Times]]|date=July 15, 2011|access-date=January 21, 2018|via=[[PressReader]]|dead-url=no|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180123072306/http://www.pressreader.com/philippines/manila-times/20110715/282222302408600|archive-date=January 23, 2018}} It has been presented to one woman in its history, American [[bantamweight]] mixed martial arts fighter [[Ronda Rousey]] in 2015. {{As of|2018}}, boxers have been most successful at the ESPY Awards with nine victories and twenty-four nominations, followed by mixed martial arts with three wins and nineteen nominations. The winner of the 2018 Best Fighter ESPY Award was American [[light welterweight]] boxer [[Terence Crawford]] who claimed his third boxing title by defeating Australian [[Jeff Horn]] and extended his winning record to 33–0. ==List of winners and nominees== {|class="sortable wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center" |- ! scope=col | Year ! scope=col class=unsortable | Image ! scope=col | Winner ! scope=col | Nationality ! scope=col | Sport ! scope=col | Sanctioning body or league ! scope=col | Weight class ! scope=col class=unsortable | Nominees ! scope=col class=unsortable | Ref. |- | [[2007 ESPY Awards|2007]] | [[File:Mayweather.jpg|100px|alt=Floyd Mayweather Jr at a WWE event in 2008]] ! scope=row | {{sortname|Floyd|Mayweather Jr.}} | {{flag|USA}} | [[Boxing]] | {{n/a}} | [[Welterweight]] | align=left | [[Miguel Cotto]] ({{flag|PRI}}) – [[Boxing]]

{{Infobox stadium | name = Bud Metheny Baseball Complex | nickname = The Bud | image = [[Image:Methenycomplex.JPG|250px|center|Bud Metheny Baseball Complex]] | caption = | fullname = | former_names = | location = 43rd Street and Parker Avenue
Norfolk, VA 23508 | coordinates = {{coord|36.88375|N|76.309454|W|region:US_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | opened = 1983 | renovated = 2008, 2011, 2012 | owner = [[Old Dominion University]] | operator = Old Dominion University | surface = Natural grass | scoreboard = Electronic | capacity = 2,500 | record_attendance = 2,125 — April 25th, 1984 vs. [[Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University|Virginia Tech]] Hokies | dimensions = Left Field — 325 feet
Left Center - 375 feet
Center Field — 395 feet
Right Center - 375 feet
Right Field — 325 feet | tenants = [[Old Dominion Monarchs baseball]] ([[Conference USA|C-USA]]) (1983-Present)
[[Colonial Athletic Association Baseball Tournament|CAA Tournament]] (1994)
[[Sun Belt Conference Baseball Tournament|Sun Belt Tournament]] (1983, 1985, 1987) | embedded = | website = {{URL|http://www.odusports.com/ot/oldd-new-facilities.html}} }} The '''Bud Metheny Baseball Complex''' is a [[stadium]] on the campus of [[Old Dominion University]] in [[Norfolk, Virginia|Norfolk]], [[Virginia]], USA. It is primarily used for [[baseball]], and is the home field of the [[Old Dominion Monarchs baseball]] team. The Monarchs are members of [[Conference USA]]. The ballpark has seating for 2,500 spectators in three sections of raised aluminum bleachers. The stadium complex also includes locker rooms, a concession stand, offices, four batting cages, a picnic area and a fully enclosed press box.{{cite web |url=http://grfx.cstv.com/photos/schools/oldd/sports/m-basebl/auto_pdf/mediaguide-09-section2.pdf |title= 2009 Old Dominion Baseball Media Guide |accessdate=2010-04-25 |date=February 2009 |publisher=[[Old Dominion University]] Athletics}} The facility replaced the university's football stadium, [[Foreman Field]], as the home of the baseball team.{{cite web |url=http://www.lib.odu.edu/exhibits/odu75thanniversary/foreman.htm |title= ODU Libraries Exhibit -- ODU 75th Anniversary -- 2005 |accessdate=2010-04-23 |date=2010-01-06 |publisher=[[Old Dominion University]] Library}} The ballpark is named after former Old Dominion head basketball [[Coach (basketball)|coach]], baseball [[Manager (baseball)|manager]], and [[athletic director]] [[Bud Metheny]], who worked for the university from 1948 to 1980 after an eleven-year stint in the [[New York Yankees]] organization including a [[World Series]] championship in [[1943 World Series|1943]]. He compiled a record of 423 wins, 363 losses and 6 ties as manager of the Monarchs. Metheny's jersey number, 3, has been retired by the university and is displayed on the right field wall of the stadium. The stadium opened for the 1983 baseball season, with the first game being a 7–2 Old Dominion win over [[Millersville University of Pennsylvania|Millersville University]]. The complex was not dedicated until April 25, 1984 with a game against the [[Virginia Tech]] [[Virginia Tech Hokies#Baseball|Hokies]]. That night's crowd of 2,125 is the highest attendance in stadium history.{{cite web |url=http://hamptonroads.com/2010/04/odu-baseball-fan-looks-fill-stands |title= ODU baseball fan looks to fill stands |accessdate=2010-04-23 |author=Molinaro, Bob |date=2010-04-21 |publisher=[[The Virginian-Pilot]]}} The ballpark hosted the [[Sun Belt Conference Baseball Tournament]] in 1983, 1985, and 1987, and the [[Colonial Athletic Association Baseball Tournament]] in 1994. Old Dominion defended home field and won the 1985 Sun Belt and 1994 Colonial championships. The stadium has also hosted multiple [[Virginia High School League|Virginia district and state]] high school baseball tournaments. The Monarchs tied the NCAA record for [[double play]]s completed in a single game on May 14, 1985, with 7 during a home game against the [[Western Kentucky Hilltoppers]].{{cite web |url=http://www.gotigersgo.com/sports/m-basebl/recaps/041106aab.html |title= Tiger Defense Ties NCAA Record with Seven Double Plays in 12-1 Win over Murray State |accessdate=2010-04-23 |date=2006-04-11 |publisher=[[University of Memphis]] Athletics}} There have been eight [[no-hitter]]s pitched at the stadium, all completed by Monarch pitchers. As of the completion of the 2012 season, Old Dominion has a record of 600 wins and 280 losses at the Bud, for a winning percentage of .682. The stadium received a new video-LED scoreboard for the 2009 season as part of a partnership between Old Dominion and [[CBS College Sports Network#Official athletic partnerships|CBS Collegiate Sports Properties]].{{cite web |url=http://www.odusports.com/genrel/080108aad.html |title=ODU Athletics Announces Multimedia Rights Partnership with CBS Collegiate Sports Properties |accessdate=2010-04-25 |date=2008-08-01 |publisher=[[Old Dominion University]] Athletics |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110726234102/http://www.odusports.com/genrel/080108aad.html |archivedate=2011-07-26 |df= }} The facility underwent an additional three million-dollar renovation for the 2011 season that erected a batters' backdrop in center field, locker room refurbishments and a beer garden. Renovations continued before the 2012 season included brick walls added down the foul lines, a clock above the scoreboard, and a custom outfield wall with images of former Monarchs who have played in the [[Major League Baseball|major leagues]].{{cite web |url=http://www.odusports.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/021012aaa.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120906012418/http://www.odusports.com/sports/m-basebl/spec-rel/021012aaa.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-09-06 |title=The Bud Metheny Baseball Complex Gets A Facelift |accessdate=2012-03-29 |date=2012-02-10 |publisher=[[Old Dominion University]] Athletics }} ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Old_Dominion_University}} {{Conference USA baseball venue navbox}} {{Virginia NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bud Metheny Baseball Complex}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Virginia]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Old Dominion Monarchs baseball]] [[Category:Sports venues in Hampton Roads]] [[Category:Sports venues in Norfolk, Virginia]] [[Category:1983 establishments in Virginia]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1983]]

[[File:Caduta.jpg|thumb|Paolo Locci, an Italian Circus Artist on Chinese Pole.]] [[File:Leosvel et Diosmani - 4.jpg|thumb|250px|Cuban acrobatic artists Leosvel and Diosmani on the Chinese pole.]] '''Chinese poles''' are vertical poles on which [[circus performer]]s climb, slide down and hold poses. The poles are generally between {{convert|3|and|9|m|ft|0}} in height and approximately {{convert|2|to|3|in|cm|0}} in diameter.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nica.com.au/dictionary |publisher=National Institute of Circus Arts |title=Circus Dictionary |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091013140359/http://www.nica.com.au/dictionary |archivedate=2009-10-13 |df= }}</ref> Some poles have a slightly larger pole that rotates around the static central pole using [[ball bearing]]s. This rotating pole allows a performer to spin on the vertical axis, giving a performer the ability to incorporate rate of spin into what would otherwise be static moves. Bringing the body closer into the pole causes the performer to spin faster. A few Chinese pole tricks have been incorporated with [[Pole dance|pole dancing]] techniques.
The poles are sometimes covered with rubber to improve grip. However, the rubber can cause [[friction burn]]s on parts of the Chinese pole artists' bodies. Acrobats often wear multiple layers of clothing to prevent such burns and bruises.
The most famous trick is "[[Human Flag|the flag]]" where the artist hangs straight out from the pole with his or her hands. This requires a very strong upper body. A few people are able to do push ups in this position, and even fewer can rotate the legs around in a circle—this requires enormous [[core strength]].
==Gallery== <gallery widths="225" heights="150"> File:Chinese Pole Dance.jpg|Example of Chinese pole dancing from China File:Chinese Pole example.jpg|Demonstration of the Monkey sit </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:Circus skills]]
{{sport-equipment-stub}}

construction_cost = [[Pound sterling|£]] 14 million | capacity = 10,105<ref name="FL">{{cite web | url=http://www.football-league.co.uk/clubs/20100801/colchester-united_2293500_691564 | title=Colchester United | work=[[The Football League]] | date= | accessdate=26 January 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140924044017/http://www.football-league.co.uk/clubs/20100801/colchester-united_2293500_691564 | archivedate=24 September 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref> | suites = 24 | record_attendance =10,064 ([[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United]] vs [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]], 16 January 2010) | tenants = [[Colchester United F.C.]] }}
'''Colchester Community Stadium''', known for sponsorship reasons as the '''JobServe Community Stadium''', is a [[association football|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Colchester]], England. It is the home of [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United Football Club]]. It has a capacity of 10,105 and opened in August 2008 in time for the [[2008–09 Colchester United F.C. season|2008–09 season]].<ref name="FL"/>
A stadium working party was first set up by [[Borough of Colchester|Colchester Borough Council]] in 1976 in order to assess the feasibility and possible location for a new stadium for Colchester United.<ref name="CFCL">{{cite news |url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/archive/2004/09/24/5433021.Colchester__Cuckoo_Farm_or_cuckoo_land_/ |title=Cuckoo Farm or cuckoo land? |newspaper=Evening Gazette |location=Colchester |last= |first= |date=24 September 2004 |accessdate=26 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140127123659/http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/archive/2004/09/24/5433021.Colchester__Cuckoo_Farm_or_cuckoo_land_/ |archivedate=27 January 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> After 30 years of discussions and various site suggestions, a location in the north of Colchester called Cuckoo Farm on land owned by Colchester Borough Council was settled on. Detailed planning permission was fully granted in June 2007 on the stadium which would cost [[Pound sterling|£]]14 million, replacing the club's [[Layer Road]] ground, which had been their home since Colchester United's foundation in 1937.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/colchester_united/6254044.stm | title=Colchester gets stadium go-ahead | work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=29 June 2007 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref> Work began in July 2007<ref name="BBC 230707">{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/essex/6911355.stm | title=Building work on stadium begins | work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=23 July 2007 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref> and construction was completed in August 2008 ahead of Colchester United's first match at the stadium.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/sport/colchesterunited/3567876.How_will_you_be_getting_there_/ | title=How will you be getting there? |newspaper=Colchester Gazette |location=Colchester |last= |first= |date=4 August 2008 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref>
After ten years of sponsorship, it was announced that the naming rights would switch from Weston Homes to [[JobServe]] in another ten year deal. The stadium would now be known as the JobServe Community Stadium.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.cu-fc.com/news/2018/june/us-flash-jobserve-are-new-stadium-sponsors/ |title=U's Flash: JobServe Are New Stadium Sponsors |last=Hudson |first=Matt |date=1 June 2018 |publisher=Colchester United FC |accessdate=2 June 2018 }}</ref>
==History==
===Origin=== [[File:Colchester United's Layer Rd Ground - geograph.org.uk - 63984.jpg|thumb|left|[[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United's]] former [[Layer Road]] ground in October 2005]] [[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United's]] previous ground, [[Layer Road]], was built in 1910, homing United's predecessors [[Colchester Town F.C.|Colchester Town]].<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.eadt.co.uk/news/colchester_layer_road_s_future_finally_announced_1_979760 | title=Colchester: Layer Road's future finally announced |newspaper=East Anglian Daily Times |location=East Anglia |last=Keeley |first=Amie |date=30 July 2011 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref> Town were an amateur club and were wound down in 1937 to begin a professional club for [[Colchester]] that would be known Colchester United, as the new club moved into Town's Layer Road ground.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cu-fc.com/news/article/club-history-town-era-230315.aspx | title=The Colchester Town Era | work=[[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United FC]] |date=11 August 2013 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref> With an ageing stadium, throughout the 1970s to the mid-2000s, Colchester United and [[Borough of Colchester|Colchester Borough Council]] had been looking to re-home the club. Attention was first brought to the idea of relocation during the 1970s, when club chairman Maurice Cadman announced that Layer Road required [[Pound sterling|£]]280,000 of basic improvements to meet the required safety legislation of the time. When the ground was purchased from the Council in 1971, a covenant was placed on Layer Road that the site could not be sold to be developed as housing. Potential resolutions for the problem included moving the pitch and building a new main stand, but proved to be too expensive for the club's ailing finances. The plans would have created an 'adequately' sized stadium with an 18,000 capacity, though the season ended with an average of just 3,818 in attendance.<ref name="70s80s">{{cite web | url=http://www.cu-fc.com/news/article/history-1970s-and-1980s-230070.aspx | title=The 1970s and 1980s | work=[[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United FC]] |date=11 July 2012 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref>
In 1976, Colchester Borough Council set up a stadium working party to work towards solutions, locations and study the feasibility for a new stadium for the town.<ref name="CFCL"/> During the [[1980–81 Colchester United F.C. season|1980–81 season]], plans were submitted for an all-seater stadium at the Avenue of Remembrance, Colchester. However, the club ended the season 22nd out of 24 in the [[Football League Third Division|Third Division]] table and relegated to the [[Football League Fourth Division|Fourth Division]], with an average gate of just 2,641 and a new all-time lowest attendance of 1,430. The stadium plan was rejected by the council on the grounds of the covenant restrictions.<ref name="70s80s"/>
In the wake of the [[Bradford City stadium fire]] on 11 May 1985 which left 56 people dead,<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/may/11/newsid_2523000/2523561.stm | title=Fans killed in Bradford stadium fire |newspaper=[[BBC News]] |location=London |last= |first= |date=11 May 1985 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref> owing to the stadium's antiquated wooden structure, it became of utmost importance to accelerate Colchester United's move from the timber-constructed Layer Road stands to a new stadium.<ref name="70s80s"/> Just 18 days later, the [[Heysel Stadium disaster]] occurred, leading to 39 deaths and hundreds of injuries.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/liverpool/content/articles/2006/12/04/local_history_heysel_feature.shtml | title=Heysel disaster | work=[[BBC]] |date= |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref> Layer Road faced £500,000 of safety improvements, but with no money, the club closed sections of the ground which reduced capacity to 4,900. A new location for a replacement stadium was mooted at Turner Rise, Colchester, as new owner and chairman Jonathan Crisp introduced developers Norcross Estates as shirt sponsors for the [[1987–88 Colchester United F.C. season|1987–88 season]]. Crisp considered selling Layer Road and ground-sharing [[Portman Road]] with neighbours and rivals [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] whilst the Turner Rise stadium was constructed. However, the plans were delayed and eventually scrapped, with Crisp's plan to ground-share swayed by a group of Colchester United's former directors. A later plan to build a stadium at Wick Lane, [[Ardleigh]] saw plans thrown out as Colchester were relegated from [[the Football League]] for the first time in 40 years.<ref name="70s80s"/>
Layer Road was sold back to the Council for £1.2 million in the early 1990s in order to clear Colchester United's debts, with the club leasing the stadium for three years. Following this, the Football League required all clubs to have a minimum lease of ten years on all stadia, to which the Council extended the arrangement. Meanwhile, the Borough Council also determined ten potential sites for a new stadium to be contracted, with each examined. With the lease on Layer Road due to expire in 2002, [[Kirklees]] [[Alfred McAlpine|McAlpine]] were commissioned as consultants for a new stadium in 1998. A preferred site at Cuckoo Farm was identified, with additional benefit being that the land was already owned by the Council.<ref name="90s00s">{{cite web | url=http://www.cu-fc.com/news/article/club-history-90s-and-00s-230024.aspx | title=The 1990s and 2000s | work=[[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United FC]] |date=11 August 2013 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/archive/1998/10/23/5538327.Cuckoo_Farm_is_target_site_for_new_U_s_ground/ |title=Cuckoo Farm is target site for new U's ground |newspaper=Evening Gazette |location=Colchester |last= |first= |date=23 October 1998 |accessdate=26 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203045141/http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/archive/1998/10/23/5538327.Cuckoo_Farm_is_target_site_for_new_U_s_ground/ |archivedate=3 February 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
===Planning=== With a site now chosen, plans were submitted in April 1999 which would include an earmarked 30-acre site, ten acres of which would accommodate car parking and a [[park and ride]] system, and a further ten for commercial use, including hotels and leisure facilities. The application was submitted simultaneously with plans for a new major junction (junction 28) on the [[A12 road (England)|A12]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/archive/1999/04/06/5531630.Soccer__Stadium_hope_for_Colchester/ |title=Stadium hope for Colchester |newspaper=Evening Gazette |location=Colchester |last= |first= |date=6 April 1999 |accessdate=26 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140127123646/http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/archive/1999/04/06/5531630.Soccer__Stadium_hope_for_Colchester/ |archivedate=27 January 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Outline planning consent was approved in July 2003, including approval for 1,500 homes, a police station and a primary school.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/archive/2003/08/01/5450591.Soccer__U_s_stadium_on_its_way/ |title=U's stadium on its way |newspaper=Evening Gazette |location=Colchester |last= |first= |date=1 August 2003 |accessdate=26 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140127123733/http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/archive/2003/08/01/5450591.Soccer__U_s_stadium_on_its_way/ |archivedate=27 January 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
With the ''Community Stadium Now!'' petition set up by Colchester's Evening Gazette newspaper and with 13,000 signatures in support, the Cuckoo Farm plans were submitted to [[Deputy Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|Deputy Prime Minister]] [[John Prescott]] for a decision to be made on the application.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/archive/2004/12/16/5429737.Colchester__Cuckoo_Farm_plan_goes_to_Prescott/ |title=Cuckoo Farm plan goes to Prescott |newspaper=Evening Gazette |location=Colchester |last= |first= |date=16 December 2004 |accessdate=26 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140127123622/http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/archive/2004/12/16/5429737.Colchester__Cuckoo_Farm_plan_goes_to_Prescott/ |archivedate=27 January 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Prescott gave his approval for the regeneration project for the north of Colchester in January 2005, meaning construction work could begin as early as 2006 after planning application had been submitted in autumn 2005.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/archive/2005/01/19/5428747.Colchester__Deputy_PM_gives_OK_to_stadium_plan/ |title=Deputy PM gives OK to stadium plan |newspaper=Evening Gazette |location=Colchester |last= |first= |date=19 January 2005 |accessdate=26 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20140127123623/http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/archive/2005/01/19/5428747.Colchester__Deputy_PM_gives_OK_to_stadium_plan/ |archivedate=27 January 2014 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
On 13 November 2006, Colchester United chief executive Marie Partner announced to United fans gathered at Colchester's Moot Hall that the stadium had received the go-ahead after clearing a major hurdle. The Council had backed the £14.23 million stadium by taking out a £10.23 million loan. At this point, the petition had also gathered over 30,000 signatures.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/1019824.Colchester__U_s_fans_celebrate_town_stadium_go_ahead/ | title=Colchester: U's fans celebrate town stadium go-ahead|newspaper=Colchester Gazette |location=Colchester |last= |first= |date=14 November 2006 |accessdate=23 June 2018 }}</ref> The remaining £4 million came in the form of grants from the [[Football Foundation]] and local government and development agencies.<ref name="BBC 230707"/> More good news followed with the announcement by Colchester Councillors that work could begin on the stadium prior to the opening of a new access route linked to the A12 in January 2007.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/1105542.Colchester__Stadium_restriction_is_lifted/ | title=Stadium restriction is lifted |newspaper=Colchester Gazette |location=Colchester |last= |first= |date=5 January 2007 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref> Scottish firm [[Barr Construction]] were then announced as contractors for the new stadium just two weeks later.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/1145648.Colchester__Scottish_firm_wins_contract_for_community_stadium/ | title=Scottish firm wins contract for community stadium |newspaper=Colchester Gazette |location=Colchester |last= |first= |date=25 January 2007 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref>
===Construction and opening=== [[File:Colchester community stadium construction.jpg|thumb|left|Colchester Community Stadium under construction in April 2008]] Work began on the Cuckoo Farm site in June 2007, with temporary buildings and construction vehicles arriving on site from 4 June.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/1455923.Colchester__Stadium_work_starts/ | title=Stadium work starts |newspaper=Colchester Gazette |location=Colchester |last= |first= |date=7 June 2007 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref> Building work finally began in July 2007 with the intention of completion in time for the beginning of the [[2008–09 Colchester United F.C. season|2008–09 season]].<ref name="BBC 230707"/> With building work nearing completion, Colchester announced the name for the stadium would officially be the ''Colchester Community Stadium'', but owing to a deal with building firm Weston Homes, the ground would be known as the ''Weston Homes Community Stadium''. The ten-year sponsorship deal would be worth up to £2 million and would also include shirt sponsorship for the 2008–09 season.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/colchester_united/7449295.stm | title=Colchester reveal ground sponsors |newspaper=[[BBC Sport]] |location=London |last= |first= |date=12 June 2008 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref>
The first fixture to be played at the Community Stadium was a friendly between Colchester United and Spanish club [[Athletic Bilbao]], on 4 August 2008.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/teams/c/colchester_united/7500076.stm | title=Bilbao to visit Community Stadium |newspaper=[[BBC Sport]] |location=London |last= |first= |date=10 July 2008 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref> The first goal to be scored at the stadium was from [[Aritz Aduriz]] for Bilbao after 15 minutes, but Colchester [[forward (association football)|forward]] [[Scott Vernon]] equalised from the [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty spot]] on 32 minutes, registering the first Colchester goal at the Community Stadium. The game finished 2–1 to the Spanish club.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/sport/colchesterunited/3570427.U_s_beaten_by_late_penalty/ | title=U's beaten by late penalty |newspaper=Colchester Gazette |location=Colchester |last=Waldron |first=Jonathan |date=4 August 2008 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://en.liveresult.ru/football/matches/match32953_Colchester-Athletic_Bilbao_live/ | title=Colchester – Athletic Bilbao | work=liveresult.ru |date= |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref>
The first competitive fixture at the Community Stadium came on 16 August 2008 when Colchester hosted [[Huddersfield Town F.C.|Huddersfield Town]] in front of a crowd of 5,340.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7551187.stm | title=Colchester 0–0 Huddersfield | work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=16 August 2008 |accessdate=27 January 2014 }}</ref> [[Mark Yeates]] scored the first competitive goal at the stadium in a 2–2 draw with [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] on 30 August 2008<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7578337.stm | title=Colchester 2–2 Oldham | work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=30 August 2008 |accessdate=27 January 2014 }}</ref> but the U's had to wait until 25 October 2008 to register their first win at the ground. They won emphatically against [[Carlisle United F.C.|Carlisle United]], scoring five with goals from [[David Perkins (footballer)|David Perkins]], [[Dean Hammond]], [[Akanni-Sunday Wasiu]] and two netted by Mark Yeates.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/7674504.stm | title=Colchester 5–0 Carlisle | work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=25 October 2008 |accessdate=27 January 2014 }}</ref>
==Structure and facilities== [[File:Weston Homes Community Stadium Colchester - geograph.org.uk - 1626318.jpg|thumb|right|Colchester Community Stadium southeast corner in December 2009]] With a [[seating capacity]] of 10,105,<ref name="FL"/> the stadium is divided into four stands, with each stand incorporating disabled access. The West Stand is the largest stand which contains both conventional seating for supporters, but also houses 24 executive boxes and corporate areas. These areas can hold up to 400 diners in the Layer and Centennial suites. Directors boxes are situated either side of the tunnel entrance with dugouts and press areas also separated by the tunnel. A television gantry is placed on the roof of the stand above the executive boxes. Housed in the West Stand are the club's administration offices, club shop, ticket office and reception.
The North Stand is designated for away supporters for [[The Football League|Football League]] fixtures.
The East Stand is home to the family enclosure which offer family-friendly pricing for supporters choosing to be situated there.
The South stand houses Colchester United's vocal supporters, where up to 2,000 fans can sit. This stand also uses pricing incentives to encourage supporters to create a loud and vocal atmosphere.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cu-fc.com/club/stadiuminfo/ | title=Weston Homes Community Stadium | work=[[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United FC]] | date=10 July 2012 | accessdate=26 January 2014 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140128163817/http://www.cu-fc.com/club/stadiuminfo/ | archivedate=28 January 2014 | df=dmy-all }}</ref>
==Other uses== [[File:Elton John in Norway.jpg|thumb|right|[[Elton John]] became the first artist to play an open-air gig at the Community Stadium in June 2014.]] Utilising the space of the Layer and Centennial suites, the stadium also plays host to a range of other activities, including conferences, banqueting, weddings, parties and events. The stadium features a 600 space car park and hosts boxing dinners, darts opens, comedy nights, tribute band nights, fashion shows, award ceremonies and proms.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.colchesterstadiumexperience.com/ | title=Weston Homes Community Stadium, Colchester | work=colchesterstadiumexperience.com |date= |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref>
The stadium was used as an open-air music venue for the first time on 29 June 2014 when [[Elton John|Sir Elton John]] played his first ever Colchester concert.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.colchesterstadiumexperience.com/events/sir-elton-john-conert.aspx | title=Sir Elton John comes to The Weston Homes Community Stadium | work=colchesterstadiumexperience.com |date= |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.eadt.co.uk/news/poll_music_legend_elton_john_announces_live_date_at_weston_homes_community_stadium_in_colchester_1_2968442 | title=Music legend Elton John announces live date at Weston Homes Community Stadium in Colchester |newspaper=East Anglian Daily Times |location=East Anglia |last= |first= |date=6 November 2013 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref> The event had a capacity of around 16,500.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cu-fc.com/news/article/290614-elton-rocks-colchester-1705784.aspx?events/sir-elton-john-conert.aspx | title=Elton Rocks Colchester | work=Colchester United FC |date=29 June 2014 |accessdate=30 June 2014 }}</ref> [[Lionel Richie]] performed in an open air setting in June 2016 as part of his ''All The Hits'' tour.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Brading |first1=Wendy |date=1 December 2015 |title=International star Lionel Richie to perform at the Weston Homes Stadium in Colchester |url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/14114650.Singer_Lionel_Richie_to_perform_in_Colchester/?ref=mr&lp=3 |newspaper=Daily Gazette |location=Colchester |accessdate=2 December 2015 }}</ref> An audience of 17,000 watched local singer [[Olly Murs]] perform on 10 June 2017 in the stadiums third open-air concert.<ref>{{cite news |date=11 June 2017 |title=Singer Olly Murs wowed the crowd at sun drenched concert in Colchester |url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/news/15340803.Olly_Murs_returned_home_and_wowed_the_crowd_in_front_of_17_000_delighted_fans/#comments-anchor |newspaper=Daily Gazette |location=Colchester |accessdate=11 June 2017 }}</ref>
===International football matches=== The Community Stadium has hosted four international football matches; three featuring the [[England national under-21 football team|England under-21s]] and one [[England national under-19 football team|England under-19]] game. The first international game at the stadium saw England under-19s defeat their [[Germany national under-19 football team|German]] counterparts 1–0 in front of a crowd of 9,692 on 18 November 2008 courtesy of a [[Henri Lansbury]] goal.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/sport/colchesterunited/3859878.Robbie_hoping_for_another_England_visit/ | title=Robbie hoping for another England visit |newspaper=Colchester Gazette |location=Colchester |last=Waldron |first=Jonathan |date=19 November 2008 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/MatchRsl/MatchRslTmU19pg1.html |title=England Matches – Under-19's 1991–2010 |last= |first= |date= |publisher=England Football Online |accessdate=22 October 2014 }}</ref> The next international fixture saw England under-21s qualify for the [[2011 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship]] as they beat [[Lithuania national under-21 football team|Lithuania]] 3–0 with two goals from [[Danny Welbeck]] and one from [[Marc Albrighton]]. A crowd of 7,240 watched the game on 7 September 2010.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/8974671.stm | title=England U21 3–0 Lithuania U21 | work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=7 September 2010 |accessdate=26 January 2014 }}</ref> The England under-21s returned to Colchester for a [[2013 UEFA European Under-21 Football Championship qualification|2013 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualifier]] on 11 November 2011. The Young Lions cruised to a 5–0 victory against [[Iceland national under-21 football team|Iceland]] on the night, with goals from [[Marvin Sordell]], [[Martin Kelly]], [[Craig Dawson]] and two scored by [[Gary Gardner]].<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/15687214 | title=England U21 5–0 Iceland U21 | work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=11 November 2011 |accessdate=27 January 2014 }}</ref> The attendance for the game was 10,051.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.englandfootballonline.com/MatchRsl/MatchRslTmU21pg4.html |title=England Matches – Under-21's 2010–20 |last= |first= |date= |publisher=England Football Online |accessdate=22 October 2014 }}</ref> England won their fourth match after almost five years away from the Community Stadium on 6 September 2016. Full England international [[Marcus Rashford]] made his England under-21 debut in the game, scoring a [[hat-trick]] as England scored six times against [[Norway national under-21 football team|Norway]]. The other scorers were [[Nathaniel Chalobah]], [[Ruben Loftus-Cheek]] and [[Lewis Baker (footballer)|Lewis Baker]]. England's opposition scored for the first time at the Community Stadium when [[Ghayas Zahid]] scored Norway's consolation with the score at 4–1.<ref>{{cite news |last=Marston |first=Carl |date=6 September 2016 |title=Marcus Rashford scores a hat-trick at the home of Colchester United |url=http://www.greenun24.co.uk/colchester-united/marcus_rashford_scores_a_hat_trick_at_the_home_of_colchester_united_1_4686897? |newspaper=Green'Un |location=Ipswich |accessdate=7 September 2016 }}</ref>
The stadium hosted the [[England women's national football team|England women's team]] for the first time in a competitive fixture for their [[2019 FIFA Women's World Cup qualification]] game against [[Kazakhstan women's national football team|Kazakhstan]] on 28 November 2017. The Lionesses won 5–0 on the night with goals from [[Melissa Lawley]], [[Fran Kirby]], two from [[Nikita Parris]], and [[Izzy Christiansen]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42132008 |title=England Women 5–0 Kazakhstan Women |last=Law |first=James |date=28 November 2017 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=30 November 2017 }}</ref> The [[England women's national football team|England women's team]] had previously played at the stadium in a 2-0 loss against Iceland women's team on 16th July 2009<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/women/8155927.stm|title=England 0-2 Iceland|date=2009-07-17|access-date=2018-07-14|language=en-GB}}</ref>

/>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/42132008 Report]<br />[http://www.gazette-news.co.uk/sport/15689431.Bumper_Colchester_crowd_cheer_England_Women_to_easy_victory_in_World_Cup_qualifier/ Report] |team2 = {{flagicon|KAZ}} [[Kazakhstan women's national football team|Kazakhstan Women]] |goals1 = [[Melissa Lawley|Lawley]] {{goal|15}}<br />[[Fran Kirby|Kirby]] {{goal|64|pen.}}<br />[[Nikita Parris|Parris]] {{goal|68||75}}<br />[[Izzy Christiansen|Christiansen]] {{goal|76}} |goals2 = |location = [[Colchester]] |stadium = Colchester Community Stadium |attendance = 9,644 |referee = Lois Otte ([[Royal Belgian Football Association|Belgium]]) |stack = }}
==Records== The highest attendance at the Community Stadium is 10,064 when Colchester United hosted [[Norwich City F.C.|Norwich City]] on 16 January 2010. Canaries manager [[Paul Lambert]] had been in charge at Colchester when the U's defeated Norwich 7–1 on the opening day of the season at [[Carrow Road]]. Shortly after this event, Lambert defected to Norwich, and with bad feelings between the clubs spelt a fiery affair for the return fixture. Substitute [[Ian Henderson (footballer)|Ian Henderson]] was sent off on his home debut for Colchester as they were handed a heavy 5–0 defeat by Norwich.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/football/eng_div_2/8444108.stm | title=Colchester 0–5 Norwich | work=[[BBC Sport]] |date=15 January 2010 |accessdate=27 January 2014 }}</ref>
==Transport== [[File:A12, New Junction - geograph.org.uk - 2134075.jpg|thumb|right|Colchester Community Stadium and junction 28 on the [[A12 road (England)|A12 road]] under construction in August 2010]] The Colchester Community Stadium is situated close to junction 28 on the A12. The stadium can hold just under 700 cars in the main car park, and there are two drop off zones situated around the stadium.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.cu-fc.com/news/article/travel-by-car-224051.aspx | title=Getting To The Stadium By Car | work=[[Colchester United F.C.|Colchester United FC]] |date=9 October 2013 |accessdate=27 January 2014 }}</ref> A [[park and ride]] situated on the opposite side of the A12 opened in 2015, in which supporters are able to park on match days.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.essexhighways.org/Transport-and-Roads/Getting-Around/Bus/Park-and-Ride/Colchester-Park-and-Ride.aspx |title=Colchester Park and Ride |last= |first= |date= |publisher=Essex Highways |accessdate=24 November 2015 }}</ref>
==Awards== In May 2009, the Colchester Community Stadium was named overall winner in the [[Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors]] East of England Awards. The RICS said the stadium project had been a "fantastic new facility for Colchester United Football Club" but that it also gave "benefits to the wider community". The stadium also won the community benefit award.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/england/8054280.stm | title=New £14m stadium wins top award |newspaper=[[BBC News]] |location=London |last= |first= |date=17 May 2009 |accessdate=27 January 2014 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|2}}
==External links== * [http://www.colchesterstadiumexperience.com/ Official website]
