revision.text:
{{Infobox film |name=Colors of the Blind |image=colorsoftheblind.jpg |caption=official film poster |film name={{Infobox name module|chinese={{linktext|黑|眼睛}}|pinyin=Hēi Yǎnjīng|translation=Black Eyes}} |director=Chen Guoxing |writer=[[Wan Fang]] |producer={{Unbulleted list|Chen Guoxing|Jiang Huaiyan|Lu Yao|Han Hongfei}} |starring={{Unbulleted list|[[Tao Hong (actress, born 1972)|Tao Hong]]|Jiang Kai|He Bing}} |music=[[Zhao Jiping]] |cinematography={{Unbulleted list|Liang Ming|Wen Deguang}} |runtime=89 minutes |country=China |language=Mandarin |studio={{Unbulleted list|Tianjin Film Studio|Beijing Film Studio}} |released=1997 }} '''''Colors of the Blind''''' is a 1997 Chinese drama film directed and co-produced by Chen Guoxing, starring [[Tao Hong (actress, born 1972)|Tao Hong]] as a blind girl training to become a competitive [[sprint (running)|sprinter]]. The script was written by [[Wan Fang]].
At the time of filming, Tao Hong was a third-year student at the [[Central Academy of Drama]], acting in her second film role. She was chosen for the lead role mainly because of her athletic background, as she had been a professional [[synchronised swimming|synchronised swimmer]] for 10 years. To prepare for the film, Tao also spent time among disabled people.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tao Hong in Full Bloom|url=http://cctv.cntv.cn/lm/storyboard/20110426/109447.shtml|website=[[China Central Television]]|date=2011-04-26|last=Zheng Limin}}</ref> Her performance in this film won her some of the highest honors in China, as well as awards in Syria and France.
A number of real-life Chinese Paralympians appeared in small roles, such as [[Wang Juan (athlete)|Wang Juan]].
==Plot== If not for attending a school for the blind, Ding Lihua ([[Tao Hong (actress, born 1972)|Tao Hong]]) is just like any other young, silly girl. The chirping of canary or the touch of snow will bring out a big smile from her. She hates it, however, when people mention her disability especially out of sympathy, and when her brother (Zhang Wankun) and sister-in-law ([[Ding Jiali]]) try to matchmake her with an older blind musician, she takes offense. One day, running after her brother's bicycle on the rural road, Ding is spotted by Li Mingsheng (Jiang Kai), a dedicated Paralympic coach who trains a group of disabled track athletes. Ding joins his team, though she quits not long after due to a disagreement with his harsh training method.
Realizing that running under Li is her best bet to become something, she returns to the team, and Li quickly sees the potential and the competitive spirit in her. They train hard and Ding wins the 100-metre dash in her first official competition. Ding develops feelings for Li, even though she is also aware that he is fully healthy with a beautiful girlfriend Yu Su (Cui Qianmei). Around this time, Liu Yi (He Bing), a rich ex-classmate, visits her frequently with the intention of dating her. Though not interested in him, Ding borrows money from Liu to try to help Li mend his failing relationship with Yu, but Li and Yu still break up for good. Li thanks Ding, but rejects her love. Ding becomes sullen, and leaves the team again after an argument with Li. Li gains more understanding of blind people that they wish to be treated normally more than they need sympathy, while Ding also realizes that she needs to accept the reality that she is blind and different from others.
After winning a gold medal at a [[Paralympic Games]] for China, Ding returns home and becomes a masseuse. It is through sports that she becomes a confident human being, and she begins to see colors in her dreams.
==Awards and nominations== *'''1997 10th [[Damascus International Film Festival]]''' **'''Won''' — Best Actress ([[Tao Hong (actress, born 1972)|Tao Hong]]) *'''1998 4th [[Huabiao Awards]]''' **'''Won''' — Top-10 Films **'''Won''' — [[Huabiao Award for Outstanding Actress|Outstanding Actress]] ([[Tao Hong (actress, born 1972)|Tao Hong]]) *'''1998 18th [[Golden Rooster Awards]]''' **'''Won''' — [[Golden Rooster Award for Best Actress|Best Actress]] ([[Tao Hong (actress, born 1972)|Tao Hong]]) *'''2000 2nd [[Deauville Asian Film Festival]]''' **'''Won''' — Best Actress ([[Tao Hong (actress, born 1972)|Tao Hong]])
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *{{IMDb title|0261730}}

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2014}}
{{Citation style|date=September 2009}}
'''Daniel John Szymborski''' (born June 19, 1978, in [[Baltimore]], Maryland) is an American writer of [[sabermetrics]] primarily known for his work with baseball projections and minor league translations.
Szymborski is a member of [[Society for American Baseball Research]] (SABR) and is best known for contributions to BaseballPrimer.com, now known as [[Baseball Think Factory]], after the site was featured by ''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'' in 2002 and 2003's ''[[Moneyball]]'' by [[Michael Lewis (author)|Michael Lewis]]. After developing his projection system, ZiPS (S'''Z'''ymborsk'''i''' '''P'''rojection '''S'''ystem) prior to the 2003 season, Szymborski became commonly quoted in print and web media as an expert in the field of baseball statistics.
==References==
*''[[Time (magazine)|TIME]]'', "50 Best Websites," [http://www.time.com/time/2002/tech/best/complete.html, ''Time'', December 18, 2002] *Dan Szymborski, "Bonds Unlikely to Hit 35 Home Runs Next Year," [http://www.insidebayarea.com/sports/ci_3055339, ''[[Oakland Tribune]]'', September 23, 2005] *Dan Szymborski, "Pujols faces long and winding road to 714," [http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4176/is_20060526/ai_n16437777/?tag=content;col1, ''Oakland Tribune'', May 26, 2006] *David Gassko, "Projection Roundtable," [http://www.hardballtimes.com/main/article/projection-roundtable-part-1-of-5/], ''[[The Hardball Times]]'', July 31, 2006 *[[Nate Silver]], "2007 Hitter Projection Roundup," [http://www.baseballprospectus.com/unfiltered/?p=564, [[Baseball Prospectus]], October 4, 2007] *Dan Rosenheck, "Toledo, Here He Comes?" [https://www.nytimes.com/2007/11/25/sports/baseball/25score.html, ''[[The New York Times]]'', November 25, 2007] *David Appelman, "Inside the 2007 player projection systems," [http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/2007/baseball/mlb/02/19/fangraphs.projections/index.html, [[CNN Sports Illustrated|CNN/SI]], September 19, 2007] *Geoff Baker, "Projecting Bedard's Mariners," [http://blog.seattletimes.nwsource.com/mariners/2008/02/05/projecting_bedards_mariners.html, ''[[The Seattle Times]]'', February 5, 2008]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *''[[St. Petersburg Times]]'', "What they're saying about the Rays," [http://www.tampabay.com/sports/baseball/ml/article435829.ece, March 30, 2008] *Vlae Kershner, "Computer unkind to Crosby," [http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/blogs/athletics/detail?blogid=21&entry_id=31869], [[San Francisco Chronicle|San Francisco Gate]], October 24, 2008 *[[Jerry Crasnick]], "Young core gives Reds immediate hope," [http://sports.espn.go.com/mlb/preview09/columns/story?columnist=crasnick_jerry&id=4033671, [[ESPN.com]], April 2, 2009]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Szymborski, Dan}} [[Category:1978 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Writers from Baltimore]] [[Category:Baseball statisticians]] [[Category:Baseball culture]]

{{Use British English|date=February 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}} In [[cricket]], a '''duck''' is a batsman's [[Dismissal (cricket)|dismissal]] for a score of zero.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/bitesize/articles/z683qp3 |title=The origins of cricket jargon |work=BBC Bitesize |accessdate=17 November 2018}}</ref>
==Origin of the term== The term is a shortening of the term "duck's egg", the latter being used long before Test cricket began. When referring to the Prince of Wales' (the future [[Edward VII]]) score of nought on 17 July 1866, a contemporary newspaper wrote that the Prince "retired to the royal pavilion on a 'duck's egg' ".<ref name="Correspondent"/> The name is believed to come from the shape of the number "0" being similar to that of a [[duck]]'s [[Egg (biology)|egg]], as in the case of the [[American English|American]] slang term "goose-egg" popular in baseball and the tennis term "love," derived - according to one theory - from French ''l'oeuf'' ("the egg"). The Concise Oxford Dictionary still cites "duck's egg" as an alternative version of the term.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.askoxford.com/concise_oed/duck_3?view=uk | title=duck | accessdate=2009-03-29 | publisher=[[AskOxford.com]]}}</ref>
==Significant ducks== The first duck in a [[Test cricket|Test match]] was made in the very first Test, between [[Australia cricket team|Australia]] and [[England cricket team|England]] at [[Melbourne Cricket Ground|Melbourne]] in March 1877, when [[Ned Gregory]] was [[Caught (cricket)|caught]] by [[Andrew Greenwood]] off the bowling of [[James Lillywhite]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Scorecards/2/2077.html | title=Australia v England in 1876/77 | accessdate=2007-05-22 | publisher=CricketArchive}}</ref> As of 2017, the record for the most ducks in Test cricket is held by [[West Indies cricket team|West Indies]] player [[Courtney Walsh]], who was out for nought on 43 occasions,<ref> {{cite web | url=http://uk.cricinfo.com/db/STATS/TESTS/BATTING/DUCKS_IN_TESTS.html | title=Tests – Most Ducks in Career | accessdate=2017-07-07 | publisher=[[Cricinfo]]}}</ref> while the overall [[first-class cricket|first-class]] record is 156, set by [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire]] and England player [[Reg Perks]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Records/Firstclass/Overall/Most_Ducks.html | title=Most Ducks in First-Class Cricket | accessdate=2007-05-22 | publisher=CricketArchive}}</ref>
One particularly high-profile example of a duck came in 1948, when [[Don Bradman]] was playing his final Test match for Australia, against England at [[The Oval]]. In Australia's first innings, Bradman was [[bowled]] for a duck by [[Eric Hollies]], causing his Test average to fall from 101.39 to 99.94; had he scored just four runs, his average would have been 100. As things turned out, Australia won the match [[the result in cricket|by an innings]], and so Bradman did not get to bat a second time (had he batted, he would have needed at least 104 runs if dismissed or at least four runs if [[not out]] to get his average back to 100).<ref> {{cite web | url=http://cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Players/0/492/492.html | title=Don Bradman | accessdate=2007-05-22 | publisher=CricketArchive}}</ref>
In the first Test of Australia's tour of India in 1986, with the cumulative scores tied, Indian tailender [[Maninder Singh (cricketer)|Maninder Singh]] was trapped [[Leg Before Wicket|LBW]] by [[Greg Matthews]] for a four ball duck, ensuring just the second [[tied Test]] in Test Cricket history.
Indian [[all-rounder]] [[Ajit Agarkar]] earned the unfortunate nickname "[[Bombay Duck]]" after being dismissed for ducks five consecutive times in test matches against [[Australia cricket team|Australia]].<ref>{{cite news|title=No more Bombay Duck|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/sport/126266/No-more-Bombay-Duck.html|publisher=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|date=4 August 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Ask Bearders |last=Frindall |first=Bill |authorlink=Bill Frindall |coauthors= |year=2009 |publisher=[[BBC Books]]|location= |isbn=978-1-84607-880-4 |page=|pages=80–81 |url= }}<!--|accessdate=12 June 2011--></ref>
In a 1913 match against [[Glastonbury Cricket Club|Glastonbury]], Huish and Langport's batsmen all scored ducks for a total of zero runs.<ref>{{Cite news|title = Ducks all round: the cricket team that was all out for nought|url = https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2011/sep/07/cricket-team-all-out-nought|newspaper = The Guardian|date = 2011-09-07|access-date = 2016-02-13|issn = 0261-3077|language = en-GB|first = Steven|last = Morris}}</ref> A similar occurrence in [[Indoor cricket (UK variant)|indoor cricket]] happened in 2016, when Bapchild Cricket Club were dismissed for zero against Christ Church University.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Cricket team bowled out for zero in Kent indoor game|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/cricket/35550946|website = BBC Sport|access-date = 2016-02-13|date = 2016-02-11}}</ref>
On January 30, 2017 [[Batting order (cricket)|tailender]] [[Josh Hazlewood]] (Aus) became the first player to be dismissed for a ''diamond duck'' in a partnership of more than fifty runs. He was run out at the non-striker's end without facing a delivery.
==Variations== There are several variations used to describe specific types of duck. The usage or prevalence of many of these terms vary regionally, with one term having different meanings in different parts of the world. Even within commentary from ESPN Cricinfo or individual cricket board websites, there is no uniform application of some of these terms. *Players who are dismissed by the first ball they face are said to have been dismissed for a '''golden duck'''. This term is applied uniformly throughout the cricket world.<ref name="Cricinfo"> {{cite web | url=http://www.cricinfo.com/link_to_database/ABOUT_CRICKET/EXPLANATION/EXPLANATION_OF_CRICKET.html | title=Cricket explained | accessdate=2007-05-22 | publisher=[[Cricinfo]]}}</ref> *A batsman who is dismissed without facing a ball (most usually run out from the non-striker's end, but alternatively stumped or run out off a wide delivery) is said to be out for a diamond duck,<ref name="VCA">Victorian Cricket Association Umpires and Scorers Association Association Newsletter, Vol. 15 No. 5, 2008–2009 season, p11</ref><ref name="cricket.com.au Twenty20 Match Commentary">{{cite web|url=http://ls.cricket.com.au/HomeFullScorecardMatchMilestones81_2360_15.html |title=cricket.com.au Twenty20 Match Commentary |accessdate=2009-01-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090120152648/http://ls.cricket.com.au/HomeFullScorecardMatchMilestones81_2360_15.html |archivedate=20 January 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/cricket/article-1335307/Martin-Samuel-The-joys-Simon-Katichs-diamond-duck.html | title=A diamond duck? Simon Katich's howler was as rare as a sighting of Quackula... | date=4 December 2010 | location=London | work=Daily Mail | first=Martin | last=Samuel}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.smh.com.au/sport/cricket/diamond-duck-places-katich-in-select-ashes-club-20101203-18jt4.html | title=Diamond duck places Katich in select Ashes club | date=4 December 2010 | work=The Sydney Morning Herald}}</ref> but in some regions that term has an alternative definition. *An opening batsman who is dismissed on the first ball of a team's innings is said to be out for a diamond duck,<ref name="VCA"/><ref>[http://www.cricinfo.com/magazine/content/current/story/149530.html ''All Today's Yesterdays – South Africa's first home Test for 22 years'']</ref> platinum duck<ref>Sailesh S. Radha, ''Five Days in White Flannels: A Trivia Book on Test Cricket'', p46, (AuthorHouse) {{ISBN|1-4389-2469-0}}</ref> or royal duck,<ref name="Correspondent">LONDON from THE DAILY TIMES CORRESPONDENT, 25 July 1866 can be viewed at [http://paperspast.natlib.govt.nz/cgi-bin/paperspast?a=d&d=OW18660922.2.6&l=mi&e=-------10--1----0-all Paper's past]</ref> depending upon the regional usage.
==Pair== To be dismissed for nought in both [[innings]] of the same two-innings match is to be dismissed for a pair,<ref> {{cite web|url=http://www.middlesexccc.com/report-detail.asp?ReportID=163 |title=Middlesex facing innings defeat at Lord's |date=22 June 2006 |accessdate=2013-09-08 |publisher=[[Middlesex County Cricket Club]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205073133/http://www.middlesexccc.com/report-detail.asp?ReportID=163 |archivedate=5 February 2012 }}</ref> because the two noughts together are thought to resemble a pair of [[spectacles]]; the longer form is occasionally used.<ref> {{cite news | first=Henry | last=Blofeld | authorlink=Henry Blofeld | title=CRICKET: Smith has the class and character to revive England | url=https://www.questia.com/library/1P2-1780286/cricket-smith-has-the-class-and-character-to-revive | archive-url=https://archive.is/20130908215938/http://www.questia.com/library/1P2-1780286/cricket-smith-has-the-class-and-character-to-revive | dead-url=yes | archive-date=8 September 2013 | work=[[The Independent]] | publisher=[[FindArticles]] | date=18 August 2003 | accessdate=2013-09-08 | quote=Conversely, Graham Gooch made a pair of spectacles in his first Test, against Australia.}}</ref> To be dismissed first ball in ''both'' innings (''i.e.'', two golden ducks) is to suffer the indignity of making a ''[[king pair]]''.<ref name="Cricinfo" />
'''Most duck by a batsmen in his career''' <big><sup>(top ten)</sup></big> {| class="wikitable" !Player !Span !Mat !Inns !NO !Runs !HS !Ave !BF !SR !100 !50 !'''0''' !4s !6s |- |M Muralitharan (Asia/ICC/SL) |1992-2011 |495 |328 |119 |1936 |67 |9.26 |2668 |72.56 |0 |1 |'''59''' |196 |41 |- |CA Walsh (WI) |1984-2001 |337 |264 |94 |1257 |30* |7.39 |2539 |49.50 |0 |0 |'''54''' |100+ |28+ |- |ST Jayasuriya (Asia/SL) |1989-2011 |586 |651 |35 |21032 |340 |34.14 |25849+ |81.13* |42 |103 |'''53''' |2486 |352 |- |GD McGrath (AUS/ICC) |1993-2007 |376 |207 |89 |761 |61 |6.44 |1818 |41.85 |0 |1 |'''49''' |58 |1 |- |DPMD Jayawardene (Asia/SL) |1997-2015 |652 |725 |62 |25957 |374 |39.15 |40100 |64.73 |54 |136 |'''47''' |2679 |170 |- |DL Vettori (ICC/NZ) |1997-2015 |442 |383 |86 |6989 |140 |23.53 |10692 |65.36 |6 |27 |'''46''' |745 |34 |- |Wasim Akram (PAK) |1984-2003 |460 |427 |74 |6615 |257* |18.73 |9597+ |68.39* |3 |13 |'''45''' |571+ |178+ |- |Z Khan (Asia/INDIA) |2000-2014 |309 |232 |61 |2036 |75 |11.90 |3469 |58.69 |0 |3 |'''44''' |210 |53 |- |SK Warne (AUS/ICC) |1992-2007 |339 |306 |46 |4172 |99 |16.04 |6883 |60.61 |0 |13 |'''44''' |413 |50 |} ==See also== *[[Hat trick]], the dismissal of three batsmen from three consecutive balls *[[Names for the number 0 in English]] *[[Pairs in test and first-class cricket]] *[[Golden sombrero]], an equally inglorious batting feat in baseball *[[Daddles]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Cricket terminology]]

[[File:20140321 Dancing Stars Erik Schinegger 4198.jpg|thumb|upright|Erik Schinegger 2014]] '''Erik Schinegger''' (born 19 June 1948) is an [[Austria]]n [[intersexuality|intersex]] and [[transgenderism|transgender]] skier. He was the [[world champion]] women's downhill skier in 1966, at which time he was recognized as female and known as '''Erika Schinegger'''.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wXwQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=fJMDAAAAIBAJ&pg=6182,3089370&dq=erik-schinegger&hl=en|title=Champion Girl Skier In Sex Change .|date=17 June 1968|publisher=''[[The Age]]''|accessdate=3 March 2010}}</ref>
==Early life== Schinegger was born in [[Agsdorf]], [[Carinthia (state)|Carinthia]], and raised as a girl.
==Skiing and transitioning== Schinegger had won the gold medal in the women's downhill skiing competition at the [[FIS Alpine World Ski Championships 1966|1966 World Ski Championship]] in [[Portillo, Chile]] <ref name=natpres>{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=xzdWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=r-gDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7223%2C2393624 |newspaper=Spokesman-Review |agency=Associated Press |title=Austrian's win help to national prestige |date=August 9, 1966 |page=13 }}</ref>, but would give up the 1966 medal 20 years after completing his [[Sex reassignment surgery|reassignment]]. <ref name=mwhwon>{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/1988-11-19/sports/sp-422_1_gold-medal |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |agency=Associated Press |title=Man who won '66 women's downhill gives up medal |date=November 19, 1988 |accessdate=February 3, 2015}}</ref>
In 1967, as he was preparing for the [[1968 Winter Olympics]] in [[Grenoble]], a medical test by the [[International Olympic Committee]] (IOC) determined that Schinegger had XY chromosomes and internal male sex organs, and disqualified him. Schinegger ultimately decided to live as a man and [[transitioning (transgender)|transitioned]], undergoing medical treatment and changing his name to Erik. He married and became a father.<ref name="TimesUK">Rick Broadbent, [http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/sport/article2374245.ece "From Erika to Erik, a long journey of self-discovery"], ''[[The Times]]'', October 22, 2009.</ref><ref>John Fry, ''The Story of Modern Skiing'' ([[University Press of New England]], 2006), pp.131-133 ([https://books.google.com/books?id=FOhrjSuy6rsC&pg=PA132&lpg=PA132&dq=Erik+Schinegger&source=bl&ots=tEge3XfFJt&sig=kRIVOM5EGQRgmj4kWgrPGKBHN4c&hl=en&ei=wSmQS5H6CYL4MvXulPUN&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CAsQ6AEwAjgy#v=onepage&q=Erik%20Schinegger&f=false excerpt] available at [[Google Books]]).</ref>
Together with Marco Schenz, Schinegger published an autobiography in 1988 titled ''Mein Sieg über mich. Der Mann, der Weltmeisterin wurde'' ("My Victory over Myself: The Man Who Became a Female World Champion"). He was also the subject of a 2005 [[documentary film]] by [[Kurt Mayer]] called ''Erik(A)'', with music by [[Olga Neuwirth]].<ref>Jay Weissberg, [http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117930528.html?categoryid=31&cs=1&p=0 Review of ''Erik(a)''], ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'', May 16, 2006.</ref> In 1988, on a television show broadcast by the Austrian [[ORF (broadcaster)|ORF]] network, Schinegger gave his 1966 gold medal to the second-place finisher, [[Marielle Goitschel]].<ref name="AP1988">[http://articles.latimes.com/1988-11-19/sports/sp-422_1_gold-medal "Man Who Won '66 Women's Downhill Gives Up Medal"], [[Associated Press|AP]] in ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'', November 19, 1988.</ref>
==Personal life== Erik Schinegger currently lives in the place of his birth and runs a ski school for children.<ref name="TimesUK" />
==See also== *[[Gender verification in sports]]
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Infobox sport overview | boxwidth = 250 | title = Football in Africa | image = | imagesize = 240px | image_alt = | caption = | union = [[Confederation of African Football]] | country = | sport = association football | noncountry = | teamlabel1 = | nationalteam = | teamlabel2 = | repteam = | nickname = | first = | registered = | clubs = | national_list = | club_list = | intl_list = [[CAF Champions League|Champions League]]
[[CAF Confederation Cup]]
[[CAF Super Cup|Super Cup]]
[[FIFA Club World Cup]]
[[FIFA World Cup]](National Team)
[[African Cup of Nations]](National Team) | match = | league = }} [[File:World cup african countries best results and hosts.png|thumb|Best results of African men's national teams at the FIFA World Cup]] [[Association football|Football]] is the most popular sport in [[Africa]]. Indeed, football is probably the most popular sport in every African country, although rugby and cricket are also very popular in South Africa.{{cite web|url=http://exploringafrica.matrix.msu.edu/football-soccer-in-africa/ |title=Football (Soccer) in Africa | Exploring Africa |website=Exploringafrica.matrix.msu.edu |date= |accessdate=2016-07-15}} ==History== Football was first introduced to Africa in the late 19th century by Europeans.{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=127600200 |title=The History Of Soccer In Africa |publisher=NPR.org |date=2010-06-09 |accessdate=2016-03-31}} The game was first played in the continent in 1862; historian Peter Alegi said that it "spread very quickly through the mission schools, through the military forces and through the railways." Teams were being established in South Africa before 1900, Egypt and in Algeria during a similar time period. Savages FC (Pietermaritzburg, South Africa), and [[Gezira Sporting Club|Gezira SC]] are the oldest African football clubs that remain in existence. Both began play in 1882 followed by [[Alexandria Sporting Club|Alexandria SC]] (1890) and [[Club athlétique liberté d'Oran|CAL Oran]] from Algeria in 1897. By the 1930s, football was being played in Central Africa. As Africa is a highly superstitious continent many African teams depend on [[witch doctor]]s for success.{{cite web|url=https://www.graphic.com.gh/features/features/a-world-of-superstition-frustration-and-disillusionment.html|title=Ghana news: A world of superstition, frustration and disillusionment - Graphic Online|first=Enoch Darfah|last=Frimpong|publisher=|accessdate=23 September 2017}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2010/jun/26/sports/la-sp-juju-men-world-cup-20100626 |title=For African soccer, days of juju men have mostly passed |publisher=LA Times |date= |accessdate=2016-03-31}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/features/6625855/Premiership-stars-blow-fortune-on-Juju-men.html |title= Call in the pitch doctor|publisher=Sun |date=|accessdate=2016-03-31}}{{cite news|author= |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/08/08/world/kangemi-journal-for-spellbinding-soccer-the-juju-man-s-on-the-ball.html |title=Kangemi Journal; For Spellbinding Soccer, the Juju Man's on the Ball |publisher=NY Times |date= |accessdate=2016-03-31}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2006/06/060630-soccer-magic_2.html |title=World Cup Witchcraft: Africa Teams Turn to Magic for Aid|publisher=National Geographic |date= |accessdate=2016-03-31}}{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=IkovJnw2g9gC&pg=PT384&lpg=PT384&dq=football+africa+superstition&source=bl&ots=uhfm11TDgK&sig=L0opf0KZ34IM7GaWLp0-BIRxVFw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjPr66MuuvLAhXEvBQKHW5xBrY4ChDoAQgbMAA#v=onepage&q=football%20africa%20superstition&f=false |title=The Rough Guide to Cult Football |author=Andy Mitten |website=Books.google.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-04-02}}{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2002/feb/10/sport.africannationscup2002 |title=African Nations Cup overshadowed by hocus pocus | Football |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date= |accessdate=2016-04-09}} Activities that witch doctors have performed for teams include cutting players, placing potions on equipment, and sacrificing animals.{{cite book|last=Kuper|first=Simon|title=Soccer Against the Enemy: How the World's Most Popular Sport Starts and Stops Wars, Fuels Revolutions, and Keeps Dictators in Power|publisher=Nation Books|year=2006|page=123|isbn=978-1-56025-878-0}} Children are also often exploited by agents.{{cite web|last=Edwards |first=Piers |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-33602171 |title=Can Fifa end child trafficking from Africa to Asia? |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=2016-04-02}}{{cite web|last=Sinnott |first=John |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2013/03/28/sport/football/football-trafficking/ |title=Human traffic: Africa's lost boys - CNN.com |website=Edition.cnn.com |date=2013-03-28 |accessdate=2016-04-02}}{{cite news|author=Dan McDougall |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2008/jan/06/newsstory.sport4 |title=The scandal of Africa's trafficked players | Football |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date= |accessdate=2016-04-02}}{{cite news|author=Ed Hawkins |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/news-and-comment/victims-or-fraudsters-the-world-of-football-trafficking-a6783421.html |title=Victims or fraudsters? The world of football trafficking laid bare | News & Comment | Sport |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=2015-12-22 |accessdate=2016-04-02}} Other issues faced in African football include a lack of organisation by national team officials, and internal disputes between players and federation officials.{{cite book|last1=Kuper|first1=Simon|last2=Szymanski|first2=Stefan|title=Soccernomics: Why England Loses, Why Germany and Brazil Win, and Why the US, Japan, Australia, Turkey—and Even Iraq—Are Destined to Become the Kings of the World's Most Popular Sport|publisher=Nation Books|year=2009|pages=269–270|isbn=978-1-56858-425-6}} ==Changes== The [[Confederation of African Football]] (CAF) was founded in 1957, Sudan was the founder of African football by creating CAF with four member nations: [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]], [[Ethiopia national football team|Ethiopia]], [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]], and [[Sudan national football team|Sudan]].Kuper (2006), p. 130. The first [[Africa Cup of Nations]] was held the same year, with a three-team field. Egypt won the [[1957 African Cup of Nations|inaugural African Cup of Nations]], defeating Ethiopia 4–0 in the [[1957 African Cup of Nations Final|final]]. As the sport grew football associations grew across the continent. Qualification rounds were added for the 1962 event. African national teams compete in the Africa Cup of Nations and also in the [[African Nations Championship]] for local teams.{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2013/jan/17/african-cup-nations-history |title= Africa Cup of Nations: A brief history |publisher=Guardian |date=|accessdate=2016-03-31}}{{cite news |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport2/hi/football/africa/cup_of_nations/1709599.stm |title=African Cup of Nations - How it all began |date=14 December 2001 |work=BBC Sport |publisher=BBC |accessdate=14 July 2016}} The first African nation to participate in the [[FIFA World Cup]] was Egypt in 1934.{{cite news|last=Adam|first=Mohammed|title=Why African countries don't win the World Cup|work=Ottawa Citizen|date=2014-07-23|url=http://ottawacitizen.com/sports/soccer/international-soccer/why-african-countries-dont-win-the-world-cup|accessdate=2016-12-04}} That remained the only World Cup appearance by a team from the continent until 1966, when a team from CAF was originally scheduled to compete in a playoff with teams from Asia and Oceania for one tournament berth. In response, CAF nations boycotted World Cup qualifying, and FIFA granted CAF one guaranteed berth in the [[1970 FIFA World Cup|1970 tournament]]. Starting in 1970, [[African nations at the FIFA World Cup]] started to compete regularly.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-36763036 |title=How Africa boycotted the 1966 World Cup - BBC News |website=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2016-07-15}}{{cite web|last=Edwards |first=Piers |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-37120388 |title=Joao Havelange, the unlikely godfather of African football |publisher=[[BBC News]] |accessdate=2016-08-27}} [[DR Congo national football team|Zaire]] was Africa's representative at the [[1974 FIFA World Cup|1974 edition]] of the competition.{{cite web|last=Merrill |first=Austin |url=http://www.vanityfair.com/online/fairplay/2010/04/zaire-the-leopards-and-the-1974-world-cup |title=Zaire, the Leopards, and the 1974 World Cup |publisher=Vanity Fair |date= |accessdate=2016-03-31}}{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.nation.co.ke/sports/TalkUp/The-tale-of-Africa-disastrous-entry-into-the-World-Cup/-/441392/2294756/-/6c178ez/-/index.html |title=Zaire: The tale of Africa’s disastrous entry into the World Cup - Daily Nation |website=Nation.co.ke |date= |accessdate=2016-04-02}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport3/worldcup2002/hi/history/newsid_1993000/1993333.stm |title=BBC SPORT | WORLD CUP | History | 1974: Zaire's show of shame |publisher=BBC News |date=2002-05-22 |accessdate=2016-03-31}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/06/11/sports/soccer/11sot.html?_r=0|title=Africa Honors Its Soccer Past and Looks Forward|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2016-04-02}} The team lost all three of its games. In 1977, [[Pelé]] stated his belief that a team from the continent would be crowned World Cup champions by the end of the 20th century, which proved incorrect.{{cite web|last=Sweetman|first=Tom|title=Brazil 2014: Five things African teams need to win first World Cup|publisher=CNN International|date=2014-06-13|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2014/06/13/sport/football/world-cup-africa-vieira-football/|accessdate=2016-12-04}} After the 1970, 1974, and 1978 World Cups, which each had one African qualifier, there were two teams from the continent in 1982: [[Algeria national football team|Algeria]] and [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]], each of which missed out on advancing from the group stage on [[goal difference]]. The 1986 and 1990 World Cups also featured two African nations; [[Morocco national football team|Morocco]] reached the round of 16 in 1986 after finishing first in their group.Kuper (2006), pp. 119–121. [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]] advanced to the quarterfinals of the [[1990 FIFA World Cup|1990 World Cup]], becoming the first African national team to do so. [[Senegal national football team|Senegal]] and [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] matched the feat, in 2002 and 2010 respectively. By 2010 [[South Africa]] become the first African nation to host the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|World Cup]].{{cite web|author=Charles P. Korr |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/2013/12/05/nelson-mandela-death-soccer-rugby-sports-impact-appreciation/2432659/ |title=Nelson Mandela saw sport as way to connect S. Africans |publisher=Usatoday.com |date=2013-12-05 |accessdate=2015-03-31}}{{cite news|author= |url=http://www.cnn.com/2013/12/05/world/africa/nelson-mandela-sports/ |title=For Nelson Mandela, sports were major weapon against racism |publisher=CNN.com |date=2013-12-06 |accessdate=2015-03-31}} ==Women's football== {{main|Women's football in Africa}} Numerous Nigerian cities hosted women's football teams by 1960. Multiple efforts were made in the 1960s to start women's football clubs in South Africa, but they proved fleeting. The 1970s saw some growth, with new women's leagues in Nigeria and an expansion of women's football into Western African countries, including Senegal. One local club in [[Dakar]] played a match against an Italian club in 1974; five years later, an early match between African nations was played by the Dakar side and a team from Guinea.{{cite book|author=Peter Alegi|title=African Soccerscapes: How a Continent Changed the World's Game|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NrW50yHkr0EC|accessdate=3 April 2016|date=2 March 2010|publisher=Ohio University Press|isbn=978-0-89680-278-0|page=120}} Despite a lack of support from Nigerian officials, 28 clubs played women's football in the country by 1989, and [[Nigeria women's national football team|Nigeria's national team]] competed in the [[1991 FIFA Women's World Cup|1991 Women's World Cup]]. More women began playing football in the 1990s, in countries like Nigeria and South Africa. In 1998, CAF introduced an official [[Africa Women Cup of Nations|African Women's Championship]], following two unofficial versions of the tournament earlier in the 1990s; host country Nigeria won, beginning a stretch of five consecutive titles in the event. The next year, the squad reached the quarterfinals of the [[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup|1999 Women's World Cup]].Alegi, pp. 121–123. Football is played in a limited capacity by women due to a lack of funding.{{cite web|author=Anna Kessel |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2015/jun/19/ivory-coast-exit-womens-world-cup-africa-support |title=Ivory Coast exit Women’s World Cup as Africa pleads for more support | Anna Kessel | Football |publisher=Theguardian.com |date= |accessdate=2016-04-03}} The masculine nature of football has proved a deterrent to women's involvement in football in Africa.Alegi, p. 119.{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/dec/03/skilled-determined-and-broke-africas-female-football-pioneers|title=Skilled, determined and broke: Africa's female football pioneers|first=Maeve|last=Shearlaw|date=3 December 2016|publisher=|accessdate=4 December 2016|via=The Guardian}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{Football in Africa}} [[Category:Sport in Africa]] [[Category:Association football in Africa]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Stadium | stadium_name = Glenn Field | nickname = | image = | fullname = | location = Mecaslin St, Atlanta, GA 30318 | coordinates = {{coord|33.787857|-84.400481|type:landmark_region:US|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = March 3, 1987 | renovated = | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = [[Georgia Institute of Technology]] | operator = | surface = | construction_cost = | architect = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor= | project_manager = | main_contractors = | former_names = | tenants = [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets]] (1987 - present) | seating_capacity = 500 | dimensions = Left field - {{convert|190|ft|m|1}}
Center field - {{convert|220|ft|m|1}}
Right field - {{convert|190|ft|m|1}} }} '''Glenn Field''' is the former home field for the [[Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets]] fast pitch [[softball]] team located in Midtown [[Atlanta, Georgia|Atlanta]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. Glenn Field was built in 1987 and has a capacity of 500 spectators. Glenn Field is one of the two Tech sports facilities off campus being located adjacent to [[Atlantic Station]]. The field dimensions are 190 feet to left and right fields and 220 feet to center field. Tech holds a 247-153-2 record at home (0.614 winning percentage). The current field is Shirley C. Mewborn field. ==History== The first game played on Glenn Field was a 7-4 loss to [[Samford University]] on March 3, 1987. Tech hosted thirteen additional games that season posting a 4-10 record at home and a 6-27 record overall. The first winning season at home was in 1989 where Tech posted a 12-8-1 record. The greatest season in Glenn Field history was in 2002 when Tech won the ACC Tournament. Tech went 20-2 at Glenn Field in 2002. Tech played its first game against [[Clean, Old-Fashioned Hate|archrival]] [[University of Georgia]] in 1997. The game was played at [[Georgia State University]] and resulted in a Bulldog win. Tech played UGA again in 1998 at Glenn Field marking the first home field advantage in the heated series. The first home win against the Dogs came in 2000 in the second game of a March 2 doubleheader. The most played opponent at Glenn Field is [[Georgia Southern University]]. Tech holds a 20-5 record over the Eagles at Glenn Field. Glenn Field has also been host to [[Georgia State University]], [[Mercer University|Mercer]], [[Georgia College & State University|GC&SU]], [[Kennesaw State]], and [[University of West Georgia|West Georgia]]. Tech holds a commanding 41-13 record over these instate schools while playing at Glenn Field. In June 2007, Georgia Tech Athletic Director [[Dan Radakovich]] announced that Glenn Field would cease to be the Yellow Jackets home field.[http://ramblinwreck.cstv.com/genrel/062807aab.html The Good Word - Issue 33] A new facility being constructed adjacent to historic [[Atlanta Public Schools#High schools 2|O'Keefe High School]] was completed February 2009, supplanting the twenty-year-old Glenn Field. The new facility will hold 1,000 spectators and make it possible for the Jackets to host postseason games with the presence of stadium lights.[http://ramblinwreck.cstv.com/sports/w-softbl/spec-rel/041708aac.html Construction Underway On Georgia Tech Softball Complex ] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://ramblinwreck.cstv.com/genrel/032102aaf.html Ramblinwreck.com - Glenn Field] * [http://ramblinwreck.cstv.com/sports/w-softbl/spec-rel/020107aac.html Ramblinwreck.com - 2007 Softball Media Guide] {{Georgia Tech Navbox}} [[Category:Georgia Tech Yellow Jackets softball]] [[Category:Sports venues in Atlanta]] [[Category:College softball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1987]]

revision.text:
'''Laurie Schwab''' (died June 1997<ref name="age-knights-lakers">{{cite news | url=http://newsstore.fairfax.com.au/apps/viewDocument.ac?page=1&docID=news970904_0108_7851 | title=Knights, Lakers honor Laurie Schwab | work=The Age | date=4 September 1997 | accessdate=28 February 2015 | author=Johnson, Philip}}</ref>) was an Australian journalist and broadcaster. Schwab was best known as a soccer writer for ''[[The Age]]'' newspaper in [[Melbourne]].<ref name="ffa1">{{Cite web|url=http://footballhalloffame.com.au/ |title=Laurie Schwab |publisher=Football Federation Australia |accessdate=30 June 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090915151145/http://www.footballhalloffame.com.au/ |archivedate=15 September 2009 |df= }}</ref>
==Early life== Schwab was the son of [[German people|German]] immigrants and grew up in [[St Albans, Victoria]].<ref name="ffa1" /><ref name="hugog1">{{Cite web|url=http://hugog.blogspot.com/2006/06/laurie-schwab-soccer-visionary.html|title=Laurie Schwab, soccer visionary |last=Uzunov |first=Sasha |date=19 June 2006|publisher=The Hugog|accessdate=30 June 2009}}</ref>
==Journalism== He joined ''The Age'' in the early 1970s where he soon became a soccer writer. He later founded and edited a specialised soccer newspaper, ''Soccer Action'', published by ''The Age'''s parent company [[Fairfax Media|Fairfax]].<ref name="ffa1" /><ref name="hugog1" /><ref name="age1">{{cite news|url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/soccer/a-victory-for-everyone/2007/02/17/1171405503679.html?page=fullpage|title=A Victory for everyone|last=Mangan|first=John|date=18 February 2007|work=The Age|accessdate=30 June 2009}}</ref> He also occasionally commentated on the game for [[ABC Radio and Regional Content|ABC Radio]].<ref name="ffa1" />
For his services to soccer he was posthumously inducted into the [[Australian Football (Soccer) Hall of Fame|Australian Football Hall of Fame]] in 1999.<ref name="ffa1" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Schwab, Laurie}} [[Category:Journalists from Melbourne]] [[Category:Australian radio personalities]] [[Category:Sports journalists]] [[Category:1997 deaths]] [[Category:Year of birth missing]]

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Linare| image = | fullname = Linare FC| nickname = Mamalente| founded = 1931| ground = [[Hlotse Stadium]],
[[Hlotse]], [[Lesotho]]| capacity = 1,000| chairman = Mr Thabiso Madiba| manager = Mr Matete| league = [[Lesotho Premier League]]| season = 2013–14| position = 3rd| }} '''Linare FC''' is a Lesotho football club based in [[Hlotse|Leribe]]. It is based in the city of [[Hlotse|Leribe]] in the [[Leribe District]]. It was established in 1931 and it has been in the Lesotho Premier Division from the early 1930s to date. Its one of the soccer power house in Lesotho with most of the players been able to play in foreign countries like South Africa. The team currently plays in [[Lesotho Premier League]].{{Cite web | last = | first = | coauthors = | title =lesotho premier | publisher =soccerway| date =2014 | url =https://int.soccerway.com/teams/lesotho/linare-fc/17210/matches/ | accessdate =2010-01-15 }} ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the 1,000 capacity [[Hlotse Stadium]]. ==Titles== * '''[[Lesotho Premier League]]: 3''' ::1973, 1979, 1980 ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/lesotho/linare-fc/17210/ Soccerway] {{Lesotho Premier League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Lesotho]] {{Lesotho-footyclub-stub}}

page.title: List of one-club men in association football

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/90.215.8.180|90.215.8.180]] identified as test/vandalism using [[WP:STiki|STiki]]
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=March 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2013}}
[[File:Rogério Ceni.jpg|thumb|The Brazilian goalkeeper [[Rogério Ceni]] played 1,238 official matches for [[São Paulo FC]]. He was also the club captain from 1999 until his retirement and is recognized by [[Guinness World Records]] as the one-club player with most appearances in football history.]]
A '''one-club man''' is a sportsperson who has played his or her entire professional career with only one club. The term is often used in the context of team sports such as football or rugby.<ref>{{citenews|title=Europe's rare breed – the one-club man|url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=2047668.html|publisher=[[UEFA|UEFA.com]]|date=11 February 2014}}</ref><ref>{{citenews|title=Monday Maul - A tribute to a dying breed: The one-club man|url=http://en.espn.co.uk/premiership-2014-15/rugby/story/263829.html|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=11 May 2015}}</ref>
In the strictest definition, one-club men are rare in football due to the effects of the large pay offers from rival clubs and [[promotion and relegation]] systems used by most professional leagues. Promotion creates the tendency for (mostly younger) players to be lent out to gain first-team experience, while relegation causes players to move for financial reasons (most often the case if the club is relegated or in debt) and for (mostly older) players to play at a lower level in order to prolong their careers.
:{{Expand list|date=August 2008}} __TOC__
==Association football== [[File:Totti 2011 crop.jpg|thumb|upright|Former [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] captain [[Francesco Totti]] appeared in 786 matches for [[A.S. Roma|Roma]] over 25 seasons.]] [[File:PaoloMaldini.jpg|thumb|upright|Former [[A.C. :''Players must have been at their club for a minimum of ten years in order to be included here. Loan spells at other teams disqualify players from being counted in the list. Only seasons with appearances in the senior first team are counted. Current players who have been at their club since 2009 will be eligible for inclusion in 2019.

===Playing and post-playing careers=== [[File:Aankomst Real Madrid op Schiphol. Santiago Bernabeu (cropped).jpg|thumb|222px|[[Santiago Bernabéu Yeste|Santiago Bernabéu]] spent his entire playing and managerial career with [[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]].]] In addition to those who spent their entire playing career with a single club, there are several examples of players remaining with a single club throughout their entire career within the professional club game — playing, coaching, management, etc. Notable examples are listed below.
{{inc-sport}}
*[[Bob Paisley]] ([[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]]): player 1939–1954; coach/physiotherapist 1954–1959; assistant manager 1959–1974; manager 1974–1983. *[[Edmund Białas]] ([[Lech Poznań]]): player 1934–1951; manager 1956–1976 with intervals *[[Michael Anhaeuser]] ([[Charleston Battery]]): player 1994–1998; coach 1999–present *[[Lajos Tichy]] ([[Budapest Honvéd FC|Budapest Honvéd]]): player 1953–1971; manager 1976–1982. *[[Şeref Bey]] ([[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]]): manager 1911–1925. *[[Hakkı Yeten]] ([[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]]): player 1931–1948; manager 1949 and 1950–1951; club president 1960–1963, 1964–1966 and 1967–1968. *[[Süleyman Seba]] ([[Beşiktaş J.K.|Beşiktaş]]): player 1946–1953; club president 1984–2000. *[[Santiago Bernabéu Yeste|Santiago Bernabéu]] ([[Real Madrid C.F.|Real Madrid]]): player 1912–1927; director/assistant manager and manager 1927–1941; club president 1943–1978. *[[Agustín Gaínza]] ([[Athletic Bilbao]]): player 1940–1959; manager 1965–1968 *[[Ali Sami Yen]] ([[Galatasaray S.K. (football)|Galatasaray]]): player 1905–1909; manager 1916–1917; club president 1905–1918 and 1925 *[[Boris Anatolyevich Gavrilov|Boris Gavrilov]] ([[FC Shinnik Yaroslavl|Shinnik Yaroslavl]]): player 1971–1989; assistant manager 1989–present. *[[Bill Nicholson (footballer)|Bill Nicholson]] ([[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]]): player 1938–1955; manager 1958–1974. *[[Ledley King]] ([[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]]): player 1999–2012; club ambassador 2012–present. *[[Lev Yashin]] ([[FC Dynamo Moscow|Dynamo Moscow]]): player 1949–1971; club administration 1971–1990. *[[Ryan Giggs]] ([[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]]): player 1990–2014; [[player-coach]] 2013–2014; player-manager 2014; assistant manager 2014–2016. *[[Cosme Damião]] ([[S.L. Benfica|Benfica]]): football player 1904–1916 (main squad 1907–1916); field hockey player; manager 1908–1926 (player-coach 1908–1916); director of the club's sports newspaper 1913–1931; stage director of the club's theatrical group (1916); president of the club's General Assembly 1931–1935. *[[Joe Bacuzzi]] ([[Fulham F.C.|Fulham]]): player 1935–1956; reserve team coach 1956–1965. *[[Fred Blankemeijer]] ([[Feyenoord|Feijenoord]]): player 1942-1952, technical director, board member, youth coach and scout. 1940-2010 *[[Gerard Meijer]] ([[Feyenoord]]): physiotherapist 1959–2009. *[[Giacinto Facchetti]] ([[Inter Milan]]): technical director, board member, worldwide ambassador, vice president, and president (2004–2006). *[[Willie Miller]] ([[Aberdeen F.C.|Aberdeen]]): player 1972–1990; coach 1990–1992; manager 1992–1995; director of football 2004–2012. *[[Antoon Verlegh]] ([[NAC Breda]]): player 1912–1931; manager, chairman, chairman of honour 1931–1960. *[[Michael Zorc]] ([[Borussia Dortmund]]): player 1981–1998; general manager of football 1998–present *[[Heinz Wewers]] ([[Rot-Weiss Essen]]): player 1949–1962; runner of stadium pub 1957–approx.1962; manager 1967 (1 month) *[[Aage Rou Jensen]] ([[Aarhus Gymnastikforening|AGF]]): player 1941–1962; manager *[[Roy Sproson]] ([[Port Vale F.C.|Port Vale]]): player 1949–1972 and manager 1974–1977. *[[Vadym Sosnykhin]] ([[FC Dynamo Kyiv|Dynamo Kyiv]]): player 1960–1973; youth-team coach 1974–1991; veterans team director 1992–2003. *[[Andriy Tsvik]] ([[FC Stal Alchevsk|Stal Alchevsk]]): player 1987–2005; reserves coach 2005–2007; assistant manager 2007–present. *[[Josu Urrutia]] ([[Athletic Bilbao]]): player 1987–2003; club president 2011–present. *[[Nat Lofthouse]] ([[Bolton Wanderers F.C.|Bolton Wanderers]]): player 1939–1960; Manager 1968–1970 and also 1971; assistant trainer 1961; chief coach 1967; chief scout; Club President 1968–2011 *[[George Bray]] ([[Burnley F.C.|Burnley]]): player 1937–1952; coach 1952–1974; kit manager 1974–1992<ref name="bray"/> *[[Michael Angerschmid]] ([[SV Ried]]): player 1992–2006; reserves coach 2007–2012; assistant manager 2008–2012; manager 2012–present. *[[Carles Puyol]] ([[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]): player 1999–2014; assistant of director of football 2014, and resign in the same year. *[[Ross Caven]] ([[Queen's Park F.C.|Queen's Park]]): player 1982–2002; director 2001–present. *[[Les Hart]] ([[Bury F.C.|Bury]]): player 1936–1953; Coach/Physio 1954–1968; Manager 1969–1971; Physio 1972–1980. *[[Giampiero Boniperti]] ([[Juventus F.C.|Juventus]]): player 1946-1961; board member 1962-1971; club president 1971-1990; CEO 1991-1994; club honorary president 2006–present *[[Hussein Saeed]] ([[Al-Talaba SC|Al-Talaba]]): player 1975–1990; manager 1992; vice-president 1985–1992. *[[John Greig]] ([[Rangers FC]]): player 1961–1978; manager 1978–1983; director 2003–2011; honorary life president 2015–present. *[[Anatoly Ilyin]] ([[FC Spartak Moscow|Spartak Moscow]]): player 1949-1962; youth coach 1962-1995.
===Special award=== In 2015, the Spanish club [[Athletic Bilbao]] (who place particular importance on player loyalty and promotion from within), introduced an annual 'One club man award' to be presented to one retired player (excluding their own) who represented those values during their career.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.athletic-club.eus/en/one-club-man-award.html|title=One Club Man Award|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=22 April 2015|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref>
Recipients, who attend a match as a guest of the club and receive the trophy on the pitch, have included: *[[Matt Le Tissier]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.athletic-club.eus/en/news/15298/le-tissier-in-san-mames.html|title=Le Tissier in San Mamés|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=29 April 2015|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref> *[[Paolo Maldini]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.athletic-club.eus/en/news/16701/paolo-maldini-at-san-mames.html|title=Paolo Maldini at San Mamés |publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=1 May 2016|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref><ref name="One Club Man Award">{{cite web|url=http://www.marca.com/en/football/international-football/2016/05/01/5726349922601de21c8b45be.html|title=Paolo Maldini receives 'One Club Man' Award from Athletic Club|publisher=Marca.com|author=Lucas Navarrete|date=1 May 2016|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref> *[[Sepp Maier]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.athletic-club.eus/en/news/17800/award-to-sepp-maier-at-san-mames.html|title=Award to Sepp Maier at San Mamés|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=14 April 2017|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref> *[[Carles Puyol]]<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.athletic-club.eus/en/news/19013/carles-puyol-in-bilbao.html|title=Carles Puyol in Bilbao|publisher=Athletic Bilbao|date=4 May 2018|accessdate=11 May 2018}}</ref>
==See also== * [[List of one-club men in rugby league]] * [[List of Major League Baseball players who spent their entire career with one franchise]] * [[List of NBA players who have spent their entire career with one franchise]] * [[List of NHL players who spent their entire career with one franchise]]

{{for|the American sporting goods retailer|Marathon Sports (retailer)}} {{Unreferenced|date=February 2009}} '''Marathon Sports''' is an [[Ecuador]]-based athletic company that distributes athletic equipment to sports teams. The brand was founded in May 1988 by [[Rodrigo Ribadeinera]].
In addition to making, importing, distributing and marketing some of the most important brands of clothing and accessories, such as Adidas, Nike, Puma, Diadora, Wilson and Joma. There are currently 88 Marathon Sports stores in Ecuador.
It currently provides uniforms to Ecuador, Bolivia and Perú. Their slogan for the [[Ecuador national football team|Ecuador national team]] is "Orgullosamente la piel de tu pais desde 1994".
==History== The company was founded in May 1988 by Rodrigo Rivadeinera. It first started as a sporting store chain for Ecuador, but in 1994, the [[Reebok]] contract with [[Ecuador national football team|Ecuador's national football team]] expired. Marathon Sports then signed a contract with the Ecuadorian squad for an unknown number of years. Their first national squad jersey design had a band of thick blue and red strips on the right shoulder reflecting the flag of Ecuador. After being close to qualify for their very first FIFA world cup in 1998, the F.E.F (Federacion Ecuatoriana de Futbol) decided to stick with the brand, releasing a design reflecting more of an Andean style. In 2002 the Ecuadorian team qualified for its very first [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]] in Korea/Japan, [[FIFA]]'s first jointly hosted World Cup. As time passed and technology advanced, the brand still releases the latest designs and technology for the squad. Their newest design is an evolution of its previous 2006 design. The company said it wanted to maintain its vertical lines because of its latest achievements with the design, Ecuador's national football team having qualified for its second time and reaching the knockout stages of the 2006 World Cup.
Today, Marathon Sports is an international brand having sponsored some of teams how Barcelona S.C., Independiente del Valle in Ecuador, Deportivo Municipal in Perú and Rampla Juniors in Uruguay.
Marathon Sports also has stores outside Ecuador, is the case of stores in Lima (Peru) and runs a virtual store that offers personalized soccer jerseys of Ecuadorian teams and also offers a store of printed T-shirts for children and adolescents, Teleshop de Marathon Sports.
==Teams sponsored by Marathon==
===Football (Soccer)===
====National==== *{{flagicon|Bolivia}} [[Bolivia national football team|Bolivia]] *{{flagicon|Ecuador}} [[Ecuador national football team|Ecuador]] *{{flagicon|Peru}} [[Peru national football team|Peru]]
====Club====
=====Americas===== *{{flagicon|Ecuador}} [[Barcelona S.C.]] *{{flagicon|Ecuador}} [[C.S.D. Independiente del Valle]] *{{flagicon|Perú}} [[Deportivo Municipal]] *{{flagicon|Perú}} [[Club Universitario de Deportes]] *{{flagicon|Uruguay}} [[Rampla Juniors]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2017}} [[Image:Mascot Pachi greets US Ambassador Bruce Heyman at the 2015 Pan American Games (18959014963).jpg|thumb|Pachi greets US Ambassador [[Bruce Heyman]] at the [[2015 Pan American Games]]]]
'''Pachi''' is the name of the [[mascot]] of the [[2015 Pan American Games]] and the [[2015 Parapan American Games]].<ref name=GlobeAndMail2014-11-21/><ref name=TorStar2012-12-28/><ref name="mascot"/><ref name=Torontoist2013-04-18/><ref name="Austen"/> The Games were held in [[Toronto]], Canada, in 2015. The winning mascot was designed by Michelle Ing, Paige Kunihiro, Jenny Lee and Fiona Hong from [[Buttonville Public School]] in [[Markham, Ontario]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/sports/amateur/2013/07/17/pan_am_games_patchi_the_porcupine_introduced_as_mascot.html|title=Pan Am Games: Pachi the Porcupine introduced as mascot|date=July 17, 2013|work= [[Toronto Star]] | accessdate=July 22, 2015 | archivedate = July 11, 2015 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150711170205/http://www.thestar.com/sports/amateur/2013/07/17/pan_am_games_patchi_the_porcupine_introduced_as_mascot.html | deadurl = no }}</ref>
== Background ==
Pachi was unveiled on July 13, 2013.<ref name=NationalPost2013-07-13/><ref name=Cbc2013-07-17/><ref name="mascot2"/> Canadian schoolchildren played a role in narrowing the choice of mascot whose design is based on that of the [[porcupine]], an animal found in all 41 countries competing at the Games. There are 41 stylized conical spines on Pachi's back: one for every country participating in the Pan American Games. The spines are one of five colours, each of the five representing a quality the Games are said to endorse: youth, passion, collaboration, determination, and creativity.
Porcupines have relatively poor vision, so the choice of basing Pachi's design on a porcupine is said to be a symbolic bond with the athletes of the Parapan Games.<ref name=GlobeAndMail2014-11-21/>
The Games licensed "[[Inner Ninja]]" as Pachi's theme song.<ref name=GlobeAndMail2014-11-21/>
Seventeen performers were hired to don a Pachi suit, and play Pachi.<ref name=GlobeAndMail2014-11-21/>
{| class="wikitable sortable" |+ Selected Pachi's design and operating costs<ref name=GlobeAndMail2014-11-21/> |- ! Cost || Description |- | align="right" | $93,232 || Mascot Creation Challenge |- | align="right" | $32,900 || Promotional video about the Mascot Challenge |- | align="right" | $5,000 || Licensing Pachi's theme music |- | align="right" | $3,006 || Mascot selection photo shoot |- | align="right" | $33,250 || Mascot research |- | $472,184 || Print advertisements |- | $134,550 || Mascot payroll |}
After the Pan Am and Parapan Am Games, Pachi became the mascot for the [[Ontario Games]]. Pachi's appearance were slightly changed. The Pan Am and Parapan Am branding on the hat and wristbands were replaced by Ontario Games branding. The hat changed to white and the quills consist of red, green and blue colours.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.mtc.gov.on.ca/en/sport/gamesontario/meet_pachi.shtml |title=Meet Pachi - Games Ontario Mascot |publisher=Ontario Ministry of Tourism, Culture and Sport |date=March 6, 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|refs= <ref name=NationalPost2013-07-13> {{cite news | url = http://news.nationalpost.com/toronto/pachi-the-porcupine-unveiled-as-2015-pan-am-games-mascot | title = Rainbow-quilled Pachi the Porcupine unveiled as 2015 Pan Am Games mascot | work = [[National Post]] | author = Jessica Vitullo | date = July 13, 2013 | quote = Being awarded the Pan Am/Parapan Am Games was considered a big deal for Toronto but nothing heightens the spectacle of a major international sporting event like the unveiling of the obligatory mascot. }} </ref> <ref name=GlobeAndMail2014-11-21> {{cite news | url = https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/toronto/toronto-pan-am-games-mascot-has-cost-taxpayers-383045-so-far/article21712033/ | title = Toronto Pan Am Games mascot has cost taxpayers $383,045 so far | work = [[The Globe and Mail]] | author = Dakshana Bascaramurty | date = November 21, 2014 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150716185354/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/toronto/toronto-pan-am-games-mascot-has-cost-taxpayers-383045-so-far/article21712033/ | archivedate = July 16, 2015 | accessdate = July 16, 2015 | deadurl = No }} </ref> <ref name=TorStar2012-12-28> {{cite news | author = Kamila Hinkson | date = December 28, 2012 | title = Pan Am organizers set to launch mascot contest | url = https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2012/12/28/pan_am_organizers_set_to_launch_mascot_contest.html |newspaper = [[Toronto Star]] | location = Toronto, Canada | accessdate = March 3, 2015 | archivedate = July 11, 2015 | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20150711025210/http://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2012/12/28/pan_am_organizers_set_to_launch_mascot_contest.html | deadurl = no }} </ref> <ref name="mascot"> {{cite news |author = Jodee Brown |date = April 18, 2013 |title = Maple-headed beaver, punk porcupine among finalists for Toronto’s Pan Am mascots |url = http://news.nationalpost.com/2013/04/18/finalists-for-torontos-pan-am-mascot-include-punk-porcupine-and-dancing-twins-in-unusual-hats/ |newspaper = [[National Post]] |location = Toronto, Canada |accessdate = March 3, 2015 |archivedate = April 21, 2013 |archiveurl = https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20130421072756/http://news.nationalpost.com/2013/04/18/finalists-for-torontos-pan-am-mascot-include-punk-porcupine-and-dancing-twins-in-unusual-hats/ |deadurl = no |author = Ian Austen |title = In an Indifferent Toronto, the Pan-Am Games Land With a Thud |work = [[The New York Times]] |date = July 9, 2015 |url = https://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/10/world/americas/in-an-apathetic-toronto-the-pan-am-games-land-with-a-thud.html |archivedate = July 21, 2015 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nytimes.com%2F2015%2F07%2F10%2Fworld%2Famericas%2Fin-an-apathetic-toronto-the-pan-am-games-land-with-a-thud.html&date=2015-07-21 |deadurl = no |df = mdy-all }} </ref> }}

[[Pensacola Flyers]] ([[Eastern Indoor Soccer League|EISL]]) (1998)
[[Pensacola Barracudas (indoor football)|Pensacola Barracudas]] ([[AF2]]) (2000–2002)
[[Pensacola Ice Flyers]] ([[Southern Professional Hockey League|SPHL]]) (2009–present) | seating_capacity = 10,000 (8,150 for hockey) }} '''Pensacola Bay Center''' (formerly '''Pensacola Civic Center''') is an [[indoor arena]] located in [[Pensacola, Florida]]. It is owned by [[Escambia County, Florida|Escambia County]] and operated by [[SMG (property management)|SMG Management]]. The Bay Center has a capacity of 8,150 for hockey games, and as much as 10,000 for non-hockey events. The arena contains {{convert|23000|sqft|m2|-2}} of space and {{convert|10000|sqft|m2|-3}} of meeting space. The Escambia County Commission voted to rename the arena the Pensacola Bay Center on October 18, 2012 as part of a citywide [[rebranding]] effort begun by Pensacola [[Mayor]] [[Ashton Hayward]].http://www.pensacoladigest.com/2012/10/civic-center-renamed-pensacola-bay-center/http://www.weartv.com/newsroom/top_stories/videos/wear_pensacola-civic-center-rebranded-renamed-26050.shtml ==Sporting events== The Bay Center opened in January 1985.{{cite news |title=Civic Centers Built With $20.5 Million in Taxes Open Soon|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=1jxWAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qukDAAAAIBAJ&pg=5825,1555077&dq=en|newspaper=Gainesville Sun|date=January 20, 1985}} Beginning in the fall of 1996, it was used primarily as the home of the [[Pensacola Ice Pilots]] hockey team until the team's exit from the [[ECHL]] on June 23, 2008. Hockey returned to the Civic Center, however, in fall 2009 when the [[Pensacola Ice Flyers]] of the [[Southern Professional Hockey League]] began play. Other minor professional teams have used the Civic Center as its home. From 2000 to 2002, the [[Pensacola Barracudas (arena football)|Pensacola Barracudas]] played in the [[af2]].The Pensacola Tornados of the Continental Basketball Association (CBA)played at the Civic Center from 1985-1991. In 1998, the [[Pensacola Flyers]] of the [[Eastern Indoor Soccer League]] played for one season. Various sporting events have taken place at PBC, including wrestling and rodeos. [[World Championship Wrestling]] hosted their November 1993 [[pay-per-view]] event [[Battlebowl]] at the Civic Center. It has also been the multiple-time home of the U.S. Roller Skating National Championships. ==Concerts== On February 27, 1990, [[Janet Jackson]] opened her [[Rhythm Nation World Tour]] in Pensacola. The tour's dress rehearsal at the Pensacola Civic Center Tickets Issued 7.600 to the public as a benefit to local charity, Which sold out in less than an hour. [[Kiss (band)|KISS]] was the first band to perform at the arena, and continues to make Pensacola a destination on its North American tours. Perhaps the biggest concert ever at the Pensacola Bay Center never took place. [[Michael Jackson]] used the venue to rehearse for his Bad World Tour for nearly a month in 1988, but did not perform a public concert at the venue. On 4/9/91 Yes played the first show on their Union tour at The Pensacola Bay Center. This is notable because it was the first show Yes played with the 8 man line up of Jon Anderson, Chris Squire, Steve Howe, Rick Wakeman, Alan White, Bill Bruford, Trevor Rabin and Tony Kaye, which was just recently elected to the Rock n Roll Hall of Fame. Many other large touring acts, including [[AC/DC]], [[Page & Plant]], [[David Bowie]], [[Rush (band)|Rush]] & [[Van Halen]] have used the arena for pre-tour rehearsals in the past, thanks to the venue's relatively inexpensive rental rates and availability for extended occupation. (Rush performed there on February 25, 1992 as part of their ''[[Roll the Bones Tour]]''.) On March 9, 1994, the Pensacola Bay Center hosted the largest [[Rock for Choice]] concert in history, which was organized by the band [[L7 (band)|L7]] and headlined by [[Pearl Jam]].[http://www.feminist.org/welcome/chronology/fm_1994.html Feminist Majority Foundation] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061207224531/http://www.feminist.org/welcome/chronology/fm_1994.html |date=2006-12-07 }} On February 26, 1995, Jimmy Page & Robert Plant played a show on their [[No Quarter Tour]] in Pensacola. On March 11, 1995, Van Halen opened [[The Balance "Ambulance" Tour]] in Pensacola. In March 2000, [[Britney Spears]] kicked off her [[Crazy 2K Tour]]. In February 2012, [[Jeff Dunham]] appeared performing "Uncontrolled Chaos". The largest attendance for a concert was over 12,000 for AC/DC in 1988 and Bon Jovi in 1989. [[The Florida SpringFest|Springfest]], an annual music event in downtown Pensacola, used the arena in its final years. [[Lynyrd Skynyrd]] has also performed there and the arena also featured moderately in the music video for "[[What's Your Name (Lynyrd Skynyrd song)|What's Your Name]]" (with [[Johnny Van Zant]] and a newly reformed Lynyrd Skynyrd performing a live concert as part of the music video) ==Politics== The Pensacola Bay Center has also had various guest speakers, including President [[George W. Bush]] in 2006. During the [[United States presidential election, 2008|2008 Presidential race]], both [[Sarah Palin]] and [[Michelle Obama]] used the venue for political rallies as the November election drew close. Republican Presidential nominee [[Mitt Romney]] visited the venue for a campaign rally on November 3, 2012 as part of his final push in the [[United States presidential election]] Republican candidate [[Donald Trump]] visited on January 13, 2016, during the Republican primary. Trump also visited again on September 9, during his presidential campaign against [[Hillary Clinton]].{{citation needed|date=January 2017}} ==External links== * [http://www.pensacolabaycenter.com/ Pensacola Bay Center Official Site] ==References== {{reflist}} {{SPHL}} {{coord|30.416485|-87.209372|type:landmark|display=title}} [[Category:Arena football venues]] [[Category:Convention centers in Florida]] [[Category:Music venues in Florida]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Florida]] [[Category:Indoor soccer venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues in Pensacola, Florida]] [[Category:1985 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Florida]] [[Category:Continental Basketball Association venues]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1985]]

revision.text:
[[Image:Fieldboots.jpg|thumb|250px|Black English riding field boots]]
A '''riding boot''' is a [[boot]] made to be used for [[equestrianism|horse riding]]. The classic boot comes high enough up the leg to prevent the leathers of the [[saddle]] from pinching the leg of the rider, has a sturdy toe to protect the rider's foot when on the ground and has a distinct heel to prevent the foot from sliding through the [[stirrup]]. The sole is smooth or lightly textured to avoid being caught on the tread of the stirrup in the event of a fall.
The modern riding boot is relatively low-[[heel]]ed, with a heel of less than one inch, though historically a higher heel was common, as it has always been critically important for riding boots to prevent the foot from slipping through the [[stirrup]]. Today, only some styles of [[cowboy boot]] retain a higher heel than other modern riding boots.
== English riding designs == For the riding disciplines that fall into the category of [[English riding]], there are a number of different styles of riding boots, intended for different styles of riding, from [[horse show]]s, to [[pleasure riding]]. Tall boots, which end just below the knee of the rider, include field, dress, and hunt boots. These are standard show apparel, worn by all competitors in the hunter/jumper and dressage disciplines. A lower, paddock boot that stops just above the ankle, is worn by children, by some show competitors in the UK, Australia, and by those that show [[Saddle seat]]...
'''Field boots''': so called because they were traditionally worn by officers ranked "[[Field Grade Officers|field grade]]" or higher, have lacing at the [[shoe|vamp]], which allows for some give so the rider is more comfortable riding with the highly flexed ankle that develops from the shorter stirrup length required for work over fences. Therefore, field boots are preferred in all jumping disciplines, including [[Hunt seat]] [[equitation]], [[show jumping]], [[fox hunting]], and both jumping phases in [[eventing]]. They are also worn by [[police officers]] riding motorcycles or on [[police horse|mounted]] patrols, and by some [[police]] agencies as part of their "Class A" uniform or with ceremonial mounted units. The majority of field boots are black, although brown-colored boots may also be purchased.<ref name=Catalog>Price, Steven D. (ed.) ''The Whole Horse Catalog: Revised and Updated'' New York:Fireside 1998 {{ISBN|0-684-83995-4}} p. 209-211</ref>
'''Dress boots''': do not have lacing at the ankle, and are generally stiffer. They are worn by [[dressage]] riders, [[eventer]]s in the dressage phase, and at formal [[fox hunting|fox hunts]]. They are also worn by riders of [[show jumper]]s. Dress boots are traditionally black in color.<ref name=Catalog/> A recent fad is dress boots for dressage that are cut to go extra high on the outside of the knee.
[[Image:Paddockboots.jpg|thumb|Paddock style black leather boots, well worn.]]
'''Hunt boots''', or '''Top boots''': like the dress boot, except it has a "cuff" at the top. The boot is usually black, with a tan cuff (traditional for male riders). It is appropriate for [[fox hunting]].<ref name=Catalog/>
[[Image:HalfChaps1.jpg|thumb|150px|left|Half chaps worn over paddock boots duplicate the protection and visual line of a tall boot]]
'''Paddock boots''', also known as '''[[Jodhpur boot]]s''', are short boots that come just above the ankle, used most often for pleasure riding and everyday use.<ref name=Catalog/> They are also required for [[Saddle seat]] style riding<ref name=Crabtree>Crabtree, Helen K. ''Saddle Seat Equitation: The Definitive Guide'' Revised Edition New York:Doubleday 1982 {{ISBN|0-385-17217-6}} p. 92</ref> and are frequently worn by children when showing in [[hunt seat]] disciplines because they are less costly for rapidly growing children than are tall boots. They are sometimes combined with [[chaps|half chaps]], a type of [[gaiter]] also known as chapettes, for added protection or to give the visual impression of a tall boot. The lace-up style is primarily seen in [[hunt seat]] riding, whereas the elastic-sided [[Chelsea boot]] design is seen in both hunt seat and saddle seat disciplines. The elastic side boot is also commonly used in Australia as a riding boot and dress boot. They are part of the required attire in [[Australian Stock Horse]] turnout competitions and for [[Pony Club]] riding. Heavier versions, such as [[Blundstone]] boots, are made for general work and gardening but are not suitable for riding owing to their heavy, deep-grooved soles.
Field boots (and many paddock boots) have an extra layer of leather on the toe, called a toe cap. All styles have somewhat tapered, round toes. Current styles include zip-on boots, with a zipper running down the back of the calf of a tall boot or the front of a paddock boot, making them easier to put on and remove without aid of boot hooks or a [[boot jack]].
Brown tall boots (field or dress) were somewhat more common before [[World War II]], when the English riding habit lost popularity outside of formal and/or [[horse show]] events. The [[U.S. Army]], whose officers had worn high brown boots in [[World War I]], abandoned the practice by the late 1930s. For a time, some show sanctioning organizations did not allow brown boots, considering them to be casual attire, although the rule has been relaxed somewhat.
==Cowboy boots== [[Image:Blackcowboyboots.jpg|thumb|left|Black leather western Cowboy boots with "walking" heels.]] {{main|Cowboy boot}}
For [[western riding]] and [[horse show|showing]], western riders wear [[cowboy boot]]s, with either the high "cowboy" or "riding" heel; the intermediate, somewhat lower "walking" heel; or the low, "roper" style heel that is similar to that of English boots. The uppers may vary in height. The lowest is the "roper" style that stops just a bit above the ankle, about an inch or so higher than the English paddock boot. The most classic length is the mid-calf height that keeps the fenders of a [[western saddle]] from chafing the ankle and calf of the rider. The tallest cowboy boots are seldom seen outside of fashion venues, but have an upper that reaches nearly to the knee, are usually extensively decorated, but in the modern day are seldom used for actual horse riding. For pleasure riding, lace-up or zip-up boots similar to English paddock boots, have become popular in recent years, though the classic pull-on boot still is common. Cowboy boots are traditionally made of smooth cowhide, though occasionally a boot style may be of a [[suede]] or "roughout" look. However, the uppers of more expensive designs may be made of leather obtained from somewhat exotic creatures, including alligator, ostrich and snakeskin.<ref name=Catalog/>
== Materials == [[Image:HooksAndBootjack.jpg|thumb|Boot hooks may be required to pull on some riding boots, and a [[boot jack]] is often helpful when removing them]]
Traditionally, English riding boots are made of smooth leather, usually cowhide, or occasionally pigskin, and most show boots remain thus due to the classic look. However, synthetic leather, vinyl and other materials are becoming more common. Quality of leather varies, with softer, finer-quality increasing the value of the boot. For formal wear, [[patent leather]] is occasionally seen, particularly in jodhpur boots designed for [[saddle seat]] [[horse show]] classes held after 6:00 pm, when formal attire may be worn in certain types of competition.
For casual riding, riders often wear well-worn show boots, but also may take advantage of new boot designs modeled after the athletic shoe or hiking boot that have been created, using space age synthetics and breathable materials to create what essentially is a "tennis shoe with a heel."
== References == {{commons category|Riding boots}} {{reflist}}
{{Footwear}}
[[Category:Boots]] [[Category:Sports footwear]] [[Category:Rider apparel]]
