revision.text:
{{Infobox venue | name = Smart Araneta Coliseum | nickname = The Big Dome | logo_image = Smartaranetacoliseum logo.png | logo_size = 180px | image = File:Araneta Coliseum (Araneta Center, Cubao, Quezon City)(2017-08-13).jpg | image_size = 280px | image_alt = | caption = | fullname = | former_names = Araneta Coliseum (1960–2011) | location = [[Araneta Center]], [[Cubao]], [[Quezon City]], [[Metro Manila]] | coordinates = {{Coord|14|37|14|N|121|3|12|E|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = 1957 | built = 1958 | opened = March 16, 1960 | renovated = 1999 | expanded = | owner = Progressive Development Corporation | operator = United Promotions, Inc. (Uniprom) | surface = | scoreboard = ADSystems 4-side LED display (Big Cube), OES ISC9000 Controller, and Homeworks Trading timer | cost = {{Philippine peso|6 million}} (1958) | architect = Dominador Lugtu | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = Basketball: 15,959{{cite web|title=SEATING- Basketball|url=https://www.smartaranetacoliseum.com/seating.php|website=Smart Araneta Coliseum|accessdate=8 March 2018}}
Concert: 9,679{{cite web|title=SEATING- Concert|url=https://www.smartaranetacoliseum.com/seating.php|website=Smart Araneta Coliseum|accessdate=8 March 2018}}
Boxing: 15,895{{cite web|title=SEATING- Boxing|url=https://www.smartaranetacoliseum.com/seating.php|website=Smart Araneta Coliseum|accessdate=8 March 2018}}
Full house: 16,035{{cite web|title=10 Popular Venues in Manila for Big Events|url=http://primer.com.ph/business/2016/10/03/10-popular-venues-in-manila-for-big-events/|website=Philippine Primer|accessdate=8 March 2018}} to 20,000 https://www.aranetagroup.com/aci.php
Record: 25,000–36,000https://peopleasia.ph/?p=164
| suites = | record_attendance = | dimensions = | acreage = | publictransit = {{rint|metro}} {{rint|manila|MRT-3}} {{mrt|Araneta Center–Cubao}}
{{rint|metro}} {{rint|manila|2}} {{lrt|Araneta Center–Cubao}} | tenants = [[National Collegiate Athletic Association (Philippines)|NCAA]] (1960–2012)
[[University Athletic Association of the Philippines|UAAP]] (1960–present)
[[Philippine Basketball Association|PBA]] (1975–1984, 1995–present)
[[Binibining Pilipinas]] (1964–present)
[[UNTV Cup]] (2013–present)
[[Philippine Super Liga]] (2014–present)
[[MPBL]] (2018–present) }} The '''Smart Araneta Coliseum''', known as '''The Big Dome''', is an indoor multi-purpose [[arena|sports arena]] that is part of the [[Araneta Center]] in the [[Cubao]] area of [[Quezon City]], [[Philippines]]. It is one of the largest indoor arenas in Asia, and it is also one of the largest clear span domes in the world. The dome measures approximately 108.0 meters making it the largest dome in Asia from its opening in 1960 until 2001 when it was surpassed by the [[Ōita Stadium]] in Japan with a dome measuring 274.0 meters.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} The Smart Araneta Coliseum is mostly used for sports such as basketball. It is a main venue of the [[Philippine Basketball Association]]{{cite web|url=http://www.interaksyon.com/interaktv/big-dome-still-main-pba-venue-but-moa-arena-an-alternative-option|title=Big Dome still main PBA venue, but MOA Arena an alternative option|work=InterAksyon.com|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140306225704/http://www.interaksyon.com/interaktv/big-dome-still-main-pba-venue-but-moa-arena-an-alternative-option|archivedate=2014-03-06|df=}} and for the basketball games of the [[National Collegiate Athletic Association (Philippines)|National Collegiate Athletic Association]] and the [[University Athletic Association of the Philippines]]. The Big Dome is also used for [[boxing]], [[cockfighting]], local and international concerts, [[circus]]es, religious gatherings, [[beauty pageant]]s and more.[http://www.smartaranetacoliseum.com/2006/corporate.php] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111111150406/http://www.smartaranetacoliseum.com/2006/corporate.php|date=November 11, 2011}} ==History== {{multiple image | align = left | direction = vertical | image1 = Araneta Coliseum construction aeiral shot.jpg | width1 = 210 | caption1 = Araneta Coliseum during its construction | image2 = Araneta Coliseum 1960s.jpg | width2 = 210 | caption2 = The Araneta Coliseum during the 1960s | image3 = Smart Araneta Coliseum - Green Gate facade - 2015-1226 (23350192134).jpg | width3 = 210 | caption3 = The Green Gate facade of the Smart Araneta Coliseum | image4 = Smart Araneta Coliseum - Basketball configuration - wideshot - 2016 (30183917215).jpg | width4 = 210 | caption4 = The Smart Araneta Coliseum during the Game 1 of the [[w:Barangay Ginebra San Miguel|Barangay Ginebra]]–[[w:Meralco Bolts|Meralco]] championship series for the [[w:2016 PBA Governors' Cup|2016 PBA Governors' Cup]]. }} In 1952, [[J. Amado Araneta]], a member of the [[Araneta family]], purchased from [[RCA|Radio Corporation of America]] (RCA) {{convert|35|hectare}} of land in Cubao which includes the [[Araneta family]] home and is bounded by [[EDSA (road)|Epifanio Delos Santos Avenue]] or EDSA, Aurora Boulevard, P. Tuazon and 15th Avenue. The Araneta Coliseum was constructed from 1957 to late 1959, and designed and built by Architect Dominador Lacson Lugtu and Engrineer Leonardo Onjunco Lugtu. From 1960 to 1963, the Coliseum received international recognition and was recognized as the largest covered coliseum in the world.{{Citation needed|date=October 2015}} Today, it remains one of the largest [[clear span dome]]s in the world with a dome diameter of 108 meters.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} It occupies a total land area of almost {{convert|40,000|sqm}} and has a floor area of {{convert|23,000|sqm}}.{{cite news |url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=416704 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120906233605/http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=416704 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-09-06 |title=Mecca of sports |first=Quinito |last=Henson |authorlink=Quinito Henson |work=[[The Philippine Star]] |date=2008-11-19 |accessdate=2011-07-24 }} The coliseum opened on March 16, 1960, with [[Gabriel Elorde|Gabriel "Flash" Elorde]] boxing for the World Junior Lightweight crown against [[Harold Gomes]]. General admission then was 80 centavos and the reserve section was five pesos. Among the notable events to take place at the arena were the 11th and 34th [[FAMAS Award]]s, the 1975 "[[Thrilla in Manila]]" boxing match between [[Muhammad Ali]] and [[Joe Frazier]], in which the arena was renamed into the "'''Philippine Coliseum'''", and the annual [[Binibining Pilipinas]] beauty pageant. The [[Philippine Basketball Association]] (PBA) has played more than a thousand games at the Araneta Coliseum as of today{{when|date=October 2015}}.{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} Other basketball events hosted by the arena were the [[1978 FIBA World Championship]], a game between the [[1978 NBA Finals|1978 NBA champions]] [[Washington Bullets]] and a PBA selection in 1979, and the 1982 Asian Youth Basketball Championship where the Philippines defeated China in the final.{{cite news|url=http://www.philstar.com/thedeanscorner/columnscontent.aspx?articleid=416964&publicationsubcategoryid=69 |title=More on the mecca |first=Quinito |last=Henson |authorlink=Quinito Henson |work=[[The Philippine Star]] |date=2008-11-19 |accessdate=2011-07-24 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} [[File:Aranetacoliseum logo.png|thumb|Araneta Coliseum logo from 1999 to 2011 prior to naming rights deal with [[Smart Communications]].]] In the third quarter of 1998, the Aranetas and Pilipinas Shell (local arm of [[Royal Dutch Shell]]) started negotiations for a [[naming rights]] deal that would have lasted until 2008. The Aranetas, who wanted to retain their name at the arena rejected proposed name "''Shell Coliseum at the Araneta Center''". Instead, the parties agreed on a contract where Shell's name and logo will be painted at the arena's basketball court, a move that was almost shelved due to objections from other PBA teams because Shell owned the then-PBA team, the [[Shell Turbo Chargers]].{{cite news |url=http://www.philstar.com/sportsarticle.aspx?articleid=708020&publicationsubcategoryid=69 |title=Araneta Coliseum, now Smart Araneta |first=Philip Ella |last=Juico |authorlink=Philip Ella Juico |work=[[The Philippine Star]] |date=2011-07-20 |accessdate=2011-07-24 }}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} In 1999, the coliseum underwent its first major renovation at the cost of P200 million.[http://www.aranetacoliseum.com/2006/circle.php Coliseum History] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060519132310/http://www.aranetacoliseum.com/2006/circle.php |date=2006-05-19 }} The major changes include the renovation of the lower box area, replacement of seats for the patron and lower box sections, and installation of a four-sided center hung scoreboard. The section names were also given numerical designations: 100 for Patron section, 200 for Lower Box, 300 for Upper Box A and 400 for Upper Box B. In 2003, a LED display was added to the scoreboard. From 2001 to 2008, the highest grossing event at the arena is the [[Pacquiao vs. Larios]] boxing fight between [[Manny Pacquiao]] and [[Óscar Larios]], earning 96.2 million [[Philippine peso]]s. A concert by [[Westlife]] was attended by 17,887 people and earned 18.5 million pesos, while a [[Cliff Richard]] concert earned 17.2 million despite being watched by 5,647 spectators. Prior to the [[2010–11 PBA season#Smart Ultimate All-Star Weekend|Ultimate All-Star Weekend]] in July 2011, it was announced that the Aranetas entered into a [[naming rights]] deal with [[mobile network operator]] [[Smart Communications|Smart Communications, Inc.]] (a subsidiary of [[Philippine Long Distance Telephone Company]]), renaming the arena into "'''Smart Araneta Coliseum'''". The deal was for five years and includes improvements the arena such as the installation of escalators to improve access in the upper box and general admission areas, and the construction of a parking lot that can accommodate up to 2,000 cars. Additional improvements were made in 2012, including the renovation of the Red Gate entrance and the Green Gate side [[facade]], and the replacement of Upper Box level seats, thus increasing its [[seating capacity]].[http://www.spin.ph/sports/basketball/news/pba-attendance-record-set-to-fall-as-major-facelift-expands-big-domes-seating-capacity PBA attendance record set to fall as facelift expands Big Dome's seating capacity], Snow Badua, spin.ph, November 13, 2013 The Lower Box and Patron sections were combined to make a new Patron section (100 and 200 level seats). A pathway between the former Patron and Lower Box sections was also made. The former Upper Box A section (300 level seats) was renamed as Box section and the former Upper Box B section (400 level seats) is now referred as the "Upper Box" section. In January 2015, the Hydra-Rib basketball backboard first used in 1995 was replaced with a Spalding backboard. The backboard was first used in Game 1 of the [[2014–15 PBA Philippine Cup Finals]]. ==Events== [[File:Araneta Coliseum Basketball with Big Cube 2011.JPG|thumb|right|210px|The Araneta Coliseum with the "Big Cube" LED display during a [[Philippine Basketball Association|PBA]] game in 2011. This photo was taken before the naming rights with Smart Communications took effect.]] ===Sports=== The arena is primarily the home arena for the [[Philippine Basketball Association]] and the [[University Athletic Association of the Philippines]] (UAAP) basketball leagues. It annually hosts every [[PBA Finals|PBA Basketball Championship]], [[NCAA Basketball Championship (Philippines)|NCAA Basketball Championship]], as well as the [[University Athletic Association of the Philippines]] [[UAAP Basketball Championship|Basketball]] and [[UAAP Volleyball Championship|Volleyball]] championships, and also the [[Maharlika Pilipinas Basketball League]]. The facility has also hosted the 1975 [[Thrilla in Manila]], [[1978 FIBA World Championship]], the 2007 [[2007 WPA Men's World Nine-ball Championship|Philippines World Pool Championship]] and the [[2017 SEABA Championship]]. The coliseum will also be one the venues for the upcoming [[2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup]].{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/sports/2017/12/16/1768893/fiba-world-cup-venues-will-be-ready-2023|title=FIBA World Cup: Venues will be ready in 2023|work=[[Philippine Star]]|date=December 16, 2017|accessdate=January 5, 2018}} ===Entertainment and others=== {{main|Entertainment events at the Smart Araneta Coliseum}} The coliseum also hosts concerts, shows, graduations, seminars, [[ice show]]s, circuses, and beauty pageants. [[Sarah Geronimo]] is the youngest solo performer to stage a concert in the coliseum at the age of 16 with her ''Sarah Geronimo: The Other Side'' concert on September 30, 2005. [[Eat Bulaga!]], the longest running noontime show of the Philippines, also used the coliseum for some special events such as its 10th anniversary on September 23, 1989 in [[ABS-CBN]] and its move to [[GMA Network]] on January 28, 1995. The coliseum has hosted the [[Binibining Pilipinas]] pageants annually. From 1990 until 2016, the coliseum hosted [[Disney on Ice]] productions during the holiday season; in 2016, the [[Mall of Asia Arena]] in [[Pasay]] began hosting these productions.{{cite news|last1=Tantuco|first1=Vernise|title='Disney on Ice' in Manila 2016: 4 things you need to know|url=http://www.rappler.com/entertainment/news/147582-disney-on-ice-philippines-2016-details|accessdate=February 19, 2017|work=[[Rappler]]|date=October 6, 2016}} At the turn of the new millennium, [[Regine Velasquez]] held her iconic two-night sold out concert entitled [[R2K#R2K: The Concert|R2K: The Concert]], in support of her album ''[[R2K]]'', on April 7 and 8, 2000. R2K The Concert which became the most attended concert at the coliseum with over 37,000 attendees, was center staged and has used the [[seating capacity]] to its 360-degree maximum. Some notable international performers include [[Air Supply]] on 2008, [[Akon]] (on July 4, 2009),{{cite web |last=Beltran |first=Nelson |url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=474348&publicationSubCategoryId=70 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120909222212/http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=474348&publicationSubCategoryId=70 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-09-09 |title=Aquino faces rap for allegedly mauling fan | Sports, News, The Philippine Star |publisher=philstar.com |date=2009-06-05 |accessdate=2015-08-29 }} [[Kelly Clarkson]] as part of her [[All I Ever Wanted World Tour]] on May 1, 2010,[http://www.mb.com.ph/node/255730/kelly-clark/] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110225140217/http://www.mb.com.ph/node/255730/kelly-clark/|date=February 25, 2011}} [[Incubus (band)|Incubus]] (in 2008 and 2011), [[Carly Rae Jepsen]] (in 2013 and 2015),{{cite news|title=Carly Rae Jepsen in Manila concert|url=http://news.abs-cbn.com/entertainment/09/15/15/watch-carly-rae-jepsen-manila-concert|accessdate=September 2, 2016|work=[[ABS-CBN News]]|date=September 15, 2015}} [[Lady Gaga]] as part of her [[The Fame Ball Tour]] on August 11, 2009, [[Avril Lavigne]] as part of her [[The Best Damn Tour]] on September 3, 2008,[http://thefilipinoweb.com/music/avril-lavigne-in-manila-the-best-damn-tour/] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110706223835/http://thefilipinoweb.com/music/avril-lavigne-in-manila-the-best-damn-tour/|date=July 6, 2011}} [[The Black Star Tour]] on February 16, 2012{{cite web|url=http://ph.omg.yahoo.com/avril-in-manila/ |title=Yahoo Celebrity Singapore – Yahoo |publisher=Ph.omg.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2015-08-29}} and the [[Avril Lavigne On Tour]] on February 17, 2014, [[Kylie Minogue]] as part of her [[Aphrodite: Les Folies Tour]] on July 5, 2011, [[Bruno Mars]] as part of his [[The Doo-Wops & Hooligans Tour|The Doo-Wops and Hooligans Tour]] on April 8, 2011, [[The Script]] (in 2011 and 2013), [[Snow Patrol]] (on August 9, 2012), [[Taylor Swift]] as part of her [[Speak Now Tour]] on February 19, 2011,[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/02/19/11/taylor-swift-manila-concert] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110222144748/http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/entertainment/02/19/11/taylor-swift-manila-concert|date=February 22, 2011}} and [[Westlife]] in 2001 and as part of their [[Gravity Tour]] on September 29, 2011,[http://www.mb.com.ph/node/154494] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120913060353/http://www.mb.com.ph/node/154494|date=September 13, 2012}} as well as the [[American Idols LIVE! Tour 2011]] (on September 21 and 22, 2011),{{cite news|title=Thia would 'love' to meet Pacman, Aga in Manila|url=http://entertainment.inquirer.net/9401/thia-would-%E2%80%98love%E2%80%99-to-meet-pacman-aga-in-manila|accessdate=September 2, 2016|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=August 13, 2011}} and the [[American Idols LIVE! Tour 2012]] (on September 21, 2012).{{cite news|title=The 'American Idol' tour is ready for Manila|url=http://entertainment.inquirer.net/57480/the-american-idol-tour-is-ready-for-manila|accessdate=September 2, 2016|work=[[Philippine Daily Inquirer]]|date=September 8, 2012}} Following her performance with the American Idols LIVE! Tour 2012 five months prior, Filipino-American ''[[American Idol]]'' runner-up [[Jessica Sanchez]] had her first sold out solo concert at the coliseum on February 14, 2013.{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/lifestyle/12/13/12/dolphy-jessica-sanchez-top-2012-web-searches |title=Dolphy, Jessica Sanchez top 2012 web searches |publisher=ABS-CBN News |date=2012-12-13 |accessdate=2015-08-29}} The coliseum also housed [[K-pop]] artists like [[Super Junior]]'s [[Super Show]]-the first [[Koreans|Korean]] to perform in the [[arena]], [[2NE1]], [[SS501]], [[CNBLUE]], [[Highlight (band)|Beast]] and [[EXO (band)|EXO]].[http://www.mb.com.ph/node/305730/from-japan-] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110228053224/http://www.mb.com.ph/node/305730/from-japan-|date=February 28, 2011}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20180425031805/http://pulpmagazinelive.com/main/?p=859] [[K-Pop]] group [[U-KISS]] also had their concert at the big dome and later released into a [[concert]] [[DVD]] dubbed as [[U-KISS 1st Kiss Tour in Manila DVD]].{{cite web |author= |url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=578764&publicationSubCategoryId=70 |title=3 katao kinidnap ng A-SG | Probinsiya, Pilipino Star Ngayon Sections, Pilipino Star Ngayon |publisher=philstar.com |date=2010-05-28 |accessdate=2015-08-29 }}{{Dead link|date=December 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} It was the first time that an international artist released a [[concert]] [[DVD]] featuring the coliseum. [[GOT7]]'s first fan meeting in Manila was also held in the Coliseum last November 14, 2015. On October 12, 2014, the main celebration of the 75th Diamond Anniversary of [[Quezon City]] was held at the coliseum.{{cite web|url=http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/2014/10/11/1378764/kamuning-bakery-wins-qc-award |title=Kamuning Bakery wins QC award | Entertainment, News, The Philippine Star |publisher=philstar.com |date=2014-10-11 |accessdate=2015-08-29}} The Coliseum is also the home to the annual ABS-CBN Christmas Special, which is typically held during the early weekdays of the second week of December. ===Religious services and other uses=== [[Image:JILKKBExtreme.jpg|260 px|thumb|[[Jesus Is Lord Church Worldwide]] (JILCW) KKB Youth Summit 2012, with then Philippine President Benigno Aquino III]] The Big Dome also hosted a praise and worship concerts like [[Israel Houghton]], [[Parachute (band)|Parachute]], [[Don Moen (singer)|Don Moen]], [[Hillsong musicians|Darlene Zschech & The Hillsong Worship Team]], [[Sonicflood]], [[Planetshakers]], [[Hillsong Young & Free]] and [[Hillsong United]]. Starting 2017, The Annual [[Planetshakers Conference]] is being held at the coliseum.{{cite web|url=http://planetshakers.com/conference |title=Planetshakers Conference|publisher=planetshakers.com |date=2017-01-15 |accessdate=2017-01-15}} The Big Dome is also the venues of religious gatherings like the anniversary celebration of [[Members Church of God International]] also known as the [[Ang Dating Daan]], [[Christ's Commission Fellowship]], [[Iglesia ni Cristo]], International Convention of Pentecostal Missionary Church of Christ (4th Watch), [[Jesus Is Lord Church Worldwide]], [[Jesus Miracle Crusade]], Kingdom of Jesus Christ (during early years), Shalom CCFI (Every Holy Week), the Special Assembly of [[Jehovah's Witnesses]] and [[Victory Christian Fellowship]],[http://www.ccf.org.ph/ccf-turns-silver/] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120330025349/http://www.ccf.org.ph/ccf-turns-silver/|date=March 30, 2012}} and different talent search finales, like ''[[Pinoy Big Brother]]'', ''[[Pilipinas Got Talent]]'', ''[[Philippine Idol]]'', ''[[StarStruck (Philippine TV series)|Starstruck]]'', and ''[[Artista Academy]]'' (which held its one-time grand audition{{cite web|url=http://www.tempo.com.ph/2012/artista-academy-p20m-await-winners/ |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130503165552/http://www.tempo.com.ph/2012/artista-academy-p20m-await-winners/ |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2013-05-03 |title=Artista Academy: P20M await winners – Tempo – News in a Flash |publisher=Tempo |date= |accessdate=2015-08-29 }} at the coliseum).[http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/video/entertainment/06/12/10/12-performers-pilipinas-got-talents-grand-finals] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100616213731/http://www.abs-cbnnews.com/video/entertainment/06/12/10/12-performers-pilipinas-got-talents-grand-finals|date=June 16, 2010}}{{cite news| url=http://findarticles.com/p/news-articles/manila-bulletin/mi_7968/is_2006_March_12/starstruck-winners/ai_n34279465/ | work=Manila Bulletin | title=Starstruck winners known today | date=March 12, 2006}}{{cite web |url=http://www.philstar.com/Article.aspx?articleId=252603 |title=Matiyaga si Sr. Supt. Querol at dapat siyang premyuhan | PSN Opinyon, Pilipino Star Ngayon Sections, Pilipino Star Ngayon |publisher=philstar.com |date=2004-06-04 |accessdate=2015-08-29 }}{{Dead link|date=December 2018 revision.text:
{{Infobox stadium | name = Sparta Stadion | nickname = Het Kasteel | image = Rotterdam spangen spartastadion.jpg | image_size = 250px | fullname = Sparta Stadion | former_names = | location = [[Rotterdam]], [[Netherlands]] | opened = 1916 | renovated = 1999 | surface = | architect = J.H. de Roos and W.F. Overeynder (1916)
[[ZJA Zwarts & Jansma Architects|Zwarts & Jansma]] (1999) | capacity = 11,000 | tenants = [[Sparta Rotterdam]] }} The '''Sparta Stadion''', nicknamed '''Het Kasteel''' ({{IPA-nl|ət kɑsˈteːl}}) is a [[association football|football]] [[stadium]] in [[Rotterdam]], [[Netherlands]]. It is the home ground of [[Sparta Rotterdam]]. It has a capacity of 11,026. ==History and layout== The stadium is located in the neighbourhood of [[Spangen]], where it was built in 1916 as ''Stadion Spangen'' based on a plan of the architects J.H. de Roos and W.F. Overeynder. The name "Het Kasteel" (The Castle) is derived from the small building with two small towers which backs onto the south-facing tribune (Kasteel Stand) of the stadium, which looks similar to a castle. This building is the only authentical remain of the original design. It was built in 1916. The castle building, which is currently located along the length of the pitch, was originally positioned behind one of the goals. A famous incident took place at het Kasteel in November 1970, when [[Feyenoord]] goalkeeper [[Eddy Treijtel]] took a goalkick and shot a passing seagull down from the air. The stuffed bird has been on display in the museum at Feyenoord's [[De Kuip]] stadion and not in Sparta's museum much to the annoyance of some prominent Sparta supporters.[http://www.ad.nl/ad/nl/1038/Rotterdam/article/detail/2166258/2008/10/19/Vogelhits-van-keeper-Eddy-Treijtel.dhtml Vogelhits van keeper Eddy Treijtel] - AD {{nl|icon}} ===1928 Olympic Games=== For the [[1928 Summer Olympics]] in neighboring [[Amsterdam]], the venue hosted two [[Football at the 1928 Summer Olympics|football]] games. The first was on 5 June when host nation [[Netherlands at the 1928 Summer Olympics|Netherlands]] defeated [[Belgium at the 1928 Summer Olympics|Belgium]] 3-1 while the second was three days later when the Dutch team tied [[Chile at the 1928 Summer Olympics|Chile]] 2-2. Through the years, the stands of "Stadion Sparta" were often renovated and extended, but the most radical renovation took place in 1998 and 1999: the stadium was completely rebuilt according to a plan of the architects [[ZJA Zwarts & Jansma Architects|Zwarts & Jansma]]. During the renovation, the pitch was turned 90 degrees. At the same time, it was renamed ''ENECO-stadion'', after its main sponsor. That name was soon replaced by the present ''Het Kasteel'' ("The Castle"), which had already been the popular nickname for the stadium ever since it was built. ''The Castle'' was bought in November 2004 by businessman Hans van Heelsbergen, the manager of the textile company Hans Textiel and also the chairman of Sparta Rotterdam. Van Heelsbergen opened in this building a Sparta [[museum]] (and an outlet of Hans Textiel). ===Tonny van Ede Stand=== The Tonny van Ede stand is on the north side of the ground and stands along the length of the pitch, opposite the Kasteel Stand. The most expensive tickets are to be found here. It houses the changing rooms as well as the corporate boxes, the ticket office and the boardroom. The players' tunnel runs from the centre of this stand onto the pitch between the two dugouts. The stand was named after one of Sparta's most famous sons, [[Tonny van Ede]], in 2010. [[File:Sparta Rotterdam nieuw Stadion.jpg|300px|thumb|right|Main entrance at Tonny van Ede stand]] ===Denis Neville Stand=== The lowest priced tickets for home fans are to be found in the Denis Neville Stand. This is at the east end of the ground behind one of the goals. It houses the more vocal supporters of the club and is usually the first stand to sell-out. The stand was named in honour of one of Sparta's most successful managers, [[Denis Neville]]. ===Bok de Korver Stand=== Opposite the Denis Neville Stand, the Bok de Korver Stand is assigned as the family stand but also houses the away fans. Formerly known as the West Stand, it was named after Sparta legend [[Bok de Korver]]. ===Kasteel Stand=== Attached to the historic Kasteel building, the Kasteel Stand is on the south end of the ground and the club shop is based here as well as the Sparta Museum. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=512/edition=197029/matches/match=32329/report.html FIFA.com 1928 Summer Olympics NED-BEL results from 5 June.] *[https://www.fifa.com/tournaments/archive/tournament=512/edition=197029/matches/match=32333/report.html FIFA.com 1928 Summer Olympics NED-CHI results from 8 June.] *[http://www.rsssf.com/tableso/ol1928f.html RSSSF.com results from 1928 Summer Olympics football tournament.] {{Commons category|Sparta Stadion Het Kasteel}} {{Sparta Rotterdam}} {{Football venues in the Netherlands}} {{1928 Summer Olympic venues}} {{Olympic venues football}} {{Rijksmonument|524305}} {{Coord|51.919485|4.433619|display=title|format=dms|type:landmark_scale:3000}} [[Category:Venues of the 1928 Summer Olympics]] [[Category:UEFA Women's Euro 2017 venues]] [[Category:Olympic football venues]] [[Category:Football venues in the Netherlands]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Rotterdam]] [[Category:Sport in Rotterdam]] [[Category:Sparta Rotterdam]] [[Category:Sports venues in South Holland]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1916]]

revision.text:
{{Use British English|date=August 2011}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2014}} {{Expand Russian|Танковый биатлон|date=August 2017}} [[File:T-72B -TankBiathlon2013-01.jpg|thumb|Four [[T-72B]] tanks of the participants, 2013]] [[File:T-72B - TankBiathlon2013-27.jpg|thumb|Russian T-72B, 2013]] [[File:T-80U - TankBiathlon2013-13.jpg|thumb|[[T-80U]] tanks waltzing at the show, 2013]]
The '''tank biathlon''' is a mechanised [[military sport]] event promoted by the [[Russian military]], similar to the [[Canadian Army Trophy]], with some similarities to the [[winter sport]] of [[biathlon]]. It utilizes the complex training of [[tank]] crews including their rough terrain passing skills combined with the ability to provide accurate and rapid fire while performing maneuvers.<ref>{{cite news|url= http://www.vesti.ru/doc.html?id=1116256 |title=Сергей Шойгу сделает танковый биатлон новым видом спорта|website=[[Vesti (VGTRK)|Vesti.Ru]]|date=August 10, 2013|accessdate=August 12, 2017|language=ru}}</ref>
== Description == [[File:Мишень №12 «Танк».svg|thumb|right|One of the shooting targets used in tank biathlon (dimensions in centimeters)]] Participating tanks drive a three-lap route of 6–10 km. During the first lap, crews fire at targets positioned at distances of 1,800, 1,700 and 1,500 m. In the second lap, different targets imitating an anti-tank mortar ([[Rocket-propelled grenade|RPG]]) squad and an infantry unit are fired upon. These targets are at a distance of 600–700 m, and must be engaged with a 7.62 mm coaxial [[machine gun]]. In the third lap the tank crews fire at targets shaped like an [[anti-tank gun]] and [[ATGM]] unit using of the turret-mounted [[heavy machine gun]] at a distance of 1,200 m. One or more misses leads to an extra penalty lap 500 m long. On the final lap tanks have to go through various terrain obstacles; an obstacle missed or improperly traversed adds 10 seconds to the crew's final timing.
== Events == The United States received an official invitation in 2013 and an unofficial invitation in 2017.<ref>{{cite news|last=Rogoway| first= Tyler|url=http://www.thedrive.com/the-war-zone/11253/russia-challenges-u-s-tankers-to-compete-in-its-annual-tank-biathlon|title= Russia Challenges U.S. Tankers To Compete In Its Annual "Tank Biathlon"|website=TheDrive.com|date=June 7, 2017|accessdate=August 12, 2017}}</ref> In 2014, 41 countries received the invitation.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kramnik|first= Ilya|url=https://defence.ru/article/10689/|title=Гонка танковых чемпионатов|website=Defence.Ru|date=May 19, 2016|accessdate= August 12, 2017|language=ru}}</ref> === International Competition, 2013 ===
The first international tank biathlon competition was held at the Alabino proving ground in the [[Moscow Oblast]], on 12–17 August 2013. Four teams took part in the competition: [[Russia]], [[Armenia]], [[Belarus]] and [[Kazakhstan]].
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- !rowspan="2" |Place !rowspan="2" |Team !colspan="2" |Range 1 !colspan="2" |Range 2 !colspan="2" |Range 3 !rowspan="2" |Total time |- !width="30px" |{{Tooltip|H|Hits}} !width="30px" |{{Tooltip|P|Penalties}} !width="30px" |{{Tooltip|H|Hits}} !width="30px" |{{Tooltip|P|Penalties}} !width="30px" |{{Tooltip|H|Hits}} !width="30px" |{{Tooltip|P|Penalties}} |- |style="background-color:#FF6347"| 1 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{RUS}}|| 1 || 0 || 0 || 0 || 2 || 0 || 23:44 |- |style="background-color:#1E90FF"| 2 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{KAZ}}|| 0 || 1 || 1 || 0 || 1 || 2 || 24:36 |- |style="background-color:#FFD700"| 3 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{BLR}}|| 0 || 0 || 1 || 0 || 2 || 1 || 25:25 |- |style="background-color:#9ACD32"| 4 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{ARM}}|| 0 || 1 || 1 || 0 || 1 || 2 || 29:48 |}
=== 1st Tank Biathlon World Championship, 2014 ===
The {{ill|2014 Tank Biathlon World Championship|lt=1st Tank Biathlon World Championship|ru|Чемпионат мира по танковому биатлону 2014}} took place at the Alabino proving ground on 4–16 August 2014. Out of 41 nations that received invitation to the tournament, 12 sent their representatives. Every competitor (except Teams China and Russia) received a [[T-72|T-72B]] tank in the biathlon color scheme. Team Russia piloted the newest modification, T-72B3, and Team China brought their own [[Type 96 tank|Type 96A]].
Russian preliminaries for the event ran in several of [[military districts of Russia]]. Each district sent its top crews to compete for the Cup of Russia, and 3 finalists from that event formed the national Team Russia for the World Championship.
Participating nations also held preliminaries on their own, sending 3 top crews and a reserve crew accompanied by maintenance and repair personnel to Russia.
Random selection placed teams under following colors:
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- !Color !Team |- |style="background-color:#FF6347"| 1 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{RUS}} |- |style="background-color:#FF6347"| 2 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{MGL}} |- |style="background-color:#FF6347"| 3 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{VEN}} |- |style="background-color:#1E90FF"| 4 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{KAZ}} |- |style="background-color:#1E90FF"| 5 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{BLR}} |- |style="background-color:#1E90FF"| 6 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{ARM}} |- |style="background-color:#9ACD32"| 7 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{CHN}} |- |style="background-color:#9ACD32"| 8 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{SRB}} |- |style="background-color:#9ACD32"| 9 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{KGZ}} |- |style="background-color:#FFD700"| 10 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{IND}} |- |style="background-color:#FFD700"| 11 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{ANG}} |- |style="background-color:#FFD700"| 12 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{KUW}} |}
First legs of the tournament consisted of:
* Individual race * Sprint * Pursuit * Athletic stage
==== Final ====
The final competition was a relay race, the top 4 teams fielded all their crews taking turns.
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- !Total time !Team |- |style="background-color:#FF6347"| 75:14 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{RUS}} |- |style="background-color:#1E90FF"| 80:03 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{ARM}} |- |style="background-color:#9ACD32"| 90:56 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{CHN}} |- |style="background-color:#1E90FF"| 94:11 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{KAZ}} |}
=== 2nd Tank Biathlon World Championship, 2015 === [[File:Type 96A - Tankbiathlon15finalp1-15.jpg|thumb|A Chinese Type 96A at the 2015 tank biathlon]]
The second event of the series took part on 1–15 August 2015 at the same venue in Alabino. This year the Tank Biathlon was held as a headliner of the {{ill|2015 International Army Games|ru|I Армейские международные игры}} that included similar competitions for all things military, from artillery (Masters of Fire) and air force (Aviadarts) to field kitchens.
The athletic stage for the crews was removed from schedule.
Veteran of both previous events, Team [[Belarus]] decided to participate in the Army Games "only in the disciplines where we are absolutely ready" and thus didn't apply for the Tank Biathlon (after finishing only 5th last year). Consequently, Belarus won 3 gold, 50 silver and 249 bronze awards and finished 3rd in the total medal score of the Army Games, being surpassed only by [[Russia]] and [[China]].
The [[Nicaragua]] and [[Tajikistan]] national teams joined the event for the first time.
All teams were piloting upgraded T-72B3 tanks, excluding Team China which continued to field its own Type 96A.
List of participants with color scheme:

=== 3rd Tank Biathlon World Championship, 2016 === The third Tank Biathlon took place in Alabino as part of the {{ill|2016 International Army Games|lt=2nd International Army Games|ru|II Армейские международные игры}} on 30 July–13 August.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ptichkin|first=Sergey|url=https://rg.ru/2016/08/13/mezhdunarodnye-armejskie-igry-zavershilis-pobedoj-rossii.html|title=Международные армейские игры завершились победой России|work=[[Rossiyskaya Gazeta]]|date=August 13, 2016|accessdate=August 12, 2017|language=ru}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- !Place !Team |- |style="background-color:#FF6347"| 1 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{RUS}} |- |style="background-color:#1E90FF"| 2 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{CHN}} |- |style="background-color:#9ACD32"| 3 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{KAZ}} |- |style="background-color:#1E90FF"| 4 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{BLR}} |- |style="background-color:#1E90FF"| 5 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{SRB}} |- |style="background-color:#FFD700"| 6 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{IND}} |- |style="background-color:#9ACD32"| 7 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{AZE}} |- |style="background-color:#9ACD32"| 8 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{MGL}} |- |style="background-color:#FF6347"| 9 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{ARM}} |- |style="background-color:#FF6347"| 10 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{KGZ}} |- |style="background-color:#FFD700"| 11 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{ANG}} |- |style="background-color:#FFD700"| 12 ||style="text-align:left;"|{{IRN}} |} === 4th Tank Biathlon World Championship, 2017 ===
The fourth Tank Biathlon took place in Alabino, Moscow Region. Most counties uses same type of vehicle as previous year such as [[T-72#Models|T-72B3]] and [[Type_96_tank#Type_96B|Type-96B]] with the exception of India fielding with [[T-90|T-90 Bhishma]]. ''New Delhi Television'' reported that the [[Indian Army]] felt disadvantaged using T-72B3 tanks provided by Russia in 2016 and was keen to field its best tanks and best crews in 2017. However, As a result of the malfunction of both T-90 tanks including the reserved one, the Indian squad was unable to complete the race and were disqualified before 1/2 final.<ref name="ndtv_2017">{{cite web |url=http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/after-both-tanks-break-down-india-knocked-out-of-international-drill-1736699|title= After Both Tanks Break Down, India Knocked Out Of International Drill |publisher=NDTV }}</ref><ref name="hindutimes_2017">{{cite web |url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/india-knocked-out-of-tank-contest-in-russia-after-t-90s-develop-snags/story-TQRNInKysug3ATwr7PK1MM.html|title= India knocked out of tank contest in Russia after T-90s develop snags |publisher=Hindustan Times }}</ref>
After seven days of contests, Team [[Russia]] won 11 gold, 5 silver and 4 bronze awards and finished 1st in the overall ratings, and Team [[China]] achieved second place with 7 gold, 2 silver and 2 bronze.<ref name="result_2017" />

== International competitions == {{main | Tank Biathlon World Championship}} Competitions on tank biathlon are held in Russia every year from 2013, in July-August, at the [[Military training range]] "Alabino". Since the foundation of the tank biathlon in 2013, 23 teams participated in the world championships. 14 teams passed into the relay race in at least one season.
The table lists the teams' places according to the results of the world championships, as well as the best results in each season (indicated by color). The teams are ranked according to the best places in the world championships.

{{about|the yachting film|gods of winds|List of wind deities}} {{DISPLAYTITLE: ''The Wind Gods'' (film)}} {{Infobox film | name = The Wind Gods | image = The Wind Gods film cover.jpg | alt = | caption = | director = Fritz Mitchell | producer = David Ellison | writer = | screenplay = | story = | based on = 2010 America's Cup
33rd America's Cup | starring = | narrator = Jeremy Irons | music = Pinar Toprak | cinematography = | editing = | studio = | production companies = Skydance Productions | distributor = | released = | runtime = | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }} '''The Wind Gods'': 33rd America’s Cup''''' is a 2011 documentary sailing yacht racing sports film about the [[2010 America's Cup]] (the 33rd Cup) revised in 2013. The film is narrated by [[Jeremy Irons]], directed by [[Fritz Mitchell]], and produced by [[Skydance Productions]]. The soundtrack composed by [[Pinar Toprak]] won the 2011 IFMCA Best Documentary Score award. The film aired nationally on [[PBS]] (the U.S. ''Public Broadcasting Service'') in 2013. {{cite web |url= https://www.kqed.org/tv/programs/archive/index.jsp?pgmid=21489 |title= Wind Gods |year= 2013 |publisher= PBS Northern California KQED 9 }} ==Film== The film, '''The Wind Gods: 33rd America's Cup''', was produced by [[David Ellison]], son of Larry Ellison, and his production company, Skydance Productions. [[Larry Ellison]] is the syndicate CEO of [[Oracle Team USA]], the winning team in the 33rd America's Cup (AC33), and chairman and founder of [[Oracle Corporation]], the title sponsor of the winning syndicate. David Ellison collaborated with [[Julian Guthrie]] on the film. Guthrie wrote the nonfiction book ''[[The Billionaire and the Mechanic]]'' about the history of Oracle Team USA. {{cite news |url= https://www.bizjournals.com/sanfrancisco/blog/2013/05/ellison-party-celebrates-movie-and.html |title= Larry Ellison's private America's Cup party |author= Patrick Hoge |date= 9 May 2013 |publisher= San Francisco Business Times }} {{cite news |url= http://www.businessinsider.com/larry-ellison-graciously-stopped-a-journalist-from-being-tossed-out-of-his-private-party-2013-5 |title= Larry Ellison Graciously Stopped A Journalist From Being Tossed Out Of His Private Party |author= Julie Bort |date= 10 May 2013 |publisher= Business Insider }} The DVD and advertising campaign were produced by [[Bean Labs]], in conjunction with [[Mt. Philo Films]]. {{cite web |url= http://beanlabs.com/project/the-wind-gods/ |title= The Wind Gods |publisher= Bean Labs |date= 2014 }} ===Synopsis=== The film profiles Larry Ellison, [[Russell Coutts]], and [[Ernesto Bertarelli]]. Coutts is the skipper for Oracle Team USA who was hired away from Bertarelli's Switzerland's [[Team Alinghi]]. Bertarelli is the head of the defending champion, the Swiss syndicate Team Alinghi, running the yacht [[Alinghi 5]], while Oracle runs the yacht [[USA-17]]. The film proceeds to cover the proceedings of the [[America's Cup]] regatta, a championship composed of multiple rounds of racing. {{cite web |url= http://www.sailingscuttlebutt.com/2013/04/26/the-wind-gods-the-story-of-the-33rd-americas-cup/ |title= The Wind Gods – the story of the 33rd America’s Cup |date= 26 April 2013 |publisher= Sailing Scuttlebutt |work= Scuttlebutt Sailing News }} ==Soundtrack== {{Infobox album | name = The Wind Gods | type = Soundtrack | artist = Pinar Toprak | cover = | alt = | released = | recorded = | venue = | studio = Caldera Records | genre = Film score | length = | label = | producer = | prev_title = | prev_year = | next_title = | next_year = }} A soundtrack album was released, '''The Wind Gods: Original Motion Picture Soundtrack''', composed by [[Pinar Toprak]], released by [[Caldera Records]], ID# C6012, containing 19 tracks, 18 music and one commentary. The film score received the International Film Music Critics Association ''Award for Best Documentary Score'' in 2011. {{cite news |url= https://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/wttw-national-productions-to-present-the-wind-gods-204756291.html |title= Wind Gods |date= 25 April 2013 |author= WTTW National Productions |publisher= PRNewsWire }} {{cite web |url= http://caldera-records.com/portfolio/the-wind-gods/ |title= The Wind Gods |publisher= Caldera Records |date= 2014 }} {{cite web |url= http://www.movie-wave.net/the-wind-gods/ |title= The Wind Gods |author= James Southall |date= 5 January 2016 |publisher= Movie Wave }} ===Track listing=== {|class=wikitable |- !| Track !| Title !| Length !| Notes !| |- || 01 || The Wind Gods || 2:50 || || |- || 02 || First Race 1851 || 5:52 || || |- || 03 || Ellison vs. Bertarelli || 1:06 || || |- || 04 || The Best Man To Steer The Boat || 2:04 || || |- || 05 || Childhood || 1:52 || || |- || 06 || We Are The American Team || 1:02 || || |- || 07 || There Is No Second Place || 1:39 || || |- || 08 || Jimmy And His Father || 1:04 || || |- || 09 || The Final Race || 3:30 || || |- || 10 || It Was Personal || 2:07 || || |- || 11 || The America’s Cup is America’s Again || 2:17 || || |- || 12 || What’s At Stake || 1:05 || || |- || 13 || The Trophy || 1:33 || || |- || 14 || Dreams Are To Pursue || 1:15 || || |- || 15 || One Australia || 1:26 || || |- || 16 || The 12 Minute Cue || 12:18 || || |- || 17 || A Noble Defeat || 1:26 || || |- || 18 || Dreams Are To Pursue II || 2:40 || || |- || 19 || Audio Commentary by Pinar Toprak || 2:54 || Bonus Track || |- |} ==Workography== * '''DVD''': {{cite |title= The Wind Gods: 33rd America's Cup |year= 2013 |author= Skydance |publisher= AC Trimaran LLC }}; {{ASIN|B018A29AQE}}; {{UPC|4-260352-760120}}; ==Awards and honors== * ''Winner'' — 2011 [[International Film Music Critics Association]] (IFMCA) ''Award for Best Documentary Score'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * Official trailer: PBS Chicago WTTW, [https://video.wttw.com/video/wttw-specials-wind-gods/ The Wind Gods], WTTW Promos and Previews (05/02/13) * Official film website: {{cite web |url= http://www.thewindgodsmovie.com/ |archive-url= https://archive.today/20130620004333/http://www.thewindgodsmovie.com/ |archive-date= 20 June 2013 |title= The Wind Gods, 33rd America's Cup |deadurl= yes |df= }} * Official album webpage: Caldera Records, [http://caldera-records.com/portfolio/the-wind-gods/ The Wind Gods] (CD movie score) * {{imdb title|2820342|The Wind Gods (2013)}} ==See also== * ''[[The Billionaire and the Mechanic]]'' (2013 book), by Julian Guthrie, documenting the rise of Larry Ellison's challenge for the America's Cup * [[Wind (film)|''Wind'']] (film), fictionalized account of Dennis Conner's loss and then win of the America's Cup {{America'sCup}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Wind Gods, The}} [[Category:2010 America's Cup]] [[Category:2011 films]] [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:2010s sports films]] [[Category:2010s documentary films]] [[Category:Competitive sailing films]] [[Category:American sports films]] [[Category:American documentary films]] [[Category:American television films]] [[Category:Documentary films about sports]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:2011 soundtracks]] [[Category:Film soundtracks]] [[Category:Film scores]] [[Category:America's Cup]]

[[File:TVIS treadmill.jpg|thumb|right|Astronaut [[Sunita Williams|Sunita "Suni" Williams]] bungeed to the TVIS treadmill aboard the [[International Space Station]].]]
The '''Treadmill with Vibration Isolation Stabilization System''', commonly abbreviated as '''TVIS''', is a [[treadmill]] for use on board the [[International Space Station]] and is designed to allow astronauts to run without vibrating delicate microgravity science experiments in adjacent labs. International Space Station treadmills, not necessarily described here, have included the original treadmill, the original TVIS, the БД-2, the '''Combined Operational Load Bearing External Resistance Treadmill''' ('''COLBERT'''), and the '''Treadmill 2''' (abbreviated as '''T2'''). Some share a name, some a design, some a function, some use different (passive) vibration-suppression systems, some it is unclear how they differ.
The name for the treadmill (COLBERT) came about due to a naming contest that NASA held for what became the [[Tranquility (ISS module)|Tranquility module]]. Comedian and TV personality [[Stephen Colbert]] used his show ''[[The Colbert Report]]'' to encourage his viewers to write in votes to use "Colbert" during the contest. After the results of the contest were announced, NASA decided to use Colbert's name for the new treadmill in place of naming the [[Tranquility (ISS module)|Tranquility module]] after him.<ref>{{Cite news| url=http://www.cnn.com/2009/TECH/03/24/colbert.nasa/ | accessdate=15 September 2009 | title=Colbert tops poll to name NASA space module| date=24 March 2009 | publisher=[[CNN]]}}</ref>
== Exercise == {{Main| Space medicine |l1= Space medicine – exercise }} Following the advent of [[space station]]s that can be inhabited for long periods of time, exposure to weightlessness has been demonstrated to have some deleterious effects on human health. Humans are well-adapted to the physical conditions at the surface of the Earth. In response to an extended period of weightlessness, various physiological systems begin to change and atrophy. Though these changes are usually temporary, long term health issues can result.
The most common problem experienced by humans in the initial hours of weightlessness is known as [[space adaptation syndrome]] or SAS, commonly referred to as space sickness. Symptoms of SAS include [[nausea]] and [[vomiting]], [[Vertigo (medical)|vertigo]], [[headache]]s, [[lethargy]], and overall malaise. The first case of SAS was reported by [[cosmonaut]] [[Gherman Titov]] in 1961. Since then, roughly some 45%{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} to 75% of all people who have flown in space have suffered from this condition.<ref>{{cite book|last=Roach|first=Mary|authorlink=Mary Roach|title=Packing for Mars|year=2010|isbn=978-1-85168-780-0|page=94|chapter=Chapter 6: Throwing up and Down}}</ref> The duration of space sickness varies, but in no case has it lasted for more than 72 hours, after which the body adjusts to the new environment.
The most significant adverse effects of long-term weightlessness are [[muscle atrophy]] and deterioration of the [[skeleton]], or [[spaceflight osteopenia]]. These effects can be minimized through a regimen of exercise. Other significant effects include fluid redistribution, a slowing of the [[cardiovascular system]], decreased production of [[red blood cell]]s, balance disorders, and a weakening of the [[immune system]]. Lesser symptoms include loss of body mass, nasal congestion, sleep disturbance, excess [[flatulence]], and puffiness of the face. These effects begin to reverse quickly upon return to the Earth.
To prevent some of the effects associated with weightlessness, a treadmill with vibration isolation and stabilization designed for the International Space Station (ISS) was first evaluated during [[STS-81]]. Three crew members ran and walked on the device, which floats freely in the [[micro-gravity]] experienced during orbit. For the majority of the more than 2 hours of locomotion studied, the treadmill operated well, and vibration transmitted to the vehicle was within the micro-gravity allocation limits that are defined for the [[ISS]]. Refinements to the treadmill and harness system, which ultimately led to development of the COLBERT model, were studied after this first flight. One goal of the treadmill design is to offer the possibility of generating [[g-force|1 g]]-like loads on the lower extremities while preserving the micro-gravity environment of the ISS for structural safety and vibration free experimental conditions.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=Evaluation of a Treadmill with Vibration Isolation and Stabilization (TVIS) for use on the International Space Station |date=August 1999| volume=15| issue=3| pages=292–302| author1=McCrory JL| author2=Lemmon DR| author3=Sommer HJ| author4=Prout B| author5=Smith D| author6=Korth DW| author7=Lucero J| author8=Greenisen M| author9=Moore J|journal=[[Journal of Applied Biomechanics]]| publisher=[[Pennsylvania State University]]| pmid=11541844| author11=Cavanagh PR|displayauthors=11|last10=Kozlovskaya |first10=I |last12=Stepansov |first12=V |last13=Miyakinchenko |first13=Y |last14=Cavanagh |first14=PR }}</ref>
The treadmills are intended to help astronauts stay fit, fighting off the bone loss ([[spaceflight osteopenia]]) and muscle decay that otherwise comes with space travel. Astronauts use bungee cords to strap themselves to the treadmill in order to remain in contact with the equipment while in [[micro-gravity]].<ref name="bungee_running">{{Cite web| url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/behindscenes/bungee_running.html| accessdate=23 August 2009| title=Bungee Cords Keep Astronauts Grounded While Running| date=16 June 2009| first=Andrea| last=Foster| publisher=[[NASA]]}}</ref> Researchers believe that exercise is a good countermeasure for the bone and muscle density loss that occurs when humans live for a long time without gravity.<ref name="colbert_feature">{{Cite web| url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/behindscenes/colbert_feature.html| accessdate=23 August 2009| title=Do Tread on Me| date=19 August 2009| first=Amiko | last=Kauderer| publisher=[[NASA]]}}</ref>
== Maintenance == The original Treadmill with Vibration Isolation Stabilization (TVIS) that was recessed into the floor of the [[Zvezda Service Module]] was decommissioned in June 2013, disposed of on the [http://www.space.com/21516-space-station-treadmill-trash.html Russian Progress (50P)] in July 2013 and replaced by the Russian БД-2.
[[Expedition 20]] flight engineers [[Michael Barratt (astronaut)|Michael Barratt]] and [[Koichi Wakata]] have performed a complete overhaul of that treadmill to extend its life. Both treadmills will continue to be used, which will nearly double the availability of these critical work-out devices for space station crews.
Treadmill with Vibration Isolation Stabilization system (TVIS) also required repair in 2002, during [[Expedition 5]] while [[STS-112]] was docked. [[Valery Korzun]] spent an entire day performing maintenance on the unit.<ref name="repair1">{{Cite web| url=http://www.spaceflightnow.com/station/sts112/020926preview/index6.html| accessdate=29 August 2009| title=Radiator deploy, treadmill repair and a final spacewalk| date=26 September 2002| first=William | last=Harwood | publisher=[[Spaceflight Now]]}}</ref>
A serious design flaw with COLBERT [http://www.nasaspaceflight.com/2010/10/iss-updates-failure-investigations-future-configuration/ power system] was discovered in September 2010, within 10 months of being [http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/behindscenes/colberttreadmill.html commissioned]. A multiple day IFM was required in October in order to remove COLBERT from its rack and replace key power components.
== Naming COLBERT== [[File:COLBERT patch.jpg|228px|thumb|right|Official patch for COLBERT]] {{Main|Tranquility (ISS module)#Naming contest|l1=NASA ISS Naming contest}}
In early 2009 [[NASA]] held an online poll to name what became the [[Tranquility (ISS module)|Tranquility module]]. On the 3 March 2009 episode of ''[[The Colbert Report]]'', host [[Stephen Colbert (character)|Stephen Colbert]] instructed his viewers to suggest "Colbert" as the name for Node 3 in the online poll.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.colbertnation.com/the-colbert-report-videos/220492/march-03-2009/name-the-nasa-module-after-stephen |title=Name the NASA Module After Stephen |publisher=colbertnation.com |date=3 March 2008 |accessdate=4 March 2008}}</ref> On 23 March 2009, it was announced that "Colbert" had garnered the most votes, but NASA did not immediately commit to using the name.
Congressman [[Chaka Fattah]] had pledged to use congressional power to ensure that democratic voting is honored in outer space as well as on planet Earth, in response to the possibility that NASA would overrule the voting.<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.eweek.com/c/a/Government-IT/Lawmaker-Backs-Stephen-Colberts-NASA-Win-105780/| accessdate=23 August 2009|title=Lawmaker Backs Stephen Colbert's NASA Win| date=26 March 2009| first=Roy| last=Mark| publisher=[[EWeek]]}}</ref> On the 14 April 2009 episode of ''[[The Colbert Report]]'', astronaut [[Sunita Williams]] appeared on the show to announce that NASA decided to name the node 3 "Tranquility", the eighth most popular response in the census, and announced that they would name a new [[treadmill]] on the station after the comedian – Combined Operational Load Bearing External Resistance Treadmill (COLBERT). Colbert was invited to Houston to test the treadmill, and later to Florida for its launch.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2009/04/14/entertainment/e171111D36.DTL&type=health |accessdate=23 August 2009 |title=NASA names treadmill after Colbert |last=Coyle |first=Jake |date=14 April 2009 |publisher=[[San Francisco Chronicle]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418193327/http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=%2Fn%2Fa%2F2009%2F04%2F14%2Fentertainment%2Fe171111D36.DTL&type=health |archivedate=18 April 2009 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The treadmill was taken to the ISS in August 2009, aboard [[STS-128]]<ref name="space">{{Cite news| url=http://www.space.com/missionlaunches/090819-sts128-launch-date.html| accessdate=23 August 2009| title=Space Shuttle Discovery to Launch 25 Aug.| date=19 August 2009| last=Malik| first=Tariq| publisher=[[Space.com]]}}</ref> and was installed in the Tranquility module after the node arrived at the station in February 2010.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.universetoday.com/2009/04/14/colbert-on-the-iss/ |accessdate=23 August 2009 |title=COLBERT on the ISS |date=14 April 2009 |last=Atkinson |first=Nancy |publisher=[[Universe Today]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090418054410/http://www.universetoday.com/2009/04/14/colbert-on-the-iss/ |archivedate=18 April 2009 }}</ref>
NASA poked fun at itself in a humorous press release included in the [[STS-128]] flight day 6 execute package report which claimed that [[Jon Stewart]] demanded to be honored similarly but turned down the agency's offer to name the ISS Urine Processor "Space Toilet Environmental Waste Accumulator/Recycling Thingy" (STEWART).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nasa.gov/pdf/383132main_fd06_exec_pkg.pdf|title=Colbert Elated, Stewart Miffed|work=STS-128/17A FD 06 Execute Package|publisher=NASA|accessdate=4 September 2009}}</ref>
== Development ==
[[File:C.O.L.B.E.R.T. decal placement.jpg|thumb|left|The COLBERT decal being placed during construction]]
NASA Engineers started development with a Woodway medical treadmill design which is available to anyone on Earth, and they asked Woodway to nickel plate the parts and make some other modifications, but it is fundamentally the same running-in-place device as the commercially available model. The structures which support the treadmill are a different story. Without gravity to hold the runner to the surface of the treadmill, designers added elastic straps that fit around the shoulders and waist in order to keep the runner from rocketing across the space station with the first hard step. Designers also had to work out a way to keep the treadmill from shaking the whole station with every step. Preventing vibrations is relatively easy to do on Earth, but the station is floating just like the astronauts are, and it wants to react against any movement that is made inside of it. Even small actions can shake up delicate microgravity experiments taking place inside the station's laboratories. Developing a system to stop the vibrations was the biggest challenge, Wiederhoeft said.<ref name="colberttreadmill">{{Cite web| url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/station/behindscenes/colberttreadmill.html| accessdate=29 August 2009| title=COLBERT Ready for Serious Exercise| date=5 May 2009| first=Jeanne | last=Ryba | publisher=[[NASA]]}}</ref>
The first station treadmill, which was brought to the Space Station aboard [[STS-98]],<ref>{{Cite press| url=http://www.shuttlepresskit.com/sts-93/dto53.htm| accessdate=29 August 2009| title=Treadmill Vibration Isolation and Stabilization System – RME 1318| date=7 July 1999| publisher=[[NASA]]}}</ref> relied on a powered system of gyroscopes and mechanisms to reduce vibrations. COLBERT's Vibration Isolation System was designed to work without power, and also to be more reliable than its predecessor. COLBERT will rest on springs that are hooked to dampers, which are then connected to a standard-sized rack that has been extensively reinforced in order to handle the power produced by COLBERT users. The rack alone weighs 2,200 pounds, which is its contractual design limit, and is also louder than the first treadmill which is a trade-off Wiederhoeft said is necessary to increase its reliability. "Noise and reliability are fighting against each other here," Wiederhoeft said. "With a lot more time we could have had both quiet and reliable. We went for reliable, and did what we could with noise."<ref name="colberttreadmill"/>
Development of the treadmills was also utilized in order to further development of commercial products. Possible secondary effects of development include improved vibration and acoustic isolation applications in sensitive equipment such as equipment used in [[optical manufacturing|optical]], [[Electronics manufacturing services|microelectronic]] and [[precision manufacturing]].<ref>{{Cite web| url=http://www.sbir.nasa.gov/SBIR/abstracts/88/sbir/phase1/SBIR-88-1-12.05-8148.html| accessdate=29 August 2009| title=Vibration Isolation of Exercise Treadmill in Microgravity| date=12 January 2005| work=[[Small Business Innovation Research|SIBR]]| publisher=[[NASA]]}}</ref>
== COLBERT delivery == {{update|section=yes|date=March 2016}} {{Main| STS-128#Mission payload|l1= STS-128: Mission Payload}} [[File:Packing COLBERT.jpg|thumb|200px|[[Pete Gauthier]], a packing engineer for [[United Space Alliance]], prepares the COLBERT and its parts for loading into the [[Multi-Purpose Logistics Module|Multi-Purpose Logistics Module ''Leonardo'']] in preparation for launch to the [[International Space Station]].]]
A team of engineers was required in order to prepare COLBERT to survive the rigorous vibrations of the launch process. COLBERT had to be disassembled into scores of parts, separated into more than six bags and strapped to racks inside the [[Multi-Purpose Logistics Module|''Leonardo'' cargo module]], which flew to the [[International Space Station]] aboard [[STS-128]].<ref name="colberttreadmill" /> COLBERT was delivered to the Space Station in 2010, and resided first inside the [[Harmony module]], before later being moved to the [[Tranquility module]].
The packing team set out to make sure everything that is launched reaches the station in good working order. "If it's the COLBERT, or if it's something else, it's still not going to be useful in orbit if it's broken," said [[Pete Gauthier]], packing engineer for [[United Space Alliance]]. "The difference with something like this is that it's big and it's heavy, so we have to use our biggest bag," he said. "It's easier for the crew if you have all the pieces in one bag, but when you have six bags, you just can't do that." The astronauts on the station are expected to spend about 20 hours putting the whole thing together, including the vibration system. After assembly, the only care COLBERT should need is an occasional greasing of its bearings.<ref name="colberttreadmill" />
